business.start.para: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Sir Alister McMullin) took the chair at 2.15 p.m., and read prayers.

Senator DEVITT- My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Air. In view of the frequent and startling increases in its cost and because of lack of conclusive evidence us to the suitability for Australian requirements of the Fill bomber, and further, because of performance problems and anticipated servicing costs, has the Government given any thought to cancelling the purchase contract for this aircraft until the whole question has been re-examined? What are the broad terms of the purchase agreement? Are we irrevocably committed to this purchase virtually on the basis of an open cheque arrangement?

Senator McKELLAR- This question arouses some inquiry in my mind. Firstly, over the years the Government has been condemned for not having suitable modern aircraft. Now, when it is proposed to obtain what [ think can be fairly described as the most modern aircraft in the world and what is considered to be the most suitable aircraft for our needs, we are running into continual criticism on account of cost. This is a part of the price we have to pay for the defence of this country. We either get the most modern weapons and equipment that are available or we just lie down on the job we have of seeing that the equipment for the defence of this country is the most modern procurable. With regard to the rest of the question, I cannot answer it. I think it has been discussed pretty fully in the newspapers. If the honourable senator wants information additional to that which I have given him, 1 ask him to put the question on the notice paper.

talk.start.para: - -I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. J crave your indulgence, Mr President, to preface my question by saying that I was most distressed to read this morning in one of the daily newspapers that Senator Ridley, who is on sick leave in

speech.para: Adelaide, is on a twenty-hour call to be rushed to Canberra to vote on the Post and Telegraph Rates Bill. Will the Leader of the Government assure me and the Senate that pairs are readily granted by both the Government and the Opposition in cases of illness? I ask for this clarification in order to put an end to any fears or distress thai Senator Ridley or his family may have suffered because of this report.

talk.start.para: - Since I have been Leader of this House no request for the granting of pairs for sickness or for any other legitimate excuse has ever been refused. I think we have had the same co-operation from the Opposition and 1 feel that this is how we will continue.

- I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Following my question to the Minister last week concerning the Government's decision to extend Australian territorial waters, I now ask the Minister whether he is aware that a recent Moscow newspaper article reported that off the southern coast of Australia the Soviet had found dense commercial concentrations of fish and that its fleet would start intensive operations with modern vessels for both near surface and deep water fishing. In view of this report, has the Government made a decision as to whether the new territorial zone should be policed and. if so, how it should be policed?

- I made some inquiries of the Minister for Primary Industry and he has advised me thai he has not seen the original Soviet article referred to by the honourable senator but is aware of an article which appeared in the 'Australian' on 23rd March 1967, commenting on proposed Soviet fishing plans to the south of Australia. There is no evidence that the Soviet Union has conducted any substantial fisheries investigations within the proposed twelve-mile exclusive zone, and it is understood that the dense commercial concentrations of fish referred to occur welt outside it. Nevertheless, the need for policing the zone is recognised and consideration is already being given as to how it should be carried out.

- I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for National Development. What stage has been reached in negotiations with the New South Wales Government in respect of a request that the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority be engaged on Sydney's eastern suburbs railway project? Can the Minister state the latest date on which a decision can be announced as to the future of the Authority if its dissolution is to be prevented?

- The honourable senator will be aware that the Government announced that it would consult with the States to ascertain whether they had propositions which would justify a continuation of the Snowy Mountains Hydroelectric Authority. I read in the newspaper, and 1 understand, that the State of New South Wales is interested in building this eastern suburbs railway. My recollection is that this project has been a hole in the ground for very many years. I understand that it was started very many years ago by a State Labor Government but never passed the hole in the ground stage. Whether the New South Wales Government has communicated with the Commonwealth Government on this matter I am not aware. If the honourable senator will put the question on notice I will see whether I can get an answer for him.

- I direct a question to the Minister for Repatriation. If a soldier of the Regular Army, being a normal subscriber to the Defence Forces Retirement Benefits Fund, is killed in Vietnam and leaves a widow, then, on account of his death, does such widow receive payment from the Repatriation Department and from the Defence Forces Retirement Benefit Fund? Is any diminution made in the repatriation benefit payable to her if she receives a payment from the Defence Forces Retirement Benefits Fund, or vice versa?
- There is no reduction at all in either of the rates payable to the widow.

- ! ask the Minister representing the PostmasterGeneral whether it is correct, as reported in the 'Sydney Morning Herald', that a device has been provided to the Minister for Customs and Excise to enable him to scramble his telephone conversation so that unauthorised persons will not be able to intercept them. If this is so, will similar facilities be provided to all members of the Federal Parliament so that their conversations likewise will not be intercepted?

- I did see such an article in the 'Sydney Morning Herald'. If I might say so, the photograph accompanying the article was a little glamorised. The facts are that the Minister for Customs and Excise carries very heavy responsibilities which, from time to time, have to be the subject of conversations between himself and the head of his Department. I remind honourable senators that customs proposals, for example, come in after 4 o'clock in the afternoon. I do not have to tell honourable senators, far instance, that decisions are taken with relation to regulations which may relate to prohibited imports or exports. All of these matters are very complex and most technical. I find understanding the tariff difficult enough when discussing it in clear language without having to discuss these matters, as I often do, with the head of my Department in monosyllables or in guarded language on those occasions when I may have to take a decision on that very same afternoon. Because of the very heavy secrecy which affects, not only an individual member of Parliament, but the whole economy of the Commonwealth, I have indicated to my Comptroller-General that he and I should have a phone on which we can talk to one another completely freely and without inhibition when discussing questions of great magnitude about which I may have to make a decision almost instantaneously after probing questions and full discussions between us. I think everybody who has a proper understanding of the processes of the tariff and the processes of by-law regulations will readily understand the type of problem with which I am confronted.

item.para: Under the terms of the waiver Australia obtained under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade - GAIT - last year to enable our system of preferences for less developed countries to be introduced, it is possible for Australia to extend the scope of the system in the way now proposed. The countries which will benefit fromthe new proposal will be the same as those to which the existing preferenc es apply. They are as follows:

It is expectedthat small cottage-type industries of Pacific Islands like Fiji will obtain some limited benefit from our system of preferences. A further examination is being madeto see if anything additional can be done in this field.

asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, upon notice:

item.para: What will be the powers of officers of the proposed Special Reports Branch attachedto the Department of Immigration in relation to (a) interrogation: (b) entry and search; (c) property confiscation: (d) detention; and (e) direction?
What will be the penalty for refusal to co-operate with the Special Reports Branch investigating officer or to carry out advice or directions?
Will any migrant who conies under investigation be entitled to a public trial before any penalty is imposed?
Will migrants be subject to normal police investigation for any action thought to be illegal, a check, if necessary, by Australian Security, and a further check by the Special Reporting Branch?
If migrants' past records contribute to undesirable behaviour after arrival in Australia, does this not indicate faults in the screening of intending migrants?
If faults are not in screening and undesirable behaviour occurs during Australian residence, should not procedure adopted against Australians apply equally to migrants?
Will the reports of the activities of the Special Reports Branch and any investigations of officers be made public or made available to members of parliament requesting information?
Will any findings of any investigation be made available to any person affected?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Immigration has supplied the following answers:

quote.para: The honourable senator's questions are based on two erroneous assumptions:

item.label: (i)
item.para: The Special Reports Branch will be carrying out police duties;

item.label: (ii)
item.para: The Branch will be concerned with migrants as such.

quote.para: Neither of these assumptions has any basis.

The following are detailed answers: 1 and 2. The officers of the new Branch will merely have the powers already given to immigration officers by statute. It is not proposed to add to these. These powers are clearly defined in the Migration Act 1958-1966, Aliens Act 1947-1966, Passports Act 1938-1966, and regulations under these Acts. 3 and 4. The Special Reports Branch has been formed to study methods of prevention and detection of malpractice in matters administered by the Department of Immigration - which would include entry to Australia, acquisition of resident status by temporary entrants, citizenship and passports - and to examine individual instances of such malpractice which require thoroughinvestigation. Matters seeming to require prosecution will be referred to the Commonwealth or State police. Any prosecutions will be undertaken in acourt of law which in this country means public hearings. If a migrant is engaged in any illegal activity that activity will be investigated but the person concerned will not be investigated as a migrant. 5 and 6. Screening of migrants is not a function in which the Special Reports Branch will be concerned. 7 and 8. Reports by the Branch to the Secretary of the Department of Immigration on its studies of malpractice will be available to the public when disclosure is in the public interest but not otherwise. Persons arrested as prohibited immigrants or deportees must be told of the reasons for their arrest or details of deportation orders.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice:

quote.para: Is it a fact that Commonwealth medical benefits are paid to an insured patient for professional attendance or the attendance of a medical practitioner if the attendance is for an examination of the eyes of the patient, but such benefit is not paid if the medical practitioner prescribes spectacle lenses; if so, will the Minister seekto amend the Act to overcome the anomaly of payment for an examination that finds no illness or disability but no payment when a disability is discovered?

talk.start.para: - The Acting Minister for Health has furnished the following reply:

quote.para: Yes. Section 4 (4.) of the National Health Act specifically excludes the payment of Commonwealth benefit for a professional attendance in consequence of which spectacles are prescribed.

The medical benefits scheme was introduced to provide financial assistance towards meeting the cost of medical services rendered by legally qualified medical practitioners to persons who are members of registered medical benefits organisations. It was necessary to ensure, however, that the scheme should not discriminate against allied professions such as optometry.

For this reason it was decided that no Commonwealth benefit would be paid in respect of an attendance by a qualified medical practitioner at which spectaclelenses were prescribed. This places the patient in the same position whether the spectacle lenses are prescribed by an ophthalmologist or by an optometrist. In these circumstances, it is not proposed to amend the Act as suggested by the honourable senator.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Industry, upon notice:

talk.start.para: - The Acting Minister for Trade and Industry has supplied the following answer:

In the case in point, I have been advised that as a matter of policy the Ford Motor Company imports tooling only if local capacity is not avail able or if there is some unusual design feature which cannot be met by local suppliers.
I am further advised that currently there is no tooling or pattern work being imported or on order from overseas by the Ford Motor Company.

speech.para: This Bill has one purpose only and that is to amend the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act to provide for the exemption from sales tax of motor vehicle seat belts in all circumstances. Seat belts have for some years been exempt from sales tax under a provision which applies to certain classes of protective equipment, but that exemption is fully effective only when the seat belts are sold as separate items of merchandise. This is brought about because seat belts, in common with other components for vehicles, lose their separate identity when they are fitted to a motor vehicle. If already fitted to the vehicle at the taxing point, which is normally the point of sale by the vehicle manufacturer or wholesaler to the retail dealer, there is only one article - a motor vehicle - to be taxed. The seat belts, as part of the complete vehicle, then bear tax at the rate applicable to the vehicle. This deterred Australian vehicle manufacturers from fitting seat belts to vehicles on their factory assembly lines. Manufacturers who specify seat belts as standard equipment for their vehicles adopted, as an alternative, the practice of selling the belts as separate articles and arranging for their dealers to fit the belts after the vehicles had passed the taxing point. By this means they arranged for their vehicles to be supplied to customers with scat belts fitted while at the same time preserving the exemption of the belts. lt is well recognised that the wearing of seat belts contributes significantly towards reducing the risk of death or serious injury in road accidents. We would like to see seat belts in all vehicles, and consider that vehicle manufacturers should be encouraged 10 provide seat belts as standard equipment with all vehicles. I indicated earlier that under the existing law vehicles fitted wilh seat belts have been supplied to the public under arrangements whereby the belts do not attract sales tax. Nevertheless., there is little doubt that there are advantages in having the belts fitted during vehicle assembly operations when the fitting can be most efficiently and economically carried out. There is the added advantage that drivers delivering vehicles from factories to dealers' premises will have the protection of seat belts. The Government accordingly decided to take action to remove the present deterrent to the fitting of seat belts to vehicles in the course of factory assembly operations. Under these proposals sales tax will not be payable on so much of the sale value of a vehicle fitted with exempt seat belt assemblies as is equal to the amount which would have been the sale value of those assemblies if sold as separate articles. In the result, the value upon which sales tax would otherwise be payable will be reduced by the value of the seat belt assemblies incorporated in the vehicle.

The Bill will also provide for the specific exemption of seat belt assemblies which are now exempt under the more general provision to which I referred earlier. The exemption will apply to all seat belt assemblies, including those of the harness and sash type, that are designed for the protection of persons in motor vehicles. Parts and fittings for exempt seat belt assemblies will also be exempt. Under the provisions of the Bill, the proposals will be effective as from 12th April 1967, the date on whichthe measure was introduced into Parliament. The Bill is explained in more detail in an explanatory memorandum which is being made available to honourable senators.I commend the Bill to the Senate.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the National Library Act 1960-1966 to provide for the appointment of the National Librarian under the National Library Act itself instead of under the Public Service Act. as the present Act provides, and to lay down audit requirements which meet The particular needs of the National Library. Since1960 the Parliamentary Librarian has been acting as National Librarian also, under a transitional provision of the National Library Act. The National Library Council wishes to have the first appointment of a full time National Librarian made by the end of 1967 in preparation for the movement of the substantial collections and for the opening of the National Library building in mid- 1968. The Act. as drafted in 1960. provides in section 17(1) for the National Librarian to be appointed and employed in accordance with the Public Service Act. This method is now considered inappropriate. The proposed amendment makes the appointment of the National Librarian a matter for the Governor-General under The terms of the National Library Act itself.

The form of the amendment will need to incorporate the usual provisions for full time statutory office bearers, such as maximum period of appointment, age limit, remuneration as fixed by the GovernorGeneral, leave of absence, termination for misbehaviour or physical or mental in capacity, vacation of office due to bankruptcy or outside employment without approval, preservation of rights of a person appointed from the Public Service and application of the Commonwealth Employees' Compensation Act andthe Superannuation Act. The Bill also provides for an Acting National Librarian.

The Bill makes some changes in existing audit requirements in order to meet the special needs of the National Library. Sections 25 and 27 of the Act contain the normal audit requirements for a Commonwealth statutory authority, but experience has shown thatthese do not recognise the special position of a great library. The requirement in section 27 (3) (b) that the financial statement should showthe state of the affairs of the Library means that a balance sheet should be produced requiring an annual stocktaking and valuation of the Library's large and varied collections. This would be impractical since the Library holds many historical and other treasures on which a meaningful monetary value cannot be placed. It is therefore proposed that the reference to 'the state of the affairs of the Library' be deleted.

Another problem is that the authority of the Auditor-General under Section 25 (1) to audit the 'financial transactions' of the Library, does not extend to assets acquired by exchange or as a gift or transferred to the Library from an existing Commonwealth collection held elsewhere. It is proposed that the Auditor-General's functions be extended to include inspection and report on records of all dealings with property, whether or not expenditure is involved. 1 should perhaps remind honourable senators that these proposals are an integral part of the process of separation of the Parliamentary and National libraries. Honourable senators will recall that the National Library grew out of the Library of Parliament. Detailed proposals for the separation of the two libraries were outlined in the second reading speech when the then Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Spooner, introduced the National Library Bill in 1960. These included the appointment to the National Library Council of two members of the Parliament and the occupancy of the positions of National Librarian and Parliamentary Librarian by the one person.

The National Library Council, in its annual reports to Parliament, has paid tribute to the value of these arrangements in assisting the development of the National Library and the separation of the two libraries as ultimately independent but closely related institutions. During this process, which is now almost complete, honourable senators will also have noted with satisfaction the development in the services of the Parliamentary Library, including its research service. For these we are especially indebted to the Presiding Officers and the Joint Library Committee. 1 commend the Bill to the Senate.

This is a Bill to amend the Trade Practices Act 1965-1966 by extending its operation in relation to the Stale of Tasmania, and by bringing up to date a reference in section 4 to the Northern Territory (Administration) Act. The Parliament of Tasmania, by an

Act entitled the Commonwealth Powers (Trade Practices) Act 1966, has referred to the Commonwealth Parliament the matter of trade practices. Under section 51 (xxxvii) of the Commonwealth Constitution the Commonwealth Parliament may make laws with respect to such a referred matter. The result of the Tasmanian reference, therefore, is that the Commonwealth Parliament has the constitutional power to give to the Trade Practices Act 1965-1966 a full operation in relation to Tasmania. The present Bill is designed to give the Act that full operation. Its passage will mean, for example, that distinctions between interslate and intrastate trade and commerce will not be material to the application of the Act to Tasmania.

The Bill provides for the extended operation of the Act by inserting in the principal Act an additional section - section 7a. The result will be that all of the law applicable to trade practices relating to Tasmania will be contained in the Commonwealth Act. As provision is made in section 8 of the Commonwealth Act for State complementary legislation, I mention that the Act which the Tasmanian Parliament has passed is not, and was not intended to be, complementary legislation as envisaged in that section. The amendment proposed by this Bill in no way extends the subject-matter of the principal Act - for example, by applying it to new kinds of agreements or practices. Its effect is simply to take that Act, the provisions of which have been fully debated in this Parliament, and, with the help of the reference from the Tasmanian Parliament, to give those provisions an operation in the State of Tasmania which is not limited by reference to the Commonwealth's ordinary constitutional powers.

The other amendment proposed by the Bill is a drafting one relating to the citation of the Northern Territory (Administration) Act. Since the enactment of section 4 of the Trade Practices Act in 1965 the Northern Territory (Administration) Act has been amended by the National Debt Sinking Fund Act 1966. Sub-section (4.) of section 4 of the Trade Practices Act should, in consequence, refer to the Northern Territory (Administration) Act 1910-1966, and clause 3 of this Bill provides accordingly. Clause 3 also amends sub-section (7.) of section 4 of the Trade Practices Act so as to provide for the Northern Territory (Administration) Act, as amended by section 4 of the Trade Practices Act, to be cited in future as the Northern Territory (Administration) Act 1910-1967.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 9 May (vide page 1275), on motion by Senator Henry:

quote.para: That the Bil! be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: - The Senate is dealing with a Bill to establish an Australian Tourist Commission for the purpose of the encouragement of visits to Australia, and travel in Australia, by people from other countries. This is in line with the intention of the Government, as a first major step, to provide facilities for encouraging tourism from overseas countries to Australia, The importance of the tourist industry to Australia is well illustrated by the fact, referred to in the second reading speech of the Minister for Supply (Senator Henty), that during 1965-66 an estimated $65m was spent in this country by overseas tourists. Tourism has thus become a main source of exchange earnings and it is the ninth in importance in our trading industries. The Federal Government has not just commenced to take an interest in this matter because it has contributed to the funds of the Australian National Travel Association some $5m in grants since 1952-53. Last year this Parliament granted $862,000 for the furtherance of the work of that Association. Seventy per cent of the Association's funds has come from the Federal Government. So it can be seen that although this Bill is the first major step towards increasing the flow of visitors to this country it is by no means just an initial step by the Government.

speech.para: The Bill is assured of passage through the Senate as both sides of the Senate support it. It will activate the Government's intention to establish an Australian Tourist Commission which will be directly concerned with promoting, not within Australia but overseas, the travel of visitors to this country. The object will be to increase the number of tourists. Although the activities of the Commission will be based in Australia the great volume of its work will be done overseas. The purposes of the Commission are set out quite clearly in Part III of the Bill. To me it would appear that the powers of the Commission will be particularly wide. I have been unable to find any other commission which has parallel powers. Clause 1 6 (2.) (b) states thai the Commission will have power: to induce and assist travel agents, transmit operators and other appropriate bodies or persons to encourage people in other countries to visit Australia and to travel in Australia.

Reading the powers, I doubted whether a correct use of words had been made, because 1 would take "induced' to mean something other than assisting. I think the wording in various other clauses needs to be looked at rather closely.

The general propositions of the Bill appear to me to be quite sound. The costs involved in establishing such a commission should be noted but in the Bill and in the Minister's speech I find no mention of what the proposed cost will be. I believe that the Senate could be armed with some information as to what will be the mounting costs of this Commission over the years that ensue after its appointment. From my investigations into various departments which have activities overseas it seems that this point of costs involved in establishments overseas is of particular importance. From the Bill before the Semite, 1 presume that in many countries this Commission will be setting up offices. Probably it will be purchasing residences ai well as offices because these functions come within its powers. I suggest that the Government or the Parliament should arrive al a definite policy as to whether we should rent premises in instances such as this or whether we should insist upon ownership of our own assets. I suggest that we should be deciding whether, with this Commission working under the Department of Trade and Industry, we should involve ourselves now in the purchase and maintenance of luxurious but nevertheless adequate accommodation in which both the Department of Trade and Industry and the Commission could work. 1 suggest thai wc should own the land, if that is possible, on which our offices are situated. I read with great disappointment at times of the great volume of money we pay out by way of rent every year. We have now reached the horrible position where it costs us in the vicinity of $500,000 a year in rent for Australia House in London. This does not appear to me to be a sound proposition by any means. I suggest that in giving the Australian Tourist Commission power to set up offices in other countries we should provide that where possible these premises should be owned by Australia if the Commission is to remain in business.

talk.start.para: - But in an agency so flexible as a travel agency, is it not wise to have a rental policy?

- 1 would think not. Lel us take America as an example. I should imagine that the Department of Trade and Industry has already decided which are the most appropriate points at which to have offices, lt may be either renting those premises or purchasing them. 1 do not know what it is doing, but I do suggest that it would be wise to decide upon one central point. In all probability the Commission as well as the Department will be working from some major capital city. I sec the Minister nodding his head. He probably believes this is so.

speech.para: I feel that the provision relating to the control of the accounts of this Commission is in line with that provided for the control of the accounts of most other authorities. I suggest to the Senate that it is most important that we should have adequate safeguards to ensure the setting up of a proper system of accounting when establishing a new commission such as this. We should provide that the accounts shall be subject to review by the Auditor-General and that a report shall be submitted by him to this Parliament so that we may have some say in the matter. On looking at this from the accounting point of view, I believe that adequate protection is provided in the measure.

talk.start.para: - Does not the honourable senator think that officers of the Department of External Affairs stationed overseas can do all the work that will be required of the Commission?

- No. 1 would not agree with that. I think this is a specialist's job. 1 have not the time to go into all the facts, but I firmly believe that special qualifications are required to fulfil efficiently the offices of chairman and members of a commission such as this. In these times of great travel, intense publicity, and great need for efficient management special qualifications are required if a commission such as this is to be conducted efficiently. It is my belief that those engaged overseas in carrying out duties connected with the Department of External Affairs and the Department of Trade and Industry are not the types of people to be employed in this work if this novel idea is to be promoted correctly.
- I think the honourable senator is a little confused because he is accustomed to Melbourne conditions.

- No. 1 am quite sure that I would not be any more confused than would be the honourable senator from Queensland. This is novel legislation. We are all supporting it because we want to see the idea get under way. Generally speaking, it must be agreed that it is wise to establish the Commission in the way set out in the Bill. I have pointed out already that the Commonwealth did do something in past years to encourage tourism. I wonder whether, at this point of time, in promoting tourism we should investigate fully the likely results of introducing an increased number of tourists into Australia and the effects of the views they may take home with them. The Commission will not necessarily be the best supplier of new tourists to Australia. I believe our best advertisements will come from the individuals who, after visiting this country, leave it with a good impression and then recommend it to their friends. The publicity put out by the various State authorities has been particularly good but there is no uniform Commonwealth publicity designed to encourage overseas visitors to Australia.
- In overseas countries?
- In overseas countries, yes.
- There has been fairly uniform publicity from ANTA.

- I query that. If any honourable senator walked into an Australian tourist office overseas and asked for publicity in relation to Australia he would be handed about a dozen leaflets distributed by the various State authorities.
- I know that the honourable senator is wrong in that statement.

- I query that because 1 have had some conversation with people who know about this matter. I have gathered the impression that the picture painted of Australia is not very bright and that the individual who says: 'I am thinking of going to Australia. What will I find there?' will not be told very much. 1 think the publicity at present is more on a State basis than on a Commonwealth basis. Let me add however that the various State authorities and industries concerned with tourism have done a particularly good job. I think the Commission should be given power to distribute publicity literature on a Commonwealth basis. In any case it is essential that the present arrangement be improved.

speech.para: Within Australia we need to look to a variety of important matters which will affect the tourist. Transport within the various States is a most important item. I know that the Commonwealth says it is a matter for the States to improve their own facilities so I urge the States, particularly my own State of Victoria, to take this matter in hand immediately if they want to gain the full benefit of the provision to be made by the Commonwealth. I believe that air transport facilities in Victoria surpass those in any other State. However the Commonwealth should enter the field and provide adequate finance for the construction of airfields in major country towns. This has been lacking in the past. Now that jet aircraft are generally in use we should look forward and provide facilities for helicopters and jet aircraft at our major cities and towns because from those points tourists from overseas will be conducted to the extremities of this nation to what we imagine to be our tourist attractions.

Our ports of entry for visitors to Australia who travel by ship are neither attractive nor adequate. In Victoria our bayside attractions are not so good at present that they cannot be improved. Turning to roads, I am sure everyone must give credit to the Commonwealth for directing that 40% of Commonwealth grants for roads shall be devoted to roads outside the metropolitan areas. We will reap the benefit of that direction with the advent of more tourists. The width of roads, at least those between capital cities, should be increased, perhaps trebled, to cater not only for growing motor traffic but also, in the future, for jet or air cushion machines. Roads of a far higher standard are required.

Our railway systems need an overhaul. I do nol know whether a great number of tourists will travel by rail. Neither do I know whether the existing railway lines will be used in the future or whether overhead railways will be constructed. In any case, wc should be surveying rail links that will take the greatest advantage of the tourist potential.

The Commonwealth should make money available for the development of tourist centres although I imagine the argument will be raised that where private finance is available this should be used first. However I believe the Commonwealth Development Hunk should make available $50ni or $100,11 for the development of tourist attractions, the provision of guest houses and accommodation centres where these do not already exist, and the improvement of existing facilities. The State Governments could act as co-ordinating bodies in a survey of facilities available at camping sites and at hostels that are owned by youth groups. The Commonwealth Department of Education and Science, through the Australian Tourist Commission, could say to other countries: 'We are anxious to assist the youth of your country to visit Australia'. An inducement would be the improvement of facilities at YMCA and scout camps and at YWCA hostels. Both overseas visitors and our own youth would benefit from this. In addition young visitors from overseas would take back to their own country word about the good job that is being done in Australia.

Other honourable senators have mentioned their own States. For my part I believe that Victoria can provide the most outstanding attractions to visitors from overseas. At any time of the year, whether it be summer, autumn, winter or spring, we can offer tourist attractions. For a start, the improvement of our bayside areas makes entry to Victoria attractive. We have snowfields in the winter and the excellence of Mildura and surrounding areas needs no publicity. All this makes Victoria a most attractive State. The Commonwealth should be encouraged to make finance available to enable private enterprise to improve its facilities so that it will be able to luke full advantage of the increased number of tourists expected as a result of the selling up of the Australian Tourist Commission. 1 have great pleasure in supporting this Bill in the knowledge that honourable senators on both sides of the House realise that it will be of immense value not only to the Australian economy as a whole but also to individuals, particularly those engaged in the tourist business. Certainly it will result in more visitors to Australia and this in turn will lead to better relations with countries overseas.

talk.start.para: - All honourable senators who preceded me in this debate seemed to have a fixation about the number of tourists we will encourage to Australia and the matter of finance. J should like to strike another note. A keyword in this whole debate is conservation'. The idea of publicising the various attractions in this Commonwealth depends upon preserving them. To support my contention about the need for conservation 1 direct the attention of honourable senators to 'Walkabout', a journal which has the objective of attracting tourists. The current issue contains a fascinating article about the platypus. It points out that there are only two fauna sanctuaries in which the platypus is in captivity. One is the Colin Mackenzie Sanctuary at Healesville in Victoria and the other is the David Fleay fauna reserve at West Burleigh on the Queensland Gold Coast. A section further on in the journal contains a very informative article entitled 'Water for a Thirsty Land'. The large arid sections of our continent combined with limitations on our conservation activities demand more than the setting up of a commission to bring people to Australia. It is time for a little stocktaking so that we might hold on to what we have already. Otherwise the experience of national parks in North America might be repeated in Australia. If control is not established gradual erosion of our natural resources will take place.

speech.para: I am brought now to my basic criticism of the Bill. I do not quarrel for one moment with its long range objectives but I believe that the personnel of the Commission may have a fixation about bringing more tourists here. Representation of any department interested in preserving our tourist attractions is not proposed. Certainly Slate governments have their responsibilities, but the very creation of the Commission is an illustration of what is termed the growth of federalism. The Commonwealth Government has to assume responsibilities that would not have been visualised ten, fifteen or twenty years ago. Tourism in Canada is world renowned, In 1961-62 the Canadian Federal Department of Northern Affairs and National Resources through its subsidiary, the Canadian Travel Bureau, received record increased earnings of $53m. The functions of the Canadian Human History Branch, the National Museums of Canada, the Water Resources Branch and the National Parks Branch are all grouped under the Federal Department of Northern Affairs and National Resources. As a contrast, the personnel of the Commission to be set up under this legislation are to be officers of the Prime Minister's Department, the Australian News and Information Bureau of the Department of the Interior, and the Department of Trade and Industry. My reaction to that is: Why is not the Minister for National Development represented? Or better still: Why do we not provide for Dr Harry Frith of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation or one of his officers to sit on the Commission? There is no mention of them. If we do not wish to take that step, perhaps representation could come from the Australian Conservation Foundation. In the Foundation's brochure it says:

quote.para: Conservation means different things to different people. Some think primarily ' of preserving our native plants and animals and setting aside adequate national parks and fauna and flora reserves. Some are more concerned with landscapes and preventing stretches of our coast degenerating into rural slums.

speech.para: The Australian Conservation Foundation believes that if we do not preserve our natural tourist attractions they will gradually be eroded. But they are the attractions that we are trying to bring people here to see.

Keenthough the appointees to the Commission may be, there is not one of them who seems equipped to stress the necessity for conservation. Senator Webster referred to the responsibilities of State departments. 1 have already pointed out to the Senate what has happened at the federal level in Canada. I direct attention now to the provincial level. I have here an annual report of the Department of Northern Affairs and National Resources in the Canadian Province of Saskatchewan. It refers to park planning, communications, surveys, fur management, hunter safety, wild life, fisheries and forestry. I hope I have made clear my basic criticism of this measure by pointing out the position in Canada. In Australia, all the various authorities, whether at the Slate or Federal level, will be the poor relations of the Commission.

On a previous occasion I have referred to what appears to be a trend in Government circles. The State abattoir authorities and the Meat Industry Employees Union are not represented on the Australian Meal Board. It is said that they are consulted when something happens. Of course, when something happens the problem is presented as a fait accompli. It is a Utile too late then. The rutile operators have moved on to the foreshores of Queensland and New South Wales. A patched up agreement is reached and a little more of our natural attractions is eroded. People say: 'We have learnt over the last five years. Bonds of great value are put up by these firms so that regeneration of the areas becomes more or less an obligation.' But it is not as easy as that.

I direct the attention of honourable senators to the history of California. Private organisations there wanted to preserve the famous redwood trees. Constant battles have taken place with State and Federal authorities to preserve the forests but always someone will say: 'We want only to run a spur off the highway. We want to go through here, lt will not affect the redwood trees at all.' But before the people know where they are they find that the bulldozers have moved in with other heavy earthmoving machinery and the growth of centuries is gone in two or three weeks. Problems have arisen in the Snowy Mountains. Every tourist does not want to be driven along in a car. Some people want to employ their own physical mobility. They do not believe that the fifteen and twenty storey buildings in big cities are the end of all beauty. They want to see a lake with all its natural effects.

The question of planning is most important. Many people will be concerned at whether the Commission will be a dollar earner. Concentration can centre on dollar earning for an intensive period of four or five years and then erosion of our natural resources will occur. Where do we go from there? I can take it a little further. The National Trust of Australia has divisional officers in most capital cities in relation to many relics of our colonial days. They arc taking preservation action. Over the last few years public opinion has become conditioned to the need for preserving our history. Attention has been directed to, say, an old time court house or perhaps the home of the poet Henry Kendall, in the Robertson electorate of New South Wales. The Trust has to move in quickly. It :s all very well to say that the slogging work will bc done and then at the top level people will bring along the tourists. In the CSIRO quite valuable assistance is given to industrial firms that do pretty well in regard to serums. But when finance for the CSIRO is considered restrictions are placed on scholarships and research funds.

I would like to know whether some of our big tourist organisations will ever say: Wc have to put something back.' I wonder whether they have yet reached that stage. A lot of them have the idea that as long as they can run tourist buses it does not mailer how they leave the places they visit. Not enough attention is paid to the effects of vandalism. If some people had their way a bright neon sign would be erected at every beauty spot. In Tasmania Luke Pedder is being menaced by hydroelectric power expansion. We live in a materialistic society and there is no doubt that Australia needs hydro-electric projects. But do we have to ruin our national attractions for the sake of hydro-electric power? The answer lies in effective planning. 1 do not criticise for one moment the basic objective of this legislation which is to attract tourists, but we must impose safeguards to avoid excessive patronage of particularly good areas.

talk.start.para: - Exploitation is the word, not patronage.

- J bow to the wisdom of my Queensland colleague. But I believe that our Department of National Development should play a major role in this matter. Already the Kosciusko State Park is facing certain problems, and unless we get this close liaison between the States and the Commonwealth Government, I think that we will not be able to give all the protection that is needed there. In last Monday's 'Sydney Morning Herald' there was a report of an interview with the New South Wales Minister for Lands, Mr Lewis. I noticed that amongst other things he said that the more dollars he could get the better. That is an over-simplification of his problem. But the New South Wales Government recently opened up a new national park in the Lake Menindee area. Again, the problem is that this venture looks all right on the surface, but in a lot of that area the stocks of various marsupials will have to be built up because there has been a certain amount of intermittent grazing in the area. I think that in one part of the area a lot of goats have gone bush. It is not an area like those in Canada where there is a lot of virgin country and there are various wildlife sanctuaries. A lot of this area in New South Wales has to be rebuilt. I know that some tourist people visualise a counterpart of Kruger Park in South Africa. Of course that is a little bit of wishful thinking when we consider the ambit of present fauna areas.

speech.para: I repeat that the thing that is worrying me is that the Government is tackling this problem only from one angle, ft is nice to know that, at least, there will be a coordination of authorities. I know that the legislation provides that State Ministers will have some say in the appointment of one or two members of the Australian Tourist Commission. I imagine that if those appointees were people from the Victorian or New South Wales Chief Secretary's Departments or were people concerned with parks and wildlife, the Commission might have some status. I give the Government full marks for its development in this field in the Australian Capital Territory and also in the Northern Territory. I know that droughts and bush fires, despite all that has been done to give relief to the States, cause difficulties which raise the conservation angle.

Recently, I asked a question about a certain type of Canadian amphibious fire bombing aircraft that is used effectively to preserve forests in Canada. No one can say that we can completely curb all forms of bush fire. But we are in the jet agc. We talk about fighter bombers for our national protection. Let us be realistic when we talk about the preservation of the national resources which we will use as tourist attractions. What are we doing to protect them? When we talk about forest acreages, we all know that all the continents are in a pretty bad way in this regard and that we have to preserve all that we have. We talk about projects being financed on a $1 for $1 basis by private tourist organisations and the Commonwealth Government. Let us consider this question of the augmentation of the revenue. Some months ago I pointed out to the Government that when the Chifley post-war Government introduced a better deal for coal miners by providing long service leave benefits, it imposed a certain levy on the tonnage of coal. I respectfully suggest that a levy could be imposed on the export of kangaroo meat in order to help preserve our wildlife. lt gets back to the proposition that people who do well out of an industry by exploiting our resources should pay something back. I again say that this is a golden opportunity for the Commonwealth Government to assist, by imposing on those people who export kangaroo meat a levy of 5c per lb on every carcass that is exported. Last year $200,000 could have been raised in this way. If the Government fed this $200,000 which could be raised from the export of kangaroo meat back to the States we would find, instead of reading, as we did in the May issue of 'Walkabout', that we had only two platypus sanctuaries - and 1 am using this only as an illustration - that the States would be able to increase considerably their fauna reserves. In conclusion, I point out that 1 do not criticise the broad proposition, but I say that there is a lamentable lack of people who are wedded to the concept of conservation.

talk.start.para: - I would strongly commend the Government for the forward move it has made regarding the tourist industry in this country. When I entered this chamber after the 1949 elections, during the first debate on the Address-in-Reply to the Governor-General's Speech early in 1950, I made a speech in which I featured the point that the tourist industry should be developed on a national basis and in a much stronger way that it had been developed in the past. I remember asking the Government to contribute £500,000 per annum to the Australian National Travel Association, which was. a colossal amount in the minds of most people then. I suggested that the following year the amount should be increased to £lm per annum. I did that as one who had been associated with the industry for many years, particularly the development around the Great Barrier Reef and Mackay. Yesterday afternoon in this chamber Senator Morris paid a tribute to me for the work that I had done in this regard. I have been associated with the industry for so long that I realise the great possibility that lies within the development of the tourist industry.
- I understand that the honourable senator is Mayor of Mackay now.

- There is nothing wrong with being a first citizen in Australia. Tourism can play a very important part, so far as this nation is concerned, not just in my own State of Queensland but in the other States. As I have said before, I believe that each State has its own characteristics. As a consequence I believe that we can offer in Australia, not only quality tourist attractions but also a variety of them. This is very important indeed.

speech.para: One point about which I have been very keen in the development of the tourist industry is that tackled in the proper way it could play an important part in overcoming one of the great problems that this country has faced for years. I have said this from time to time. By bringing people from overseas to spend money here, it can help help to balance our overeas trade. We need more trade in order to acquire overseas credits. There is no quicker way in which this can be done than by the development of the tourist industry. I am sure that if we commenced a stronger advertising campaign overseas, within a month or so people would be dropping their pounds, dollars or whatever currency it might be into this country's coffers. This is one industry in which we do not sell our product - the scenery. People go away having spent their money, but we still retain the product. To me the tourist industry offers the Government wonderful scope to alleviate the shortage of overseas credits. Therefore I am particularly pleased to note that the Government is tackling this problem in a much stronger way.

I am sorry that there has not been some indication of the amount of money which will be spent. From what has been said, I feel confident that the Government is out to do a really excellent job. The amount of advertising that is necessary reminds me of falling rain. If we get a light shower of rain we do not get very good returns. But if we get a heavy fall of rain we get a good response from the earth. So it is with advertising. If we are thin with our advertising we get little response. There has to be a saturation of advertising and publicity so that ultimately people get the thought in their minds that Australia is the place in which to have a holiday. It is no use having a spread of publicity of a light nature over a large area. It has to be done on a really saturation basis. As one travels overseas or meets people from abroad one finds that very little is known about Australia in many places. I think that the Government is setting out to do the job in a way which will rectify the current position. I believe that in the not too distant future people will realise the great value of the Government's forward step.

I think that the type of publicity used is important. I have great admiration for the work that has been done by the Australian National Travel Association. I have spoken about the type of advertising which I think is essential. I know that sometimes people tend to run a clever and sophisticated type of advertising. We want a publicity campaign which will reflect what Australia truly represents. In making a study of tourist areas 1 have looked particularly at places such as Hawaii which are really the tops in the development of the tourist industry. I have found that such places do not go in for the sophisticated kind of advertising. They go in for the sort of advertising that illustrates the features that people will see and the things that people will be able to do there. I consider that we ought to advertise in a way that will really portray Australia and present the atmosphere of this country. We should show prospective tourists just what Australia is and what they will see when they get here.
Apart from earning foreign exchange for the Government, the tourist industry returns to us other benefits that percolate right through the community. As I mentioned in my speech in the Address-in-

Repiy debate at the beginning of this session, some people say that they get nothing out of the tourist industry because they never see tourists. I have heard doctors and other professional men and people in various sections of the community say this. However, the tourist business does affect them.

talk.start.para: - Doctors have never said that they get nothing out of the tourist industry.

- I did nol mean that doctors generally say this. I know that the honourable senator is deeply conscious of the value of the tourist industry. Probably I. should have referred merely to professional men. But this sort of thing is said by many. Small storekeepers have said it to mc on a number of occasions. The point is, however, that the tourist industry employs many people. When a new tourist building, whether it be a motel, a hotel or anything else, is to be constructed, bricklayers, carpenters, plumbers, electricians, painters and other tradesmen are employed. On completion of the building, it has to bc furnished and this task provides employment for people in the furnishing trades. When it is functioning, it employs waitresses, chefs and staff members, both men and women, in many other categories.

speech.para: Overseas one finds many hotels where the staff numbers anything from 300 to 700 persons. This makes one realise the terrific importance of the tourist industry. In small communities even the lesser numbers employed in smaller establishments are significant. For example, the tourist resorts on the islands of the Great Barrier Reef near Mackay, in my district, provide a significant volume of employment. Not only tourists but also people engaged in the tourist industry have to be fed and clothed. Tourists spend money when they travel. The story told is that the tourist arrives with everything arranged. This is true. Bui the coupons obtained by the tourist from the travel agent who has made the booking mean thai money has been spent and this money finds it way to the people who provide the services. This story that everything is arranged for the tourist before he sets out is just a glib form of expression adopted by people who do not realise how valuable the tourist industry is.

Honourable senators can rest assured that the tourist industry, wherever it is to be found, brings prosperity to the local community. Recently in Mackay, my own city, I met a Mr Doe, who has decided to live in the Caribbean islands, which he has visited and which he knows. He has chosen them as the ideal place for his retirement. He is a man who has been associated with tourist islands over the years. Mr Doe told me of the money invested in the construction of huge hotels in the Caribbean islands and of what this investment meant to them. He instanced the case of Barbados, which, in many ways, is similar to the Mackay district. The sugar industry was the mainstay of the economy of that island. Fluctuating prices for sugar caused the prosperity of the island to fluctuate. So the local people went into the tourist industry with strength and determination. As a consequence, instead of fluctuating prosperity they now have a high level of permanent prosperity. During the Second World War, f had discussions with a United States entertainer who was visiting American Air Force units in the Mackay area. When he knew that I was interested in the tourist industry he undertook to get me some information from the Miami area, where he lived, and other tourist resorts. On examining the brochures with which he supplied me I found that the highest level of per capita income existed not in the great industrial cities of the United States of America but in the tourist centres. Not. only were real estate values higher in the tourist areas, generally speaking, because of their prosperity, but also the tourist districts were clean and did not have dirty, grimy industries. As a result, as 1 am sure the doctors in the Senate will acknowledge, the health of the people was generally better in tourist regions.

These factors show just what the tourist industry can do for a community. It benefits penetrate throughout the entire community. They are enjoyed day in and day out throughout the year by those who do not deal directly with tourists just as much as by those who are engaged in the industry. The local residents in a tourist area thrive on the provision of services and facilities for tourists. Above all, the man on the land in the surrounding region enjoys prosperity because the demand for food and other products for tourists, as well as for the local people, ensures him of good markets. This is of special significance to producers of butter, meat, wheat, flour and similar foodstuffs. These effects, combined with the benefits of the employment provided for the work force engaged in the tourist industry amply demonstrate the value of this industry to the country. If Australia goes ahead with the promotion of its tourist business with enthusiasm, as 1 believe the Government intends, this country will be much better off. ! want to put to the Minister-in-Charge of Tourist Activities (Mr Chipp) several concrete suggestions. The time is long overdue for us to designate the tourist business as an industry. We hear talk of tourism and we hear other terms used to describe it. There is a definite need to describe it as an industry.

talk.start.para: - It could be known as the travel industry.

- I believe that that is a good suggestion. Whatever expression is used, whether it bc 'travel industry*, 'tourist industry' or any other description, it is time the tourist business was designated as an industry. This would greatly help those who are engaged in it. The obtaining of finance presents problems today. People engaged in the tourist industry on the islands of the Great Barrier Reel" and elsewhere often find the raising of finance difficult because the tourist business is not designated as an industry. My knowledge of the industry convinces me that if it were officially designated as such the banks and other lending institutions would provide finance much more readily. Unfortunately, the tourist bushes* is at present regarded by many as some sort of plaything rather than as a distinct industry. I strongly urge the Minister to take whatever action is necessary to designate the tourist business as an industry. If he does this, he will greatly help those engaged in it, because it will become easier for them lo obtain finance when they require it.

speech.para: When the proposed Australian Tourist Commission is properly established and functioning well, it might be able to provide financial assistance for certain projects in co-operation wilh private enterprise in order to get worthwhile developments on the move. 1 know that for a number of years the Queensland Government, within the limits of its restricted resources, has guaranteed bank advances for certain people engaged in the tourist industry. The New Zealand Government also has cooperated in providing advances for the development of certain tourist areas. Though I. may appear to be mentioning these matters in only a somewhat nebulous way, I firmly believe that there may be opportunities for the Government to look into this aspect of tourist development and to see whether it can help by making finance more readily available so that projects may be initiated. Many projects would return considerable contributions to the Government's exchequer because they would increase incomes and thereby increase taxes.

talk.start.para: - What kind of projects has the honourable senator in mind?

- Various projects come to mind. I shall give the honourable senator an illustration. Transport to island resorts on the Great Barrier Reef often is difficult and when the weather is bad tourists sometimes cannot land, lt might be possible for the Government to assist in the provision of better transport services to such places. The provision of good roads in various parts of Australia would open up considerable tourist possibilities. In co-operation with the States, the Commonwealth Government might consider various developments that would promote interest in tourist features.
- We could develop a few more places like Kings Cross.

- 1 do not know about that. We could develop places that would be more attractive in many ways than Kings Cross. Admittedly, it has an attraction for many people who want a certain kind of night life. There are many possibilities of development in the manner that I have suggested. 1 have not time to discuss them fully. Under the arrangements made for the debates today, while the proceedings are being broadcast, speaking times are limited. Therefore, I cannot discuss these matters in great detail. I just point out that there may be occasions when special action can be taken by the Government. Let us remember that development of the tourist industry to a higher level will bring the Government considerable returns in taxes. 1 shall have more to say about that later.

speech.para: The second matter to which I wish especially to direct the attention of the Minister-in-Charge of Tourist Activities is the location of the headquarters of the proposed Australian Tourist Commission. I am sure that Senator Ormonde will be pleased to know that 1 strongly urge that the head office of the Commission bc in Sydney. There is a particular reason why 1 propose this. I am a Queenslander, but I am looking al this matter from the point of view of the tourist industry and the best operation of it. Most of the overseas airline and shipping companies ha.ve their headquarters in Sydney. Therefore, it would be much easier for the Commission to work in close contact with those organisations if its head office were in Sydney. 1 know that the Australian National Travel Association has been sited in Melbourne.

talk.start.para: - One reason for thai is that Melbourne is central.

- In this instance the factor of centrality is overshadowed by the fact that Sydney will always be the major point of entry to Australia for overseas people. For that reason and the reasons that 1 advanced a minute ago, I strongly urge the Government to locate the head office of the Commission in Sydney.
- That is centralism.
- It is not a matter of centralism; it is a matter of having the Commission where the major operators in the tourist industry have their headquarters.

speech.para: Queensland is a very forward Stale as far as the tourist industry is concerned. The industry has been built up strongly in that State. I pay this tribute to Senator Morris: When he was the Minister for Tourism in Queensland, by his persistence and consistency in advocating it, he gave it the status of a real industry in the minds of the people of that State. I pay him that compliment because he did a very good job.

talk.start.para: - He was not the first person to get on to it.

- He was the first Minister for Tourism in Queensland. As a Queenslander, I know how forward my State is in this industry. I have participated in the industry for more than 30 years. In the early days it was unpopular to talk about the tourist industry. I can remember all the things that were said when 1 first spoke about it when I was mayor of Mackay. 1 suggest that Queensland should have some representation on the Commission. I believe that membership of the Commission should be spread so that everything will not be concentrated in the south. Mr Wentworth made a good point in the other place when he 9 id that there should be some liaison between the Commission and the Parliament by means of representatives of the Senate and the House of Representatives being connected with the Commission in some way. Whilst the Minister in charge of the Commission will have contact with it, I believe that the Parliament should have direct contact with it so that we will know what is going on and will be able lo take a keener interest in the development of this very great industry.

speech.para: Another important aspect is that the more people we bring to Australia the more we build up friendship with other people. As honourable senators know, people are less likely to row and fight with friends than with people they do not know. If we can get to know other people and they can get to know us, this is one way of building up a bond of friendship between the peoples of different nations. Australia, being a great democracy, is a place to which people can come to see democracy really at work. 1 hope that the Government will put a considerable amount of money into the promotion of this industry. In 1950 I said that the Government should provide half a million pounds straight away and a million pounds a year thereafter. That would be S2m in our new currency. I hope the Government will provide more than that. I hope that it will bc imaginative. I am sure it will be. If we give this industry a strong shower of publicity in the countries from which we can expect tourists, just as a shower of rain will bring a good response from the soil, so will that strong shower of publicity bring a good response to the people of this country, lo business and industry and to the Government in the form of taxation revenue. We must remember that an investment by the Government in this industry will be a good one because the increasing prosperity of 'the people in the industry will mean more and more taxation revenue for the Government.

So, I heartily commend the Government on this fine piece of visionary and forward thinking. This Bill is the best thing I have seen as far as the tourist industry is concerned. I am confident that when we look back on 1967 in a few years time we will say that it was the year of the great step forward in l he tourist industry of Australia.

talk.start.para: - The Opposition supports this Bill because wc believe that the tourist induslry is an important one which should be assisted by the Australian Government. We support the Bill particularly because the establishment of an Australian Tourist Commission follows in general the lines of approach of the Australian Labor Party to such matters; namely, that in any industry there should be a national planning body which is responsible to the Parliament and which directs the general purposes and activities of that industry. So we congratulate the Government on accepting one basic principle of Labor philosophy.

speech.para: The tourist industry is not a major industry in Australia at the moment, but it could be of the greatest importance to Australia. lt is important for three major reasons. The first, quite obviously, is the income, particularly by way of foreign exchange, that an adequately conducted tourist industry will bring to Australia. The more successful the tourist industry is, the more money will we receive from overseas and the greater will be the foreign exchange coming into (he hands of the Australian people.

The second reason, to which Senator Wood referred in his very able speech, is that the tourist industry assists Australia to become known to people throughout the rest of the world. At the present time there is a great ignorance of Australia. The Labor Party agrees with the Government that the more overseas tourists or visitors come to Australia the better known will Australia become to people of other countries and the better will things be for world peace and for Australia in particular.

The third reason, as Senator Wood also pointed out, is that, if the tourist industry is adequately constituted in various parts of Australia, it will be of great assistance to local areas and will help in the maintenance of those areas. Local industry may be in a difficult position in an area, and the population and general income of that area will be assisted by having the tourist industry there.

However, it should be pointed out that it is no use just leaving these matters to luck. If we are to adequately plan the tourist industry so that the requirements of the population of particular areas may be taken into account, there needs to be some overall, national economic plan under which the tourist industry is considered not in isolation but as part of a coherent economic system.

Clause 15 of the Bill provides that the Commission is established for the purpose of the encouragement of visits to Australia and 1 .ravel in Australia by people from other countries. That is the basic purpose of the Commission. Sometimes it is very easy for us to delude ourselves by saying that, because we have in Australia a great many scenic beauties and a great many attractions which are sui generis or not to be found in any other part of the world, Australia naturally will become a popular tourist resort. I believe that there are two serious handicaps under which the overseas tourist industry in Australia has to operate. The first of those is the great distance to Australia from most of the centres from which tourists are likely to come. There is no doubt that, with the much faster air services that are being planned and the possible reduction in air fares because of the increased efficiency of the overseas airlines, it will be much easier to visit Australia in the future than it has been in the past. Nonetheless, the fact remains that it is easier for a Frenchman, for example, to go as a tourist to Italy where, he will find a country much different from France, or for an Englishman to go to Norway, than it is for either of them to come to Australia. In Europe they will see countries quite different from Australia and from their own countries. So, we have this great obstacle to overcome.

The other obstacle that we have to overcome is, I think something inherent in the nature of the Australian continent. We have a wide variety of attractions. There is a great difference between the part of Australia represented by Senator Wood and the part represented by Senator O'Byrne - but in order to see the various parts of Australia the overseas tourist has to travel huge distances. A tourist in Europe, in a much smaller distance, can see a much greater variety. Whereas Australia virtually has a monolithic culture, a multiplicity of cultures and civilisations is to be found in Europe in an area similar to that of Australia. A tourist in Europe does not have to travel vast distances to see different types of scenery.

This means that two things will have to be done. I believe that these will become the responsibility of the Australian Tourist Commission. The first is that steps must be taken to see that very efficient airline services are provided to bring overseas tourists to Australia. I know :hat, whatever we do, very great difficulties will be involved in achieving what we desire, but I do believe that by way of government subsidy or in some other fashion steps should be taken to see that tourist fares from the United States of America, Europe and elsewhere to Australia are reduced to the lowest economic level. If this is not done people just will not come to Australia because of the lares that they will have to pay in addition co the time it will take them to reach Australia. For example, nobody who lives in New York and who has nes«er been to Europe is likely to come to Australia before seeing Europe. As I have said Australia has a monolithic civilisation and ils scenery and attractions are spread very widely. No person from France, for instance, is likely to come to Australia until he has visited Germany. No person from Norway is likely to come to Australia until he has visited France. These are all great difficulties that will have to be overcome. I believe that the only way in which they can be overcome is by seeing that the most efficient means of transport is provided to bring tourists to Australia. The fares should be the lowest possible.

talk.start.para: - All the <ame, a number of our people go overseas before they go interstate.

- It is true, as Senator Hannaford said, that a number of our people go overseas before they go interstate. This only adds to my argument. These people need to go oversea? in order to see some variety. They cannot find in Australia the variety that is to be found in other parts of the world.

speech.para: A popular form of travel for the overseas tourist who arrives in Australia - one finds this in Europe and, J understand, in the United States of America - is the motor car. At present road surfaces are grossly inadequate for our vast distances. We have nothing that corresponds to the autostrades in France and the autobahns in Germany. In New South Wales, for example, we find that vast tracts of country are served by so-called major highways which are like village paths. Road markings are inadequate and it is very easy lo become lost. The motorist often cannot tell whether he is on the Hume Highway or the Federal Highway. When one compares this with the sort of thing that one finds in Europe - adequate road markings with huge cross-country roads - one realises thaAustralia is very sadly lacking. These are matters that I believe will have to be corrected. A total Government plan :s required. Nonetheless, the Opposition docs welcome the establishment of the Commission. At least Australia is to have a responsible body which can engage in an overall national plan for tourism. The Opposition trusts that the Commission will exercise ils functions in a proper manner and will do something to see that the tourist industry is no longer built up on a piecemeal basis but in accordance with an overall policy, as has been done in many other countries.

SenatorMARRIOTT (Tasmania) 14.1 lj - I rise to support the Australian Tourist Commission Bill which represents yet another step forward by this Government in its approach to the development of Australia in 1967. This is the legislative fulfilment of yet another promise made by the Government at the last election and 1 am glad thai it is receiving the commendation of both sides of the Senate. Few people who take any real interest in the future of Australia would nol say that the development of the tourist industry throughout this nation is of vital importance. Therefore, one does not need to rise in the Senate and argue against a contrary view. We all feel that we have some knowledge of the tourist industry and views as to how we would like to see it developed.

The purpose that the Government has in mind in introducing this legislation is clearly and briefly stated in the second reading speech of the Minister for Supply (Senator Henty). In the opening paragraph of his speech, the Minister stated:

quote.para: The purpose of this Bill is to establish an Australian Tourist Commission for the purpose of the encouragement of visits to Australia, and travel in Australia, by people from other countries.

speech.para: This is not a Bill that affects an individual State. This is not a debate in which it is necessary for any honourable senator to extol the tourist attractions or potential of the State he or she represents. All Australians are agreed that we have a country richly blessed by nature which could be a mecca for many hundreds of thousands of tourists. The Commonwealth is embarking on its new interest in this industry at a most suitable time. The world tourist industry is affluent. The airline industry is so greatly developed that anybody who desires to come to Australia and has the money can gel here in a short time in modern international jets. From his point of arrival in this Commonwealth, the tourist can board other modern jets and first class aircraft and be taken over the many hundreds of thousands of miles of country worth seeing in Australia.
