The Bill before the Senate ties the tourist function of government to the Department of Trade and Industry. This action is worthy of note. There is no doubt that tourism is an industry. That cannot be argued, lt can be seen, therefore, that tourism can rightly be placed under the domination of the Department of Trade and Industry. Many of us were very pleased for two reasons when the new Holt-McEwen Cabinet was announced to learn that there had been appointed lo the Cabinet a Minister for the Navy who would be also, under the Minister for Trade and Industry. Minister in Charge of Tourist Activities.

talk.start.para: - Appointed to the Ministry, not to the Cabinet.

- I stand corrected on that minor point and I thank Senator Dittmer for his courtesy. 1 remind the Senate that we are not legislating for the man and we are not legislating for today; we are legislating for the development of an industry in the future and the person who will administer the legislation setting up the Australian Tourist Commission will change from time to time. Perhaps there will be varying political outlooks if an alternative government ever rises in Australia. So it is important to realise that under this legislation we are tying the development of tourism to the Department of Trade and Industry and that, in this great developing Australia, tourism will become a very important adjunct of Commonwealth responsibility.

speech.para: Through the great drive of the present Minister for Trade and Industry, the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr McEwen), Australia has trade commissioners and other officers in many parts of the world who can readily help foster the aims of the legislation. The purpose of the legislation is to bring people from outside Australia to visit us and to travel within Australia. It is readily understood that visitors will make up their own minds about where in Australia they will travel. The sovereign States will play their part by promoting facilities which will attract travellers whom wc bring to the Commonwealth. We cannot and we should not interfere with the sovereignty of the States in this respect. However, I believe that the State governments will be pleased at the step that is being taken by the Commonwealth to bring people to Australia. The legislation will enliven the interest of State governments which are tourist minded to develop further the potential of the industry. The two well known American companies which acted as consultants to the Government on tourism told us that in developing this industry we are definitely chasing a $lOOm industry. As much as $100m in foreign currency could be spent in Australia each year. So this industry is well worth chasing.

It is unfortunate that many business people and others in Australia need to be reminded of what a tremendously widespread effect the tourist industry has on our economy. Those of us who were present in the Senate during the latter stages of the debate on the Address-in-Reply and who heard Senator Wood speak in that debate heard a clear and enlightening enunciation of what great value the tourist industry is to every sector of the community and to every township, village or city which makes provision for and attracts tourists. 1 believe that Senator Wood's remarks should be widely read and widely known by business people in Australia. It is true to say that in some parts of Australia some people decry the value of tourism. This is a selfish attitude. They say that they do not want their beaches crowded with tourists and they do not want their resorts packed out with tourists who may want to spend holidays at those places. This selfish argument denies the facts which were stated by Senator Wood. Our whole economy and, naturally, the economy of each State, is strengthened greatly as the tourist industry develops.

Two other aspects of this industry make it a worthwhile subject for legislation by the national Government. Travel is. a means of fostering goodwill and international understanding, and if ever that were needed in the world it is needed now. Anything that we can do through the tourist industry to bring people to Australia so that we can understand their points of view and they can understand ours and learn that we are not altogether a country of waltzing matildas and koala bears but have a growing, powerful and rich nation is to bc commended. Another aspect or" tourism is its great value to education. As one travels about the country one is delighted to meet young people who are visiting Australia and who are learning at first hand what this country holds. Speaking on a national basis, we have been lucky in the past to have had the Australian National Travel Association. This is a free enterprise organisation, solidly supported in growing liberality by the present Government in the work that it does, lt is interesting vo note that $862,000 was made available from Federal revenue to this association for the current financial year. The Association looks to the job of enticing travellers to Australia and helps to enthuse the States to prepare their own areas for the enjoyment and education of tourists. I repeat, that this is a $lOOm industry on which we have set our sights for the next few years.

Because of the experience gained by the Australian National Travel Association, its proved ability and its dedication to the industry, it is wise and proper that the Commonwealth Government should be to a very large extent guided by the Association and by the consultants who were brought here to advise us. In the Commission to be established by the legislation two voting members will come either from the Association or from ils panel of nominees. 1 presume that they will be selected and appointed by the Minister Tor Trade and Industry, or whoever he deputises. The Commission will have three other voting members. Here I come to what may be termed a point of criticism, an expression of disappointment and wonderment at one aspect of the Bill, an aspect on which I I question the Government's wisdom. 1 refer to the fact that from my reading of the Bill and of the second reading speech it appears that no-one can say from where the other three voting members will come, except that they will come from Commonwealth Government departments. I believe that the Senate should know the type, rank and grade of the officers and the Department that will provide them. We are giving a blank cheque to the Administration to appoint three Commonwealth public servants. That is all that we are doing. On my reading of the second reading speech, the officers could come from the Prime Minister's Department, the Department of Trade and Industry or from the Department of the Interior - because the Department of the Interior administers the News and Information Bureau. The Government may have in mind the best possible men. Its judgment may bc beyond question, but I question its right not to give this Parliament in the legislation or in the second reading speech, more detailed information as to the calibre or standing of the men or women who will become members of the Australian Tourist Commission.

The Bill disappoints me in several other ways in respect of what it does not spell out for the information of this Parliament. The finance to be available to it is possibly a question that the Government considered unnecessary to answer. Perhaps at the moment it could not give us an appropriate guess as to what money will be made available but on my reading of the legislation there again the Government has an open cheque to spend as little or as much as it deems fit, if and when it takes notice of any or all of the findings or recommendations of the Commission. The Commission is lo have two non-voting members. Personally. I am against any committee or commission or executive body that includes in its makeup non-voting members, fi can get people who are dedicated and prepared to give their ideas to it, but when it comes to a decision as to whether or not their ideas will be put 110 0 operation they must remain powerless. I do not agree with the idea of having a commission with two nonvoting members but I am pleased that the two non-voting members will be nominated by the States.

I do nol want lo be accused of being super-critical but so uncertain is the wording of this legislation that I have fears. I always fear governments or organisations of any sort that do not spell out what they intend to do particularly in regard to appointments of major importance. As far as 1 can gather, the State Ministers in charge of tourism will meet and nominate two persons or a panel from which the two nonvoting members of the Commission will bc named. I hope that the situation does not arise that after the first announcement we find that an official, say from Queensland, and another from Western Australia will serve a period, and that during the next term there will be two others, and so as the years roll on the positions will be just automatically filled because so many years ago such and such a person from such and such a State served. This Commission is the kernel of a wonderful idea. I hope that the Government gives it strength and cooperation. Apart from the criticisms that I have voiced as an individual, I support the legislation.

talk.start.para: - I am glad to be in the position that I can wholeheartedly commend the Government for taking this step to appoint an Australian Tourist Commission. Any remarks that I have to make - these will be brief - will be directed towards what may be called constructive suggestions which would help to make this Commission function in the way in which we hope it will function. Honourable senators know, of course, that until this Bill came before the Senate tourist activities in Australia were in the main promoted by the various State Governments and the Australian National Travel Association, which in my opinion deserves every bit of the praise and commendation given to it by the Minister for Supply (Senator Henty) in his second reading speech. The Association, quite wisely I think, has recognised that the question of promoting tourism should now be tackled on a national basis and it has recommended this to the Government. We can record appreciation of the work that this Association has performed in the past and perhaps express a hope that the knowledge and facilities that it has compiled over the years will be readily available to the Commission and that its advice will be accepted by the Commission.

speech.para: It is rather coincidental that two specific matters referred to by both Senator Marriott and Senator Wheeldon should be the two main points on which I base my intrusion into this debate. Senator Marriott rightly touched on the rather narrow ambit of appointments to the Commission itself. I had feelings of misgiving about the rather vague way in which it is suggested the Commission should be appointed. I do not want the Minister to think that this is criticism of an unconstructive nature but perhaps the Commission could be more widely represented than is implied in the present terms of the Bill. The proposal is that it should comprise five voting members and two non-voting members, all to be appointed by the Governor-General. Senator Marriott, I think rightly, posed a question as to the qualifications of those who will be appointed to the Commission. He suggested - J think his fears are possibly well founded - that they will be public servants and that whether or not they will be qualified to carry out the duties that we feel the Commission should carry out will be left to chance. I would have preferred to see the constitution of the Commission more widely representative of tourist specialists from the various States who could give to the Commission their knowledge on matters concerned with tourism in Australia. If something like this is not done the Commission will have to start from scratch and possibly will have to seek from such people in the initial stages advice and assistance in relation to its operations. I think there is a touch of vagueness about the constitution of the Commission. I agree with the claim by Senator Marriott that the second reading speech could have been much more explicit about the duties of the commissioners and their qualifications. The Senate is entitled to some further explanation along those lines. Perhaps when the Minister replies he will find himself in a position to give us some extra information on what I consider to be an extremely valid point raised by Senator Marriott with regard to the constitution of the Commission.

Let me say that the support I give Senator Marriott on this point does not arise from a desire to engage in carping criticism. It is a point that occurred to me, just as it occurred to him. The fact that he raised it first makes it no less valid. In fact, it perhaps adds to its validity. I hope the Government will give very serious consideration to what I consider is perhaps the weakest point of the Bill. I refer, firstly, to the extremely vague terms of the explanation relating to the proposed members of the Commission and, secondly, to what J consider to be the somewhat restrictive method of appointing the commissioners in view of the great number of people experienced in this field who are available throughout Australia.

Another point that 1 want to raise is one that 1 think was very ably put by Senator Wheeldon. He suggested that the usefulness of the commission could well be limited by the fact that we have not taken action in other fields. I am referring here to the suggestion by Senator Wheeldon that some form of inducement will inevitably have to be given to people from overseas if we expect them to avail themselves of the tourist facilities in this country. The Minister has rightly pointed out in his second reading speech that in J 965-66 an amount of $65m was added to the credit of Australia's balance of payments by the tourist industry, lt is obvious, therefore, that if we can expand this industry the benefits that will flow from its operations will be of inestimable value to the future of this country. The Government has recognised, this fact by its very action in introducing this measure. I feel that the appointment of a commission of the character proposed will be only the beginning of many other things that must accompany it. Senator Wheeldon suggested one of those things. We should offer inducements of a material character to the people whom we want to bring from overseas to enjoy the various facilities of this country. In my opinion, it would not be drawing too much on the imagination if the Australian Government were to give consideration to building its own ships to bring people to this country and to offering them greatly reduced fares in order to give them the opportunity of seeing Australia without straining their purse strings too much. I know that other countries heavily subsidise their tourist attractions and I think it is inevitable that we will have to make considerable concessions in this direction also. 1 submit that the point raised by Senator Wheeldon is one that must, of necessity, merit very serious examination by the Government. What form the inducements will take, 1 do not know, but I think that the offering of inducements becomes inevitable.

Another matter that disturbs me somewhat in relation to this Bill is that certain specific guarantees are given that the Commission itself will not intrude into certain fields. 1 think that in its desire not to cut across or in any way inhibit the operation of the various State tourist branches there may be an unconscious desire on the part of the Commission to restrict its own operations. I note that the Minister said in his second reading speech that the Commission's activities primarily would be concerned with the overseas promotion of our tourist industry. I respectfully suggest to the Senate that if the Commission concerns itself almost exclusively with the question of the promotion overseas of our tourist activities it will fail in the objective that I think the Senate wants it to achieve - the setting up and expansion of the tourist industry in Australia. I believe this to be something really worth while.

I feel that we have tourist attractions in this country far off the beaten path that will equal those anywhere else in the world. We have beauty spots in remote areas of Australia that I believe the people of the various countries of the world would flock to see if we could find facilities for bringing people to them cheaply and comfortably. What we need are landing strips and aircraft to transport people to places such as Wilpena Pound and the Flinders Ranges, to which, in the main, the only means of getting people in any numbers is by motor coach and then sometimes only after an exhausting journey.

This argument applies with even greater force to some of the great tourist attractions of the Northern Territory and north Queensland where no doubt great scenic appeal exists, but the means of reaching them are just not available. I think that, instead of being restricted almost exclusively to concern with the promotion of overseas tourist business, the Commission should have the right - indeed if it is going to succeed it must have the right - to make recommendations as to what should be done in Australia if we are to induce these people to make the journey from overseas. I submit this becomes an extremely important aspect of the whole matter. I would hope that this implied restriction in the second reading speech will not be interpreted by the Commission, when it is appointed, as one which prevents it from making recommendations along the lines I have mentioned.

talk.start.para: - The honourable senator knows, of course, of the great work that all the States do in promoting internal tourism, does he not?

- Yes. 1 have already made some slight reference to this. I am not unaware of the work they are doing. I know that to some extent at least they are bridging this gap that 1 mention and to which I commend the scrutiny of the Commission, but 1 respectfully suggest that there are circumstances where the State could not possibly provide the service. I am suggesting with all respect that aircraft be used to take great numbers of visitors to places such as Ayers Rock in Central Australia, one of the great sights of the world, in comfort. Again, comfortable aircraft could transport passengers to the Flinders Ranges, one of the greatest winter playgrounds of the world. Admittedly facilities have been put forward by the governments of South Australia over the years with respect to the Flinders Ranges, but the question of providing adequate and proper landing grounds and other facilities is beyond the capacity of the State's finances. I am suggesting that in situations such as that the Commission should not find itself inhibited by an implied restriction in its terms of operation, which would prevent it from giving due consideration to that point. I mention this point only because I see in the second reading speech the specific statement that the Commission will be primarily concerned with the overseas promotion of tourist activities. I hope we can do something along these lines.

speech.para: The only other thing I want to do is to use the parish pump, perhaps rather heavily. I have noticed in debates of this kind in the Senate and in the other place that there is a tendency for members and senators to extol the virtues of their respective States. More power to their elbows. I would not take from any honourable senator the right to advertise anything that his State may have to offer.

talk.start.para: - The Gold Coast is the holiday place for the whole of Australia. Good wine needs no bush.
- We have heard Senator Benn mention the Gold Coast-
- We can tell you about the Barrier Reef too.

- I have seen both the Gold Coast and the Barrier Reef and accept the fact that they have much to offer but I say, as kindly as I can, that although in South Australia we do not have garish places like Surfers Paradise where 'the neon lights burn, as well as the sun, we have beaches just as good as, if not better than, those anywhere in the world, let alone Surfers Paradise. I regret that Senator Benn has tempted me into perhaps over-emphasising some of these things. I have mentioned the Flinders Ranges and I am sure that any honourable senator who has seen them in .he appropriate season will agree with me wholeheartedly that they provide one of the great beauty spots in this country, if not in the world.
- And the Barossa Valley.

- And the Barossa Valley, the beautiful Adelaide hills, the upper Murray areas and the historic and beautiful Wallaroo. But these are only places that we mention to bolster the attractions of our own States. Like other States, South Australia has its beauty spots. Basically this Bill is not concerned with the parish pump, lt is a piece of legislation that we can all applaud because I believe it will set in motion a national awareness of the fact that Australia has great opportunities in the tourist industry. 1 commend the Government for taking the step thai it has taken in this direction. I hope that whatever weaknesses are contained in the present Bill will be rectified in due course.

- I join in the comments which have been made by honourable senators on both sides of the House concerning this Bill. The Government, has turned its atten tion to promoting the concept of a national tourist industry. I hope that it will exploit fully all avenues for promoting our tourist attractions while at the same time being willing to accept ideas presented to it to encourage tourism, from whatever source such ideas may come. With this thought in mind I offer a few observations on the subject.

speech.para: The first thing to which we should turn our attention in considering the concept of a national tourist industry is the provision of finance for tourist facilities in areas of tourist attraction. Then, of course, there is the additional problem of making such projects an economic proposition throughout the year. Many resorts in Australia have a limited potential because of seasonal conditions. One need only mention beaches, snowfields and mountain resorts, all of which have a limited season. The establishment of the right kind of facilities for tourists in such places entails expenditure of a substantial amount of money but the business which can be done in a short season hardly enables the businessman concerned to recoup his expenses. This is an aspect which must be given some consideration. The Government must be aware of these special problems - no doubt it will become aware of them - so that in the course of its deliberations on this subject it can take some worthwhile steps to facilitate the establishment of places where a limited tourist season reduces the monetary return.

So that this legislation will not be delayed unduly I shall refer only briefly to a number of suggestions designed to promote a national tourist industry. First of all, we must be conscious of the need to keep our transport system in first-class order. I have in mind our air, sea and road systems. I think the most important thing is to provide an adequate road service to enable visitors to travel to areas of tourist attraction without the hazards associated with poor roads. Conscious of the fact that the Government has been collecting petrol tax since 1926 and that since that time about $780m has been paid into Consolidated Revenue. I believe the Government could well channel more of this revenue into our road systems through the agency of the State governments and the local government institutions so that our roads can be brought up to modern standards.

We have heard of the need to provide adequate accommodation. This is a matter which must come under the eye of the Government or of the proposed Commission because a reasonable level of accommodation for tourists is necessary. Accommodation of a high standard does exist in many places but sometimes it exceeds the expectations and the wishes of travellers. We must keep in mind that many people who visit Australia do not belong to the most affluent section of the society in which they live abroad. Many are retired public servants and people who have saved for many years with the idea of some day visiting a country like Australia. The standard of accommodation must be adequate for those people. 1 do not think they want gold knobs on doors and things like that. Provided the accommodation is of a good general standard 1 am sure that they will be satisfied.

I have mentioned the financial aspect of establishing facilities at tourist attractions. 1 know that some States provide funds for this purpose. Another point to which the Government could give some thought is the provision of adequate road signs. If people are travelling in Australia they want to know where they are going and the distance between various centres. They want a clear indication of cities, towns and the points of scenic attraction they wish to see. Also, we might look again at the Australian highway code and see how this can be co-ordinated with the codes of other countries so that the codes will be more or less uniform. Visitors then will be more at home in following the traffic regulations which exist in various parts of Australia.

The comfort of the travelling public has been mentioned - the provision of heating in the colder climates and airconditioning in the warmer areas. One thing which may not have occurred to honourable senators but which has always rather annoyed me when travelling is the obnoxious practice of tipping. Perhaps we could in the course of our considerations of this important question of tourism endeavour to promote opposition to tipping. To me it seems to be a completely wrong practice. A guest pays for his accommodation, generally in advance and he should not have to pay out all the time for tips and so on. In so many places it seems to be an established practice. We should try to get it across that we are completely against it. I am totally opposed to tipping and I believe that it does not help tourism in any way.

talk.start.para: - It is hard to eradicate now.

- I know. But I have read that in England, where it is a prevalent practice, there has been some success in stopping it. I make that passing observation. Tipping can cause quite a deal of embarrassment to people who are not well supplied with funds and find that they have to pay for something they cannot afford.
- People who do not tip generally are discriminated against by waiters.

- That does happen. If something could be done to stop tipping, I would be happy to see it. I believe that there are opportunities for the souvenir industry in Australia as part and parcel of tourism.
- The souvenirs are all made in Japan.
- I was about to comment on that point. Many of the souvenirs available to visitors to Australia - boomerangs and such things - are stamped Made in Japan' or 'Made in Hong Kong'.
- The same is true in the United States of America. The souvenirs on sale there are made in Japan.
- Does that apply to souvenirs that people take from dining room tables?

- I was not referring to that. It had not occurred to me. I believe that the general public can help tremendously by making our tourists happy. On many trips I have made - interstate and other trips - the local residents have gone out of their way to make me feel at home and have willingly given me directions to this or that tourist attraction. I believe that the general public can help a lot in this direction.

speech.para: We must be more conscious than we are at present of our wonderful natural resources in the form of forests and other scenic attractions. Senator Mulvihill said that we must be much more conscious of the perennial problem of fires. We can reduce the incidence of fires. Means used in other parts of the world to deal with fires expeditiously should be adopted in Australia. We are too slow off the mark and we are not up with the latest practices in fire fighting and control.

On the subject of historical homes, finance is always a problem in preservation. While preservation organisations in the States are doing a particularly good job in this respect with very limited finance, perhaps the Commonwealth could have a look al this matter and endeavour to assist the historical trusts to purchase and maintain buildings of great historical interest. Some areas of Australia are rich in the history of early settlement. I have particularly in mind the grave of the child of the Irish political exile. Thomas Francis Meagher, in Tasmania. He escaped from Tasmania to the United Stales of America where he became leader of the Irish contingent in the American Civil War. He later became Administrator of the State of Montana, and subsequently Governor. The grave of his only child is in the cemetery at the Catholic church at Richmond in Tasmania. It is the oldest Catholic church in Australia and it is built beside the oldest bridge in Australia. It is an area of tremendous historical interest to people from other parts of the world. The grave of the first prisoner of war who died in Australia - a Maori chief who was taken to Tasmania at the time of the Maori wars - is on Maria Island. I believe that these are places of tremendous historical interest to people who come from overseas. Such information should be used in promotional campaigns. "

A study of methods used in the tourist industry overseas would be of benefit. European countries have a very high level of tourist activity each year and I believe that we could learn quite a deal from those countries. Recently I had a discussion with the Indonesian Director of Public Health about the differences which appear to exist between our countries. He mentioned to me the great benefit to be gained by both countries as a result of greater acceleration of visits between the ordinary people of the two countries. I believe that good relations between countries which may reciprocate in tourism play a very significant part. Migrants who have settled in Australia can do a great deal to promote tourism to this country. Their home ties are still very strong with their country of origin. Correspondence flows between the countries and as time goes on it could encourage people to visit Australia. In time it may have a bearing on our immigration programme in that visitors who find that they like Australia and that it suits them may decide to stay here. 1 want to refer now to problems which can arise when our transport systems are not up to scratch. I refer, for example, to the problem of the Bass Strait ferry service which has been operating now through the Princess of Tasmania' for some years. It has been evident to many people for quite a long while that a great deal more could be done to facilitate the transport of people between Australian ports, and particularly to Tasmania, by the use of a sister ship to the 'Princess of Tasmania'. It has been estimated that potential tourist expenditure in Tasmania of $2im a year has been lost because of the lack of a sister ferry ship carrying about 200 passengers a trip to Tasmania. The need has been realised and the Government has seen the justice of the case thai has been made out for an additional ship. It has decided to build a sister ship to the 'Princess of Tasmania'. In the interim we believe that each year about $2 1/2m is lost as potential tourist expenditure in Tasmania.

Shipping is only one problem to be considered in relation to the tourist industry. I hope that what I have said - in a condensed form in the interests of getting this Bill through the Senate - will be of some benefit to those people whose responsibility it ultimately will be to ensure that the tourist industry gets under way and becomes a reality. Australia can then gain tremendous benefit not only in an economic sense but in so many other ways from a viable tourist industry.

talk.start.para: - I desire to say first that along with other honourable senators who have spoken in this debate 1 welcome this Bill. I think it is a very gratifying advance towards bringing about a situation in regard to tourism which will be greatly to Australia's advantage. Tourism today is big business. Some countries have found it most advantageous not only because of the money that is spent inside the country but also from the point of view of its effect on overseas balances.

speech.para: I think that we must pay a tribute to what has been done for tourism in this country in the last few years. There has been considerable improvement in the standard of accommodation. Powerful moves have been made by those interested in the industry to get together and to co-ordinate their efforts. But there was something lacking, and I think that this Bill is a strong step in providing that which was lacking.

I will speak only briefly. I want to refer to one particular aspect which some may regard as trivial but which I do not. 1 think we all noticed in the second reading speech of the Minister for Supply (Senator Henty) the statement that one thing we must do is to improve our facilities inside Australia. I want to refer to the fact that the city in which our Parliament is located is today becoming an important tourist centre. We only have to look into King's Hall to see how people are regarding our Parliament as one of the places which they must visit. Tourists coming to Canberra are provided with very satisfactory air and bus services, but rail services, particularly from between Melbourne, which after all is a large and populous city, and Canberra are in my opinion entirely unsatisfactory.

Last year I took occasion to refer to the unsatisfactory nature of the rail services, particularly between Canberra and Melbourne, and to point out the effect that this must have had upon tourists who desired to use such services. I wrote to the Ministers in charge of railways in New South Wales, Victoria and the Commonwealth. I asked for some action to be taken to improve rail services, particularly between Canberra and Melbourne. The result of my efforts was absolutely nil. I think it is deplorable that it is not possible for the combined efforts of the railway departments of New South Wales, Victoria and the Commonwealth, to provide a reasonable train service, particularly an overnight train service, between Melbourne and this capital of ours which is becoming such an important tourist centre. In those circumstances it did not do my blood pressure any good to read in a publication entitled 'Railways of Australia Network', which is issued by our railways departments, what appears to be a glowing tribute to rail services and the suggestion that tourists coming to Canberra would be well advised to take advantage of what are called the 'excellent' train services available between Melbourne and the national capital. If any tourists are contemplating coming to Canberra from Victoria, particularly from Melbourne, I want to give them a powerful warning against what they will have to face if they propose to come by rail.
A significant statement appears in the report of the Commonwealth Railways which was issued in February of this year. It states:

quote.para: Passenger traffic to Canberra is not commensurate with the rise in population to nearly 100,000 people and it may be necessary to look at the question of some improvement in existing train services by providing extra rolling stock.

speech.para: Of course the rail traffic is not commensurate with a city of 100,000 people, and one would not expect it to be commensurate in view of the fact that the three departments concerned - the railways departments in the Commonwealth, in New South Wales and in Victoria - have completely fallen down on the job of providing the type of service that one would expect for a city like Canberra. Instead in some respects we have a service that would be unworthy of the worst hill-billy state in America. First of all, for the tourist who decides that he will see the country by coming by rail from Melbourne, if he wants to come overnight, according to this advertising material for the service a special air conditioned carriage is attached to the Spirit of Progress. That is so, but it only runs on four nights a week. Apparently the railway departments are particularly careful not to harm the airways services because they select nights on which to run a train right into Canberra which will do least damage to the airways.

A tourist or a person having business in Canberra who wants to come from Melbourne, normally would want to come up on Monday night and be in Canberra on the Tuesday morning because Parliament meets on that day. So what do the railway departments do? They do not run a train on the Monday night when obviously most traffic would be available, although they complain that they are not getting a fair percentage of passenger traffic. Instead they run a train on the nights when they will do least harm to the airways services. Again, Parliament finishes on Thursday. What do the railway departments do? So that they will not harm the airways services, their run a train back to Melbourne on Wednesday and on Friday. They carefully miss out Thursday when there would be a demand for rail services. I want to point out this for the hopeful soul who says: T read about these magnificent rail cars coming up from Melbourne into Canberra on four nights a week'. When he goes along and tries to book he finds out that this service from Melbourne, which is a city of between two million and three million people, consists of one carriage. Even that carriage does not consist of sleepers although it is run at night, lt consists partly of sleepers and partly of sections in which people have to sit up.

Naturally, except on occasions when there is practically nothing doing, it frequently happens that the hopeful tourist who wants to book to Canberra, in order to go in comfort, says: 'I will go on the off nights if that is the only time when they run the train'. He is told that they are sorry, but the train is booked out because they cannot run a whole carriage which consists completely of sleepers between Melbourne and Canberra. They run a carriage which consists partly of sleepers and partly of a section in which people sit up. If the tourist finds that he cannot get on this particular carriage because it happens to be booked out, what happens? They put him in an air conditioned train in which he can get a sleeper as far as Goulburn. If he travels on the Monday night he has to get out at Goulburn at twenty-five past five in the morning, and believe me, Goulburn in the middle of winter at twenty-five past five in the morning is no joke. The railways take this passenger who comes from Melbourne and decant him on the platform at Goulburn at twenty-five past five in the morning and then he has to get on what they call a train'. On a previous occasion I said that from the appearance of the branch train running from Goulburn to Canberra, it was almost certainly used to transport troops in the Crimean War. After having been in an air conditioned train until half past five in the morning, this passenger is put in this branch train with no form of heating at all. It is dirty and decrepit and it has disgraceful lavatory accommodation. Then he travels in that train into the queen city of the southern hemisphere, the capital of this mighty country of Australia.

talk.start.para: - How long does it take him to come from Goulburn?

- It takes two hours to travel the sixty miles from Goulburn. A poor unfortunate tourist who decided" to travel to Canberra on the Monday night to see the Parliament in action and who was bundled out on the platform at Goulburn at 5.25 a.m. in the middle of winter would need unfreezing, if I may use that expression, by the time he reached Canberra.

speech.para: Tourists from overseas, if they wanted to see the countryside, could travel to the national capital by the daylight express from Melbourne. It is a very comfortable train. They would get to Yass about five in the afternoon. In the middle of winter, Yass is like Goulburn - extremely cold, lt is no joke to have to get out of a warm and comfortable air conditioned train al: Yass it five in the afternoon and complete the journey to Canberra in a motor bus that has no heating or air conditioning, arriving at the National Capital about 6.20 p.m. This is by no means the most convenient time to arrive anywhere. But that is the best that the tourist can do. Despite the conditions that I have described, we find in this railways publication an exhortation to tourists to try out the train services to Canberra. I have travelled from Melbourne to small Victorian towns of 7,000, 8,000 or 10,000 people situated on branch lines, and I have always been able to travel in an air conditioned carriage. One is at least warm in the middle of winter in such a carriage, lt seems appalling that in a country like Australia the National Capital is served by train services which, as I said before, would be a disgrace in the worst hill-billy State in South America.

talk.start.para: - Perhaps the honourable senator has suffered because an Australian Labor Party adherent was getting even with him.

- I do not suggest that. In all instances a Liberal Government and a Liberal Minister have been responsible. So it is not the fault of the Australian Labor Party. I conclude, more in sorrow than in anger, Mr President, by saying that it is bad enough if tough Australians are to be compelled to put up with travelling conditions of the kind that I have described. Surely we would not try to persuade tourists to try out such conditions. Therefore, I urge the Minister-in-Charge of Tourist Activities (Mr Chipp) to warn intending tourists that in no circumstances should they try out the rail services to Canberra, which are provided by the Victorian Railways Department, the New South Wales Department of Railways and the Commonwealth Railways.
- Mr President, I support the Bill. I do not wish to traverse again all the arguments expounded by speakers on both sides of House who have already stated their support of it.
- Then the honourable senator can sit down now.

- The honourable senator has already spoken of the tourist industry in his part of Australia. 1 propose to deal with the tourist industry as it exists in another part of the country, where the situation is quite different. I consider that I have a duty to speak on this measure because 1 live in one of the largest tourist centres of Australia - Surfers Paradise. It is a centre built entirely on tourism and it caters for both Australians and visitors from overseas. The word 'tourism' means a great deal to an area of fifty square miles centred on the Queensland coast at Surfers Paradise. I realise that this Bill is concerned mainly wilh the encouraging of overseas tourists to come here. But we must also consider the importance of tourism as an industry in relation to our economy. Not wishing to be parochial, 1 point out that in the last twelve months the revenue of the tourist industry in the small area of southern Queensland and northern New South Wales that is known as the Gold Coast amounted to $70m. Senator Marriott mentioned the magnitude of Australia's tourist industry and suggested that it was worth $100m a year. 1 believe that this puts it on too small a scale in view of the revenue of the industry in southern Queensland in the last twelve months.

speech.para: The ramifications of the tourist industry are immense. Many of them have been mentioned already. There has been much criticism of our amenities, travel facilities, accommodation and the like. I suggest that local government authorities take note of what has been done overseas, particularly in Germany. I believe that that is the country that originated a tax that is known there as the kur tax. In our currency it is the equivalent of 2s per bed per night. This tax is paid by every tourist in the tourist areas of the country. The object in introducing it was to avoid penalising the local citizens of the tourist regions. I understand that in Switzerland this tax rises to the rate of 2i% of the overall charge made at motels, hotels, boarding houses and the like. Local authorities in Australia should carefully consider the advantages to be gained by imposing this relatively small tax. I suggest thai its proceeds should be used only by local government authorities and that it should be devoted to the development of their own areas. Tourism, by contributing the proceeds of this tax, would do much to help us to do away with many so called run down motels, hotels and railways and other travel facilities about which we have been told in this debate. The expenditure of the proceeds of this tax, which would be contributed largely by overseas tourists, would enable us to develop and improve many aspects of our tourist industry and particulary our travel facilities.

As I have said, the ramifications of tourism are immense. Building is an important associated industry that employs many people. But there are other associated industries that have not been mentioned. One is the clothing industry. Any tourist who travels outside his own country usually returns home with purchases of clothing in the fashion of the country or countries visited. Many new clothing factories are being established in Australia and many existing ones are being enlarged rapidly. Indeed, many of our clothing factories are already exporting.

talk.start.para: - The factories may be getting bigger, but the clothing is not.

- That may be so. The clothing industry offers considerable prospects for development and I believe that an influx of overseas tourists will help to expand it. An associated matter is the decentralisation of industry. With the development of tourism, the associated industries, such as building and its ancillary industries, will be decentralised throughout the country to a degree. I believe that there are very few parts of Australia where the tourist industry could not flourish.

speech.para: Therefore, development of this industry will help various facets of other industries to spread throughout the Commonwealth.

In passing, I point out that tourism introduces many new ideas. Touching on a matter mentioned by Senator Tangney, I point out that on the Gold Coast we have introduced meter maids clad in bikinis. This development is being carried a stage further by the appointment of courtesy maids whose attire will be less brief than bikinis. These courtesy maids will be on duty at airports, railway stations and bus terminals to advise incoming tourists on the accommodation and facilities available and the attractions that may be seen in the area they are visiting.

So much for the lighter side of the matter. In my view, the most important aspect of this Bill is ils effect on our international relations. This was mentioned by Senator Wood, who, I believe, discussed it most effectively. So I will not take it any further. In addition, the Bill encourages not only migration, as mentioned by Senator Devitt, but also foreign investment. When we look about Australia we see what has been developed by overseas people as a result of their visits to this country and publications made available to them through the various tourist agencies overseas. 1 am sure that this Commission will not be hidebound by regulations, that it will be conducted by experienced people and that it will have adequate finance for its functions. This is one of the forward practical steps taken by this Government in new fields, lt shows the Government's positive thinking. 1 support the Bill, as I am sure every other Australian will.

talk.start.para: - In the few minutes available to me I wish to make a few pertinent remarks about this legislation. At the outset, let me ask the Minister for Repatriation (Senator Mckellar), who is deputising for Senator Henty, to convey my congratulations to Senator Henty who showed the Senate the courtesy of making a second reading speech that extended over nineteen pages of foolscap. This occasion was unlike some other occasions on which he has spoken previously and also unlike other occasions on which many of his ministerial colleagues have introduced legislation-

speech.para: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Sir Alister McMullin) - Order! The honourable senator is not addressing his remarks to the Bill.

talk.start.para: - I am congratulating Senator Henty on his second reading speech, Mr President. Will you be tolerant to the extent of letting me finish the sentence?
- I will listen to the honourable senator.

- Senator Henty and many of his ministerial colleagues have treated us extremely contemptuously in the submission of many other pieces of legislation. That is why I want to take this opportunity to congratulate Senator Henty on the consideration that he extended to honourable senators on this occasion. I believe that he is entitled to a full measure of praise, with all due deference lo you, Mr President. So rarely have we occasion to praise the Minister that I thought that on this occasion I should extend to him the meed of praise that he completely deserves.

speech.para: I, like everyone else, congratuate the Government on setting up an Australian Tourist Commission. The Minister told us that it will consist of seven members, five of whom will have full voting rights and two of whom will be appointed by the States and will not have voting rights. He gave us some information, for which we are grateful. From figures that have been collected. I understand that last year between $10Om and SI 50m was spent in Australia by about 145.000 overseas tourists, lt is estimated that by 1970 more than 300,000 tourists will come to Australia each year and that in 1975 the figure will be 607,000. We can visualise how much money will be spent if the estimates made by the two American firms engaged by the Australian National Travel Association - Harris, Kerr, Forster and Co. and Stanton Robbins and Co. Inc. - proved to be correct. Those two firms submitted a report which is known as the HKF report. One of them is engaged in the tourist booking business and the other in the travel arrangements business. They have made recommendations on what should happen in Australia.

One of the members of the Commission, of necessity, will be a Commonwealth public servant, an officer of the Department of Trade and Industry. Two of the other members, in the present circumstances, are to come from the Australian National Travel Association. Two other members will be appointed with full voting rights. Another two people are to be appointed by the States, but without voting rights. I should like the Minister to explain why those people will be entitled to attend meetings, to give advice, to make suggestions and otherwise to act for the betterment of the Australian tourist industry, but will not be entitled to vote. Does he distrust them because, with only two being appointed, they can come from one or, at the most, two States and may be biased in favour of the State from which they come? lt is up to the Minister to tell us why these representatives of the States will not have voting rights. A commission of seven members is not unduly large, even if every member has voting rights. I would be interested to know why these two people will be precluded from voting.

It is interesting to note that last year the Commonwealth Government provided $806,000 to the Australian National Travel Association in order to further its purposes. I understand that that contribution represents 70% of the Association's finances. In the Minister's second reading speech there is no suggestion of the amount that will be provided in the future. Being sensible people we realise that the Minister cannot specify the exact amount; but, in fairness, he could give us some idea of what is likely to be included in the Budget for the next financial year for this purpose. He has made no suggestion at all about that. He has merely said that the amount will be determined. That leaves the matter very indefinite. Will the amount be less than last year's amount? 1 think we are entitled to assume, in all reason, that it will be more. We have no idea at all how much more it will be.

Again, what will be the grade of the people constituting this Commission? What will be the salary range of the Chairman? The Minister mentioned that the chairmanship might be a part time position or a full time position. Has not the Government made up its mind on this matter? Has it brought this legislation before the Parliament half baked? Has it not any concrete ideas on what should be the function and purpose of the Commission? It would appear that the Government has brought down this legislation and given itself time to determine what it intends the Commission to do. When the Parliament passes the legislation the Government will have a free hand. The Commission could be an effective organisation; it could be an ineffective organisation.

The Government has not said what the Commission will do. The Minister talks about publicity overseas and says that the Commission will not be concerned with publicity inside Australia. 1 believe that the Minister, in introducing this legislation, should have been fairer with honourable senators and said, in simple and concrete terms, what the Government visualises in respect of the establishment of this Commission. He should have told us whether the Chairman would be full time or part time; what would be the purpose of the Commission; what would be the amount of its budget; and what would be provided for the various forms of advertising. Will this matter just go on willy nilly? After this legislation is passed, will it be twelve months or more before the Commission commences to function?

Frankly, 1 believe that the Government has been a little unlucky. Had this Commission come in'o existence twelve months ago, it could have benefited from the activities of a little lass who has gone over to America. I think her name is Sandra Hilder. She had bigger Press and television interviews than any other person to arrive in America. Whether she was dressed or relatively undressed, the people were there in droves, watching admiringly and doing whatever people do when they sec attractive figures. Unfortunately, the Commission, not being in existence, was not able to take advantage of the visit of that girl to America. Similar occasions might arise in the future.

From a tourist point of view, Australia is probably the worst placed continent. So this Commission will face a tremendous task. It is up to the Government to give every assistance to the Commission. When I say 'every assistance', I do not mean just the size of the annual budget of the Commission or the qualifications of the personnel appointed by the Government to constitute the Commission. Many other features will have to be attended to. We must realise that Australia is an isolated country. In the other great land masses there are some extraordinary features that have been accepted over the centuries as attractions to which people go almost automatically. More particularly do I refer to Europe. Each country in Europe has an attraction for the nationals of other European countries and for the people of North American countries who almost invariably visit Europe before they come to Australia. Even South Americans with money almost, unconsciously gravitate to Europe. The East has its fascination and incidentally, is not as far away from the Americas as Australia is. Better transport facilities are available to Eastern countries than are available to Australia. Australia has to compete with all these lands. What is to be the original approach of the Government to attract tourists to Australia? lt is easy to say that Australia has certain attractions to offer to tourists. Australia has 12,000 miles of coastline. But tourists could not possibly exist on most of our coastline. The average tourist would think of going to certain limited areas only of our coastline. There are long distances to travel and high fares to pay. In the past we have found that the Minister for Civil Aviation (Mr Swartz) has looked rather adversely on charter flights. But if the Government wants to bring more tourists to Australia, the Minister for Civil Aviation will need to adopt a much more tolerant view of charter flights. Cheaper fares will need to be provided. I am not talking now about publicity for what we term our attractive features. These are known to us and can be sold through the various media of advertising to overseas people. But the Government has to get these people to Australia within the limits of their purses.

The tourist's travel does not finish when he arrives here. A tourist can go to England and spend almost the whole of his holiday there. Not far away, on the Continent of Europe he can see attractions that have existed for centuries. These attractions have a fascination for everyone and have been recorded in story and history. How many such attractions has Australia? Australia has its beaches. There is Sydney Harbour of which Sydney people boast. It is one of the most magnificent and picturesque in the world, lt is an attraction and accepted as such.

talk.start.para: - Then there are Kings Cross and the Opera House.

- As Senator Ormonde said, there are Kings Cross and the Opera House. These are attractions. The Opera House might appeal to me when it is completed and we know what purpose it is to serve. As for Kings Cross, I would not be interested irrespective of how intensely interested Senator Ormonde may be. It would be, as I know everyone realises, most unlike me to boast of Queensland. But we have to face the facts. This is a simple issue. Queensland is easily the most attractive tourist State in the Commonwealth, considering its climate and its amenities and tourist attractions. But overseas tourists land at Sydney and the question of distance arises. Distance involves fares and fares involve money. Tourists, by and large have not unlimited finance for their holidays. So, the Government must face up to the problem of reducing fares as far as possible. Tourists do not necessarily require first class service. They require safety in transit. Everyone realises that. Many people seeking holidays do not look for first class transit, arrangements. As long as they have safe transit, they are satisfied. The Government must realise that almost invariably tourists on overseas planes land at Sydney. They can fill in their holiday time at Sydney but they will not be satisfied.

speech.para: Australia has a great deal to offer if facilities can be found to get people to the various attractive features. Senator Heatley dealt with the Gold Coast in some measure because of his parochial approach. The Gold Coast is quite attractive. Ite beaches are attractive and it has all the facilities that it should have. But Senator Benn, who knows Queensland better than anyone, will agree with me when I say that the Gold Coast has not been planned. Thousands of people go to the Gold Coast and it plays a big part in tourism in Australia. People go to the Gold Coast to bowl; but there are not enough bowling greens. Infants go to the Gold Coast to play, but there are not enough playing fields. The reason is that there has been a lack of planned development. The development was not unexpected but plans were not made for it. We cannot have this happening in the future in other parts of Queensland.

The Great Barrier Reef has multitudinous islands. It is unique; unparalleled in the world. It is the greatest structure built in Australia by living creatures. But again there is the problem of the fares to be paid to get to the Great Barrier Reef. So, one of the problems that the Australian Tourist Commission will have to face up to is the matter of fares. I think that it will be the Commission's biggest problem. It is no use saying that accommodation is not suitable. I know that in some towns and capital cities a sufficient number of luxury rooms may nol be available. But a sufficient number of rooms of what one might term a reasonable first class standard are available. Any person would be quite happy to settle in one of those rooms for the night. 1 have heard some honourable senators today speak of the Aboriginal culture of Australia. But let us be realistic about this. How much Aboriginal culture is there in Australia? We know of Aboriginal bark and rock paintings. We know of Aboriginal corroborees.

talk.start.para: - Aboriginal water colours.

- Yes, we know of Aboriginal water colours. I thank the honourable senator for the suggestion but Aboriginal painting is limited to a comparatively small area of Australia. This culture is largely due to an Australian painter who fostered the talent among the Aboriginals. Perhaps this is justification for other painters to take an interest in this field. But how many tourists have the money or the time to visit the areas where Aboriginal art is displayed? We are just kidding ourselves in some small measure if we do not face up to the basic question of providing transport at reasonable costs.

speech.para: Mr President,the Minister is to be commended for what he did include in his second reading speech. But he is to be condemned for what he did not include in his speech. He did not give us any idea of what is to be provided in the next financial year to assist the Commission in the work that he outlined so extensively. The Minister did say that some of the work of the Com mission would be outside Australia. He spoke of advertising in overseas newspapers. I take it that he thought in terms of movies and television. These media are terrifically expensive overseas. We in Australia have no idea of the expense. We think that Australian television is expensive. But it is incomparably cheaper than television overseas. Consequently, the Commission will need a really large budget to be able to function in the way that the Minister outlined to us. However, it is a shame that he has not given us any idea of how much is likely to be provided. He has not even told us of the calibre of the personnel who will be appointed to the Commission. He has said that they will come from departments, but I remind him that there are many grades of officer in various departments.

Further, could not the Minister have told us whether the Chairman will be appointed as a full-time or part-time officer? It is no use leaving this up in the air. If the Chairman's activities are to be associated with an undertaking which will bring in a real profit he should be appointed as a full-time officer. It has been estimated that by 1975 the annual return from tourism will be in excess of $200m in overseas currency. Surely the Government does not intend to be parsimonious in its approach to the budget of the Commission. Surely the Minister can tell us of the calibre or standard of the men who will compose the Commission. Is the Government trying to buy something on the cheap? In this legislation is il merely paying a token tribute to tourism, or is it a recognition that we in Australia, placed as we are in a difficult location, intend to accept a real responsibility to bring people here. I ask the Minister to tell us in his reply so that we will know that a real endeavour is to be made to further the tourist industry in Australia. Within Australia people engaged in the industry are doing a tremendous job. The Australian National Travel Association, which has existed since 1929, struggled on for many years, but in comparatively recent years it has had a not unsubstantial budget for internal tourism. But only a small amount has been spent externally. The Government has now accepted the responsibility externally for tourism. Let it give us the evidence that it intends to do so.

talk.start.para: - in reply - I am afraid that 1 am a little handicapped because 1 have not been following the debate. However, I shall endeavour to reply to points which have been raised by honourable senators. Senator Willesee asked about the amount of money likely to be spent on the Australian Tourist Commission. The Government is unable to forecast what amount of money will be spent. In reply to Senator Keeffe, no decision has been taken so far on what the establishment, of (he Commission will cost the Australian taxpayer, so 1 cannot answer his question. 1 think the second reading speech of the Bill made it plain that the Government accepts the need to equip the Commission with greater finance than the Australian National Travel Association has had in the past. As has been mentioned already, the Government's grants for 1966-67 for this purpose have totalled $862,000. But it is not possible in advance of the usual Budget considerations to say what precise amount may be allocated in the next year. This is common to most other matters on which the Budget has a bearing.

speech.para: Senator Dittmerraised a point about the grade of the personnel to be appointed to the Commission. The honourable senator stated correctly that there are to be seven members of the Commission, five of whom will be voting members and two of whom will be non-voting members. The five voting members will include two members nominated by the Australian National Travel Association, one from the Department of Trade and Industry - a public servant - and two from other sources. The Chairman will be appointed from the voting members. This will give the Government an opportunity to balance the Commission. All members will be selected on ability and personal qualities.

talk.start.para: - I was referring to the grade or salary.

- I am unable to answer that question, but if the honourable senator so desires I shall see that a reply is forwarded to him, if the information is available. Members of the Commission may include more than one public servant. The nomination of non-voting members is entirely a matter for the States. 1 thank the Senate for the interest it has taken in the measure and the speedy passage that has been given to the Bill.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

Clauses 1 to 3 - by leave - taken together and agreed to.
Clause 4 (Definitions).

talk.start.para: - I recognise that the Minister for Repatriation (Senator McKellar) who closed the second reading debate is not the Minister who introduced the measure. I apologise to him for having to ask a few questions on some of these matters. But because I have not a clear understanding of them I feel that they should be raised. In clause 4 I notice that there is a definition of member', 'voting member', 'the Chairman', the Commission' and 'the General Manager'. However, there is no reference to the Minister. In my remarks on the second reading debate I raised this question and emphasised that I believe that on a task like this where we were setting up a new Commission which would have a vast job to do it was undesirable that there should be any intervention by a Minister between the Minister-in-Charge of Tourist Activities and the Ministry.

speech.para: Honourable senators are aware that although the Bill was introduced by the Minister-in-Charge of Tourist Activities (Mr Chipp), it will come under the administration of the Minister for Trade and Industry. There seems to me to be quite a conflict in this. That conflict increases because if the Minister for Trade and Industry is out of the country his ministerial responsibility moves to the Minister for Social Services. So he would be the man who, in the absence of the Minister for Trade and Industry, would be responsible for the action taken by the Minister-in-Charge of Tourist Activities. I was so interested in this question that 1 made some inquiries. I was referred to the Acts Interpretation Act which in section 17 (i) stales:

quote.para: The Minister* shall mean the Minister for the lime being administering the Act or enactment in which or in respect of which the expression is used:

speech.para: Then I come to section 19 which states:

quote.para: Where in an Act any Minister is referred to, such reference shall unless the contrary intention appears be deemed to include any Minister or member of the Executive Council for the time being acting for or on behalf of such Minister.

speech.para: This is again dealt with in sections 19a., 19b. and 19c. But from none of those provisions do I get a very clear picture of what is meant by the Minister who will be responsible. I come back to the front page of the Bill where it is clearly shown that this matter is to be administered by the Minister-in-Charge of Tourist Activities. I should like to know definitely whether the Minister-in-Charge of Tourist Activities will be directly responsible to Cabinet or will have to act through the Minister for Trade and Industry.

talk.start.para: - I think 1 can set the honourable senator's mind at rest by pointing out to him that there is no Minister for tourism. There is a Minister who assists the Minister for Trade and Industry (Mr Mc.Ewen) in matters of tourism, which form part of the portfolio of the Minister for Trade and Industry. Therefore, as I understand it, if we did have a separate Minister for tourism this would be a comparatively simple matter. The Minister assisting the Minister for Trade and Industry in this respect is the Minister for the Navy (Mr Chipp). He is the Minister who would sign on behalf of the Minister for Trade and Industry.

speech.para: Clause agreed to.
Clause 5 agreed to.
Clause 6 - Constitution of the Commission.

talk.start.para: - I am afraid that I must again go back to a matter to which I referred in the second reading debate and to some of the things that were said by the Minister for Supply (Senator Henty) in his second reading speech. We are told who the three voting members are to be but we are not told anything about the other two. I predicated the thought that undoubtedly one of the three voting members would come from the Public Service. I suggested that two could come, with advantage, from the Australian National Travel Association. I even went to the stage of suggesting the name of the person who I felt could with advantage be Chairman. But I am still not happy when I look at this clause. The Minister said:

quote.para: It is also provided that at least one of the remaining three voting members of the Commission shall be an officer of the Public Service of the Commonwealth.

speech.para: As I said, I am satisfied with that. He went on:

quote.para: Officers of the Prime Minister's Department, the Australian News and Information Bureau of the Department of the Interior, and the Department of Trade and Industry have been members of the honorary board of the Australian National Travel Association in the past.

speech.para: I direct attention to the way in which the words are used and the way in which one thought follows another. The next thought is expressed in these words:

quote.para: It is proposed that an officer of the Department of Trade and Industry be appointed to the Commission.

speech.para: It could almost be gathered that the other members not specified would be members of the Public Service. I do not think that that would be advantageous from the point of view of the work of the Commission. lt would be, I think, too circumscribed. I do not say this in any criticism of members of the Public Service. I would not do that for one moment. I think that with members of the Public Service only, or with members of the Public Service in the overwhelming majority, the Commission would not have sufficient width of vision on this matter to satisfy adequately its requirements. The Minister also stated:

quote.para: The remaining members of the Commission, both voting and non-voting, will be appointed on a pari time basis, any officers of the Commonwealth Public Service being appointed ex officio.

speech.para: That opens up two questions.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

talk.start.para: - It is unfortunate for me that the suspension of the sitting interrupted the argument I was developing with regard to clause 6. It is also unfortunate for me that urgent Cabinet matters kept the Minister away from the chamber during the discussion of that clause. I do not say this in denigration of his colleague who stepped into the breach very ably. But I must develop this point because I think it is a most important one.

speech.para: Both sides of the Committee have accepted this Bill very generously notwithstanding the fact that it is couched in vague generalisations rather than specific statements. During the second reading debate, 1. accepted this wholeheartedly, but I did express some reservations about the Commission itself which I felt might have been answered by the Minister when he replied to the second reading debate today. Because he did not answer them, my reservations have been somewhat accentuated.

There is to be a Commission of seven, five of whom are to be voting members and two non-voting members. The Minister told us that one of those five voting members would be a member of the Public Service. He said that two others would be drawn from outside. I assumed - I hope correctly - that they would be drawn from the Australian National Travel Association. That leaves a certainty of one Public Servant. In another part of his speech, the Minister referred specifically to three departments which had been active in connection with ANTA. They were the Prime Minister's Department, the News and Information Bureau of the Department of the Interior and the Department of Trade and Industry. There is nothing in this Bill to prevent the Government from appointing two more members of the Public Service to this Commission as voting members. That would mean that there would be three members of the Public Service who could be voting members, and two voting members from the whole of the industry outside. If that is to be the case, 1 will be extremely dissatisfied with this Bill.

I feel that the whole purpose of the Bill will be lost if the Commission is going to be dominated by senior officers of the Public Service who, although they may be extremely capable in their fields, do not know the tourist industry. Unless there is an adequate opportunity for the industry to express itself on this Commission I would be most hesitant to give it the enormous powers that it is being given. I would suggest that if there is some doubt about this, and if we are faced with the possibility of three of the five voting members being public servants, I have some reservations about the wisdom of the two members who are designated non-voting members retaining that qualification.

My doubts would be resolved if two things happened: firstly, if I could be sure that the Commission would not be dominated by members of the public service from these or any other departments and that at least three members will come from outside the Service, I would be satisfied. Another way to resolve my doubts would be to make the two non-voting members voting members, so that the Commission still would not be dominated by public servants. This is clear cut. I repeat that the Committee has received this Bill much more tolerantly than it normally receives bills that are presented somewhat vaguely. I think there is reason for the vagueness. I think it is because this is a new organisation. 1 have said that I accepted that but I accepted it believing that the Commission would not be dominated by officers of the Commonwealth Public Service. Having said that during the second reading debate, 1 say it again. In another part of his second reading speech, the Minister said:

quote.para: The remaining members of the Commission, both voting and non-voting will be appointed on a part-time basis, any officers of the Commonwealth Public Service being appointed ex officio.

speech.para: Let us suppose it is dominated by officers of the Public Service. What does this phrase ex officio' mean? I looked it up in the Oxford English Dictionary. The meaning given was: 'In discharge of one's duties, in virtue of one's office'. That is quit; all right. The meaning given by Webster's Third International New Dictionary is: 'By virtue or because of an office or offices'. That, too, is all right. Then I referred to the Guide for Meetings of Organisations' issued by the Sydney Law Book Company of Australasia and written by N. E. Renton, in 1961. I noticed that in addition to the words that had been used in the Oxford Dictionary and Webster's Dictionary, these words are used:

quote.para: Names of ex officio members must never be included on ballot papers or in lists of nominated candidates for any election.

speech.para: I accept this because it comes from a very high authority. Let us assume, then, that these other members are going to be from the Public Service. What a mess we shall be in. I say that because, if this: authority is correct - and 1 believe it is - then three of the members will not be permitted to be nominated as deputy chairman. That means that the appointment of deputy chairman would become automatic.

I am not trying to make trouble on this Bill because I am very keen to see it introduced but, having seen a good deal of the tourist industry throughout Australia, particularly in Queensland, I say again that I would be extremely unhappy to see the activities of the Australian National Travel Association dissolved into thin air and the work it has been doing carried on by a Commission with five voting members, the majority of whom are officers of the Public Service. I feel very strongly about this and repeat that I am not the only one who feels very strongly about it. 1 have nol only read the debates in another place but I have also listened to the debates in this chamber and 1 note that many members and senators have felt the same way as I have about this.

talk.start.para: - Why not move an amendment to put it beyond doubt?

- 1 do not want to move an amendment because I think that would be undesirable. I will be happy if the Minister can tell me that the thinking of the Minister-in-Charge of Tourist Activities is not that the Commission will be dominated by public servants. That will completely satisfy me.

speech.para: Senator WOOD(Queensland) [8.9) - I think that the point that Senator Morris has brought forward needs to be considered. Might t say that the question of selection of members of this Commission needs the most careful consideration and attention? Whilst I have nothing against public servants, I think that a very broad approach will have to be made lo this question of who shall be the members of the Commission when it is formed. Having been associated with the travel industry for over thirty years, and having initiated parts of the Great Barrier Reef industry, I have a clear working knowledge of the industry. Very often one finds people who are enthusiasts so far as the tourist industry <s concerned, but when it gets down to tin tacks they just do not know how to go about getting business for the industry. I think the Commission should be comprised of people who have some knowledge of the possibilities inherent in advertising and publicity. It needs people who know what methods to employ to encourage visitors to come to Australia by means of organised tours, package tours and so on.
