As Senator Morris would also know, the Commission needs members who can work amicably amongst themselves and in co-ordination with State tourist bureaux and the various travel agents who sponsor and organise package tours.

Senator Morris'remarks are worth considering. Possibly the Minister has in mind that the majority of members of the Commission will not be public servants but will be people from a wider sphere of activity. However I suggest the Minister should consider the appointment of people who are actively engaged in the industry, who know the industry and who know how to go about encouraging tourists. Such people would bc a valuable addition to the Commission. I commend those thoughts to the Committee.

talk.start.para: - I have listened with great interest to the points raised by Senator Morris and Senator Wood. I refer them to the following extract from my second reading speech which appears on page 1161 of Hansard:

quote.para: This recognition will give the Australian National Travel Association the right to nominate a panel of persons from whom two of the voting members of the Commission shall be appointed.

speech.para: So there will be two members who are approved by ANTA. The speech continued:

quote.para: These men will be appointed for their knowledge and understanding of Australia's task in stimulating a greatly increased number of overseas visitors to Australia. They will be selected for their personal abilities and the energies which they will be able to bring to this task as members of the Commission.

speech.para: If two men of capacity are to be chosen from a panel nominated by the Australian National Travel Association. I should not think that it could be suggested for one moment that the Commission would be dominated by public servants. In fact I think the opposite will be the case.

talk.start.para: - If the Minister gives me that assurance I am satisfied.

- Yes. I also said in my second reading speech: lt is also provided that at least one of the remaining three voting members of the Commission shall be an officer of the Public Service of the Commonwealth.

speech.para: That is the point raised by the honourable senator -

quote.para: Officers of the Prime Minister's Department, the Australian News and Information Bureau of tHe
Department of the Interior, and the Department of Trade and Industry have been members of the honorary board of the Australian National Travel Association in the past.

speech.para: The honourable senator can rest easy tonight without worrying that the Commission will be dominated by the Public Service.

talk.start.para: - I thank the Minister for his comments. I repeat what I said earlier: had the Minister been in the chamber to close the second reading debate he would have answered my question then and I would not have felt somewhat hot under the collar for the past hour or two worrying about this aspect. I thank him for his assurance. I am satisfied.

speech.para: Senator CAVANAGH(South Australia) I8.14J - I am concerned whether Senator Morris understands what the Minister has said. As far as I can understand, what the Minister has said now merely confirms the earlier fears that the Commission could be dominated by the Public Service. Clause 6 of the Bill in these terms:

item.para: - (I.) The Commission shall consist of five voting members and two non-voting members. (2.) Each member shall be appointed by the Governor-General. (3.) Two of the voting members shall be persons appointed from among persons nominated, in accordance with sub-section (6.) of this section by a body or association that is approved by the Minister as being representative of the industries in Australia connected with tourism.

speech.para: The Minister indicated in the extract he read from the second reading speech how these two voting members would be appointed. Senator Morris knew that when he commenced to speak a few minutes ago and he was happy about it. Now he wants to know where the other three will come from. The Bill provides that one shall be appointed from the Public Service but the Minister has not told us where the other two will come from. That is the point raised by Senator Morris.

talk.start.para: - The Minister gave me an assurance that the Commission will not be dominated by members of the Public Service.
- If the Minister said that and the honourable senator is satisfied, that is all right with me.

- Let me return to the constitution of the Commission. This afternoon I mentioned the possibility of a member of the House of Representatives and a senator being appointed to the Commission. I know there may be some differences of opinion on this but I believe that liaison between the Parliament and the Commission would be a very good thing. The members of Parliament need not be voting members of the Commission but I think it would be all to the good if the Parliament was so represented on the Commission.
- Two non-voting members will come from the State Parliaments.

- I think there could be some from the Federal Parliament, whether they be voting members or nonvoting members. Such representatives of the Parliament would be conversant with what was going on in the Commission and would be able to keep the Parliament advised as to developments in the tourist industry. 1 submit those suggestions to the Minister to learn the Government's view.

- I have what purports to be a copy of the report submitted by the American investigators Harris, Kerr, Forster and Co. and Stanton Robbins and Co. Inc. who were asked by the Australian National Travel Association to report on the industry. Does this Bill arise out of that report? Why was not the document made public? It was put directly into the hands of the Australian National Travel Association.
- It was available to be purchased by the community.
-(Senator Drake-Brockman).-Order! Is the honourable senator linking this up with the composition of the Commission?
- Yes.
- I will be glad when he does.

- Thank you, Mr Chairman. Has the Government, in drawing up this Bill, taken cognisance of the advice contained in the report? For example, has it taken into account the statement that there is a shortage of 6,000 hotel or motel rooms in Australia for the contemplated influx of tourists? Another point I notice is that a great deal of the report relates to real estate values and that it suggests the establishment-
- Order! I cannot see where the honourable senator is linking this up with the composition of the Commission.
- This is a report on tourism in Australia which was asked for by the Association and I assume the Government-
- The Committee has agreed to take the Bill clause by clause. Later when we deal with the remainder of the Bill the honourable senator can raise the matter he is trying to place before the Committee.

-I shall reply to the matters which have been raised so far. The report to which Senator Ormonde referred was submitted to the Australian National Travel Association, the organisation which sought it. The report was not a matter for the Government but we did accept advice from the Association and I do not think there are better advisers in this field than members of the Association. Proof of the success of the Association's activities is evident. It has conducted a very successful operation.

speech.para: I do not react to Senator Wood's suggestion that members of Parliament should be on the Commission. I am not sure whether he meant that there should be a member from each House.

talk.start.para: - Yes, one from each House.

- If it were decided that a Tasmanian parliamentarian should serve on the Commission, that might suit me but it would not suit Victorians and Queenslanders and so on. This is a States House. If the honour of serving on the Commission were to be shared among the States there would be difficulties because each senator is appointed to the Senate for a term of six years and there would be many changes in the representation on the Commission. Personally, the scheme does not appeal to me. Members of Parliament have a job to do and I do not think that serving on the Commission is in their field of operations. 1 have noticed that the Minister in Charge of Tourist Activities (Mr Chipp) agrees with me. As Senator Wood asked for my point of view I am happy to give it to him.
-I think there is a real objection to Senator Wood's suggestion.I draw the attention of the Committee to section 45 of the Constitution, which states:

quote.para: If a senator or member of the House of Representatives - (i.) . . . (ii.) . . . (iii.) Directly or indirectly takes or agrees to take any fee or honorarium for services rendered to the Commonwealth, or for services rendered in the Parliament to any person or State: his place shall thereupon become vacant.

speech.para: As it is contemplated that the members of the Commission are to be paid,I think it would be quite wrong for a parliamentarian to become a member of the Commission and take pay for it. If he did so, he would lose his seat in the Parliament. I also think it would be quite wrong for anyone to occupy a place on the Commission and not to take pay for it.

talk.start.para: - In view of the situation described by Senator Laught, let me say that for some years 1 served on the Immigration Advisory Council, and whilst other members of the Council were paid for their services, as a senator I was not paid for my services on the Council. I want to make it clear that in this instance I am not concerned with the matter of payment. I am concerned with the question of whether a parliamentarian should have liaison with the Commission and should have an opportunity to use his knowledge to help the Commission in its dealings with the tourist industry. I repeat that as a senator serving on the Immigration Advisory Council I did not get paid for my services on the Council.

speech.para: Clause agreed to.
Remainder of Bill - by leave - taken as a whole.

talk.start.para: - I wish to ask a question about clause 16 which relates to the purpose and powers of the Commission. Sub-clause (e) states in part: . . where the Commission is satisfied that no person whose principal place of business is in Australia undertakes, in that country outside Australia, the provision of assistance of the same kind; 1 know of quite a number of proprietors at tourist resorts who have incurred a great deal of expense in distributing advertising material outside Australia, and specifically in America. In Queensland we issued a travel manual for distribution throughout America dealing with many of the tourist areas in Australia - not only in Queensland but throughout Australia. The manual was for use by travel agents as a means of selling Australia. These private proprietors at tourist resorts have their principal place of business in Australia and they are undertaking outside Australia - in America - the provision of assistance to travel agents. Are they to be debarred because of this clause from continuing this work? I assume that they will not be debarred, but because the clause is somewhat ambiguous I have raised the matter hoping that 1 will receive a favourable answer from the Minister.

speech.para: Senator CAVANAGH(South Australia) 1 8. 24] - I wish to refer to clause 12, subclause (4.). We have dealt with the composition of the Commission. Sub-clause (4.) states:

quote.para: A voting member who is directly or indirectly interested in a contract made or proposed to be made by the Commission, otherwise than as a member, and in common with the other members, of an incorporated company consisting of not less than twenty-five persons, shall, as soon as possible after the relevant facts have come to his knowledge, disclose the nature of his interest at s meeting of the Commission.

speech.para: Sub-clause (5.) states:

quote.para: A disclosure under the last preceding sub-section shall be recorded in the minutes of the Commission and the member -

item.label: (a)
item.para: shall not take part after the disclosure in any deliberation or decision of the Commission with respect to that contract; and

item.label: (b)
item.para: shall bc disregarded for the purpose of constituting a quorum of the Commission for any such deliberation or decision.

speech.para: The Commission is to be set up to represent the tourist industry. It could well be that managers of companies engaged in the tourist industry will be considered for appointment to the Commission. If the manager of a company consisting of not less than twenty-five persons is appointed to the Commission and signs a contract for the Commission from which his company may gain pecuniary benefit, he should do certain things. He will still be a member of the Commission which must decide whether his company may participate in a contract from which it expects pecuniary benefit. It seems to me that all the manager needs to do is to make a disclosure of his position and then refrain from voting or from being counted as a member of a quorum. This position seems to be quite contrary to our system of appointments to committees which deal with certain industries or certain events.

People wilh a particular interest or with a possibility of financial gain from contracts entered into by the Commission should not be members of the Commission. 1. do not think it is sufficient for such a member simply to refrain from voting. He may be the manager of a big company. One can imagine a representative of the Ansett organisation serving on the Commission and influencing decisions in respect of the spending of money which may from time to time benefit his own organisation. I think this point needs consideration and I am anxious to hear the Minister's explanation.

talk.start.para: - I would like to pursue the point raised by Senator Morris and to take it a little further. Clause 16 states that the Commission has power to do certain things. Subclause (2.) states, in part:

item.label: (e)
item.para: to undertake, in a country outside Austra ia, the provision, with or without charge, of assistance to travel agents, transport operators and other appropriate bodies or persons in arranging travel, accommodation or other services or facilities for people visiting Australia, where the Commission is satisfied that no person whose principal place of business is in Australia undertakes, in that country outside Australia, the provision of assistance of the same kind;

speech.para: I hope that this provision docs not cut across the development of enterprising organisations which set up their agencies in countries outside Australia to induce travel to this country. Will this provision affect the offices that may be established within their complex enterprises which may be engaged in inviting tourists to Australia? Will the Minister tell me at what point the Commission will be, in the words of the Bill, satisfied that a person is providing the kind of services which effectively assist travellers? Is provision made in the Bill for these agencies to lodge an appeal or application if they feel that their services are effective and should not be usurped by the Commission? Will the Minister to whom the Commission is responsible have any flexibility in this matter? Will he have any discretionary powers?

talk.start.para: - Senator Morris and, I think, Senator Davidson raised a point concerning the Commission operating outside Australia. The Bill makes it quite plain that the Commission cannot operate outside Australia if Australian private enterprise is operating a tourist activity in the same area.
- The Bill uses the words in that country'. That is what troubles me. If it stated 'in that area' I would not mind.

- If the Commission were satisfied that a service was being given somewhere in a certain country it would not be precluded from entering an area of that country in which service was not being given. I take it that it would be for the Commission to decide whether to do that or not.
- What would be the situation in reverse? Could a private enterprise agency apply to go into an area which was already being served by the Commission?

- Yes. If private enterprise wished to go into an area and if it could provide a service, it could go into the area and the Commission would have to withdraw from it. Senator Cavanagh raised a point concerning clause 12(4). These are standard provisions in relation to statutory corporations. As a matter of fact, they stem from the Constitution itself. I refer to Part IV of the Constitution relating to both Houses of Parliament. Section 44 (v) refers to any person who:

quote.para: Has any direct or indirect pecuniary interest in any agreement with the Public Service of the Commonwealth otherwise than as a member and in common wilh the other members of an incorporated company consisting of more than twentyfive persons.

speech.para: The position is that anyone who is a member of a corporation consisting of fewer than twenty-five persons is not allowed to operate in this field. But if he is a member of a corporation consisting of more than twentyfive members, then he is performing only a minor part in that company. If this principle were carried to the fullest extent, it would affect a person who was a minor shareholder in a large retail store which could benefit from the tourist industry. The provision in clause 12 (4.) is the normal provision in relation to this type of Commission. I think it covers the position quite well.

talk.start.para: - Earlier I was referring to the American firm of Harris, Kerr, Forster and Co. Apparently it advised the Government that it should not compete with private enterprise, particularly in relation to advertising, as the Government might be doing in the United States of America. That is where it has to advertise Australian tourism. lt also has to advertise it in other countries. I cannot understand why the Minister took care to point out that the Government does not propose to compete with private enterprise in this field in the countries of origin of the tourists. Obviously this recommendation has been made to the. Government through the Australian National Travel Association. The Government is accepting that part of the advice which is contained in the Association's report, at any rate. If tourism is the big industry which it is claimed it is - and I suggest that it is one of the biggest industries in this country - then I think that the Government or the tourist organisation has a right to advertise. It is of great importance that the Government should advertise through Government agencies in America concerning tourism in the same way as it does for other industries. The Government advertises our butter in England. It does not worry about competing with private enterprise there, lt advertises other goods that it sells in the United States of America and it does not worry about competing with private enterprise there.

speech.para: I agree with what Senator Morris said. He expressed a doubt as to whether the Government is appointing the right type of people to this Commission. I know that the Minister cleared this point up for him. But Senator Morris had in mind the appointment to the Commission of public relations advertising people who understand how to push a trade. Senator Morris feared that public servants do not have that sort of experience. I would assume that this is what he was suggesting, lt might give Senator Morris a little comfort to know that the Government has an advertising setup in its own departments. It has highly skilled men. Tourism is important to this country and it has to be sold in America, England, Ireland, Europe and in other countries, not in Australia. We have to spend money on publicity overseas. Qantas Empire Airways Ltd already spends a lot of money on advertising overseas. The British Overseas Airways Corporation also spends money. These companies are advertising overseas for us. They are engaged in the trade of bringing people lo Australia. The shipping companies are in the same category.

I believe that the Government should at least try to co-ordinate those activities. I believe that it should try to ascertain how much money is being spent by some of these extra-governmental organisations such as Qantas. Trans-Australia Airlines also could be involved. The Government should sec what these companies are spending overseas in order to bring tourists to Australia. They are competing with private enterprise overseas. They must be. These companies take tourists from Australia and they advertise in order to get people to come to Australia because otherwise they would be returning without passengers. I believe that the Government ought to have a publicity agency of its own, particularly at San Francisco on the west coast of America where people arc interested in coming to Australia. That is all I have to say on the publicity side of this proposal.

I clare say that the Commission will carry out this task, but I ask the Minister whether the Commission will do anything about examining matters which cause annoyance to tourists coming to Australia. I recently relumed by ship from the United States. When the ship was six or seven hours outside Sydney Heads the bar and all the other shops were closed and they remained closed while the ship was in Sydney, lt meant that these people were virtually prisoners, so far as shopping was concerned. They were not very happy tourists. That is one complaint which I thought was common amongst American people in particular. Senator Wood referred to koalas and I think that Senator Mulvilhill referred to kangaroos and platypuses. People are interested in seeing the real outback life. They want to see sheep stations, for example.

talk.start.para: - And the dude ranch at Kings Cross.

- No, they are not interested in that. They want to see the working of a real sheep station on the far side of the mountains from the coast. A visit to a sheep station could easily bs arranged for American tourists when they come to this country. I suppose that at all seasons of the year it would be possible lo arrange for overseas visitors, as a special tourist feature, to see a shearing shed in operation. Visiting Americans do not want to be taken to a place conducted like a dude ranch where they will see only dummies and nol the real thing. They do not want that sort of synthetic situation. They want to see the working of an authentic sheep station.
- The National Sheep Dog Trials are conducted in Canberra.

- Yes. Something like that would be the real thing. American visitors to this country are not interested just in going to Kings Cross. Sailors may be interested in going there, but tourists are not. If the Government's publicity experts could work out schemes designed to make it possible for overseas visitors to see the work on sheep stations and to see other features of the outback, overseas tourists would be greatly interested. Americans particularly talk about the Australian outback. However, they would not really have to go far to see something of country life. Sheep are shorn within 100 miles of Sydney and within that distance of Sydney overseas visitors could be taken to typical sheep stations where they could see sheep dogs working and witness all the other typical activities. That is the sort of thing that Americans talk about seeing when they are on board ship travelling to Australia.

speech.para: Another point that I want lo make is that there is too much concentration on air travel and too little thought given to shipping as it applies to the tourist trade. After all, the bulk of the Americans who go on tour are the not so wealthy ones. The principal object of many in leaving the United Stales of America is to escape high taxes. Travel is one way of getting rid of their surplus funds so that they will not be affected by a means test. Most of these travelling

Americans are superannuated workers who measure out their spending very closely When 1 travelled with Americans in that category on board ship I found that they talked mostly about what they would see in the outback in Australia.

There are many small annoyances on the waterfront which are encountered by tourists and which ought to be removed. I have mentioned the fact that shops, bars and tea rooms are closed the whole time a ship is in port. When a vessel ties up at Woolloomooloo it may be impossible for the passengers to get even a cup of tea, much less to obtain any other refreshment, at the vessel's own shop, because it is locked. Where can one get a cup of tea at Woolloomooloo? It is impossible to get one anywhere there. So tourists have to travel into the city. This should not be. In American ports that I visited one could get service at refreshment rooms very close to the waterfront. Little things like this make all the difference between a successful tour and an unsuccessful one.

Americans who travel to Australia by ship spend three weeks at sea on the round trip. Most of these tourists of whom I speak make the round trip. Apart from a shipping service to bring migrants to Australia, we need an organised, independent Australian shipping line that will cater for tourists at medium fares. The report by the two American companies that I have mentioned places heavy emphasis on the desirability of attracting people to Australia in the off season. One almost feels that it might have used the phrase 'off tourist season'. It points out that tourists should be encouraged to come to Australia in the seasons when fares and freights are lowest. We have heard of such things as between seasons travel. 1 am happy to note from the remarks of the Leader of the Government (Senator Henty) that heed has been given to this report. It is based on the sound advice of people who, I believe, know what they are talking about. My only objection is that those who prepared it seemed to have an absolute mania about not interfering with private enterprise. It advanced all sorts of propositions designed to assist private enterprise. I believe that it is the Government's policy to do this. If country areas near the cities are to be opened up for tourists, much money will have to be spent on the development of facilities. We have to spend money on facilities if we are to attract tourists.

I believe that the Government should spend money on publicity and promotional campaigns especially in the United States, Great Britain and European countries, lt ought to have officers of its own tourist organisation stationed in those countries. The Government may intend to undertake this work through the agency of the trade officials of the Department of Trade and Industry but it should not let the matter rest there. It should appoint to the offices of the Department in other countries specialists who are trained in the field of tourism and who will give it their special attention. Tourism, to be successful, requires a sort of salesmanship different from that needed in selling woollen goods, wheat, butter or other commodities. The tourist trade is a different kind of trade altogether. I agree with both Senator Morris and Senator Wood who emphasised that tourist promotion is specialist work.

talk.start.para: - Mr Chairman, I wish to direct the attention of the Committee to clause 15 and especially clause 16. I ask whether the powers of the proposed Australian Tourist Commission are wide enough to give effect to its purposes. Clause 15 states that the Commission is to be established for the purpose of the encouragement of visits to Australia, and travel in Australia, by people from other countries. The powers of the Commission, as set out in clause 1 6, appear to be mainly to engage in publicity campaigns overseas; to induce and assist travel agents, transport operators and other appropriate bodies or persons to encourage people in other countries to visit Australia; to produce magazines and pamphlets; to collect information; and generally to undertake, in countries outside Australia, the provision of assistance to travel agents and the like in arranging facilities for people visiting Australia.

speech.para: I believe that there is no provision empowering the Commission to inspect tourist facilities or to suggest the improvement of facilities where they are not up to standard. This is rather contrary to the usual procedures of the Department of Trade and Industry, which is to administer the Commission. As you, Sir, know that Department is at present undertaking a close investigation of containerisation in transport. Another of its functions is to inspect products produced in Australia and exported, ft also lists and classifies manufactures, and labelling and packaging methods and procedures. The Department, in addition to promoting the sale of our exports overseas, classifies the means by which they are produced and labelled. Senator Dittmer referred to the need for safe travel and said that tourists want to know that they are safe when travelling about Australia. With this in mind, 1 wonder whether the powers of the Commission, as set out in clause 1 6, will be wide enough to give it a few teeth, as it were. Instead of merely producing and circulating glossy pamphlets and advertising our tourist attractions overseas, it should be able to ensure that the Australian tourist facilities that it advertises overseas are up to standard.

In particular, I want to mention health considerations at our tourist resorts, about which I asked a question yesterday. Throughout this debate emphasis has been placed on the attracting of tourists from the United States of America. I do not propose to argue about the nature of Americans, but I point out that they place great emphasis on health matters. Indeed, they are quite fastidious about health considerations at tourist resorts. I am deeply concerned at the apparent complete lack of liaison between government and municipal authorities, trade promoters, tourist organisations and operators of tourist resorts on the question of health. I am informed by a very reliable authority in South Australia that from November 1966 to the present time there has been a severe epidemic of gastro-enteritis at Hayman Island. I understand that hundreds of cases of this disease have occurred there since last November. The point that concerns me is that a constituent of mine heard through private channels that there was trouble of this sort on the Island, but was told by the agents that what he had heard was not so. However, when he arrived on the Island the staff immediately gave him pills and told him to take them to prevent diarrhoea. He quickly became ill and needed intravenous therapy. He was flown out to a Queensland hospital. I understand that he was away from his business tor several months.

The point that I make is that nothing seems to be set out in any of the clauses of this Bill to ensure that the Commission will lay down that the resorts that are advertised overseas must be attractive when people arrive after answering advertisements and being prompted by advertisements to go to them. I believe that this is a. big weakness in the Bill. In every other respect it seems to be a wise and effective one. There seems to be no provision in clause 16, which sets out the powers of the Commission, for it to liaise with the State authoriies the municipal authorities and the promotors of tourist resorts on very important questions. The most important question I can think of is the health safety one.

I should like the Minister to lel: me know whether it is contemplated that the Commission will have this tremendously important power. After all, no advertisement is satisfactory if the goods that it advertises are not as advertised. Many honourable senators have spoken about the shortcomings of tourist facilities. Unless some control is exercised by this Commonwealth Commission, I cannot see how the advertising will be as effective as we all hope it will be. I should like to know whether anything is in contemplation in relation to the control, especially in health matters, of the facilities to which reference has been made and to which we hope many thousands of overseas people will be attracted.

talker.party: IND; AP from Aug. 1969; IND from Jan. 1970
talker.name: TURNBULL, Reginald
Senator TURNBULL

talk.start.para: - I refer to the part of clause 15 that states:

quote.para: Thu Commission is established for the purpose of the encouragement of visits to Australia. . . . and to clause 16 (2.) (b), under which the Commission is to induce and assist transport operators.

talk.start.para: - What does 'induce' mean?

talker.party: IND; AP from Aug. 1969; IND from Jan. 1970
talker.name: TURNBULL, Reginald
Senator TURNBULL

talk.start.para: - I will tell the honourable senator. The point that I wish to raise is that we will not get people tn come to Australia unless they can obtain cheaper travel. The Government owns an airline which, as a member of the International Air Transport Association, assists in preventing cheap travel. The result is that Pacific fares are the highest in the world and that no charter aircraft can land in Australia. If people want to charter an aircraft from England, they have to go to New Zealand. Very rarely do tourists come to Australia on charter flights. There have to be exceptional circumstances before they can do so.

speech.para: I suggest that Australia should do what is done in other countries, namely provide cheap charter flights. Americans can go from New York to Switzerland for a fortnight's skiing on a package tour that costs them $200 return; that is all. If we had something like that we would get tourists. All the publicity in the world will not get tourists to Australia because it is such a long way away from most places. We are at the end of the line. Unless we provide cheap fares people will never dream of coming here, because there arc so many other places to see and they can go to see them on cheap charter flights.

The second point that I raise is this: what do people come here to see? The sheep stations and life in the outback certainly attract people. Another attraction is the Great Barrier Reef. All honourable senators who have seen the Reef and been out on it must realise the stupendous effect that it has on people when suddenly the tide goes out and the Reef appears forty to eighty miles off the coast. One can walk on it for four to eight hours, and then one has to leave because it is covered again. It costs money to travel within Australia. It is of no use bringing tourists to Australia if, by the time they arrive, they have no money left to enable them to sec (he tourist attractions of Australia. So I believe that the Bill does not go far enough in that, although it assists people outside Australia, it does not assist them sufficiently inside Australia.

There is only one other attraction in Australia that people cannot see elsewhere. Beautiful coastline can be seen anywhere in the world. That one other attraction is central Australia, lt would appeal to overseas people. In addition, there is Papua and New Guinea. I do not know whether the Bill covers our Territories. 1 assume that it does. Here is an untapped field of tourism. It would help the people of Papua and New Guinea if it were possible to increase tourism there. A considerable sum of money would have to be spent in preparing the field there. The hotels in the Territory are very badly run and very expensive by Australian standards.

talk.start.para: - The internal air fares are shocking.

talker.party: IND; AP from Aug. 1969; IND from Jan. 1970
talker.name: TURNBULL, Reginald
Senator TURNBULL

talk.start.para: - Yes. The whole problem is one of finance. If Papua and New Guinea is included in the Bill, the Commission should look to it because tourism is one of the few sources of revenue available to the Territory, lt certainly represents a tourist attraction that we do not have in Australia. So, if we want to do something to help the people of the Territory, here is one field in which we can help.

speech.para: When we get people to come to Australia and they see the Great Barrier Reef, the sheep stations, central Australia and, I. hope, Papua and New Guinea, what else is there for them to see? The trouble is that we have people who, although they talk about tourism, talk about it from a tourist point of view instead of from the point of view of true tourism. 1 find it a little difficult to explain what I mean. Let me refer to Tasmania. We are told that Tasmania is a tourist attraction, lt is a tourist attraction because it is easy to get to it and because one can see the whole place in a week. For years I have been trying to get the Tasmanian Government to build a cable car from the bottom lo the top of Mount Wellington. That would be a tourist attraction. It would induce people to come to Tasmania. I want the Government to build a hotel on the top of Mount Wellington. I also have another project, namely, the building of a casino in Tasmania. Of course, when 1 start talking about a casino, people raise their hands in horror because it means gambling. Noone objects to the Totalisator Agency Board. Evidently that is not gambling. Noone objects to Tattersalls and the Opera House lotteries. Evidently they are not gambling. A casino is a very dreary pi.ice to go to, but it attracts rich Americans. The only trouble about building a casino in Tasmania would be that once it was built other States would build casinos and Tasmania would be left out in the cold again. I repeat that the only answer for the Australian tourist industry is cheap fares and we will not have cheap fares as long as Qantas Empire Airways Ltd is a member of an organisation which insists that there be no charter flights and that there be high fares for flights across the Pacific Ocean.

talk.start.para: [8.58] - I wish to reply to a few of the comments that have been made. Senator Ormonde asked whether the Commission would do anything about publicity. It can undertake any publicity at all concerned with overseas tourists. Publicity is one of its functions. He also asked whether the Commission could make any actual bookings. It cannot make actual bookings outside Australia if there is in the area concerned an Australian private enterprise company that can make the bookings.
- That would include an Australian advertising agent, would it?

- I am talking about bookings, not publicity. The Commission can undertake publicity, but it cannot make actual bookings outside Australia if there is in the area concerned an Australian private enterprise company that can make the bookings. Senator Ormonde made an inquiry about the operations of the Commission. The Commission has yet to be established, but, within the limits of the Bill, the Commission itself will decide how it will operate and what work it will carry out.

speech.para: Senator Laughtspoke about health matters, inspections of premises and health controls and the problems associated with visitors going to an area where a health problem existed. The honourable senator asked whether the Commission would have any power of inspection or control in these matters. My answer to his query is that the Commission will be a promotional body, lt will not be a controller of health. It will have no powers of inspection or control regarding health. The administration of health, in the sense that Senator Laught had in mind, is a local government matter. Senator Turnbull made a very interesting comment on cheap chartered Rights. This suggestion is, I think, worthy of examination although I imagine that a variety of problems could be found concerning it. I will be pleased to bring the matter to the attention of the Minister for Civil Aviation (Mr Swartz).

Senator Turnbullalso referred to Papua and New Guinea and asked what authority the Commission would have to promote tourism in the Territory. I inform the Senate that Papua and New Guinea has its own Tourist Board. The Australian Tourist Commission could engage in joint tourist promotions with the Tourist Board in Papua and New Guinea.

talk.start.para: - I have abstained from speaking in the debate on the Australian Tourist Commission Bill because I was so impressed by the overwhelming support that the Bill received from all sides. But I wish to ask the Minister for Housing (Senator Dame Annabelle Rankin) to take into consideration clause 12 of the Bill in special relationship to the function of the Commission with which we are dealing. Before actually making reference to that point, may I say that the prime purpose for which 1 rose was to emphasise that the two persons to whom I think this country is most indebted for this Bill are, firstly, Senator Wood and, secondly, exSenator Nancy Buttfield, who laboured for years in this cause while she was a senator. I feel that everybody should acknowledge that this Bill is a belated product of their endeavours.
- This sounds like a mutual admiration society.

- I do not know whether it would be mutual. It would become the honourable senator to bestow a little admiration other than towards his own looking glass. Clause 12 incorporates the stock disqualification formula that was forged in debates in this chamber about ten years ago for legislation establishing bodies of this sort. The Australian public has been the victim of so much fraud in large commercial companies or commissions in the past ten years that safeguards are essential and it is one of the provinces of this Parliament to see that they are provided. We have had an instance in Sydney in the last 12 months which shows how imperative it is in the interests of business integrity that people sitting on boards of directors should disclose their interests.

speech.para: The position is made acute with regard to the Australian Tourist Commission by clause 6 (3.) which provides:
Two of the voting members shall be persons appointed from among persons nominated . . . by a body or association that is approved by the Minister as being representative-

quote.para: Of what? of the industries in Australia connected with tourism.

Two voting members shall be appointed from the industries associated with tourism. These are commercial interests. Clause 12 (4.) sets out the ordinary formula regarding members of commissions by stating: voting member who is directly or indirectly interested in a contract made or proposed to be made by the Commission otherwise than as a member, and in common with the other members, of an incorporated company consisting of not less than twenty-five persons, shall, as soon as possible after the relevant facts have come to his knowledge, disclose the nature of his interest at a meeting of the Commission.

The first thing that 1 want to emphasise is that the obligation of disclosure is imposed upon a person who is directly or indirectly interested in a contract. The business of this Commission is not to make contracts only. If honourable senators look at clause 16 which sets out the powers of the Commission they will see that the making of contracts is a rather small and subsidiary part of its functions. The expenditure of money on publicity advertising directed to particular purposes and the attraction of a flow of tourists are the main functions of the Commission. A member of the Commission who comes from an industry connected with tourism in Australia may, although not directly or indirectly interested in any contract, be interested in the general product of the business of the Commission and may use his position to slant publicity.

Let us assume that Senator Turnbull were to be appointed as manager of a casino. As a member of the Commission he could promote business for casinos. He would not necessarily be involved in any contract with the Commission but he could help the flow of tourists, from which the casino business could acquire profit. I use that illustration because I think, in relation to this particular type of commission, words more general than those that have been used might properly be introduced so as to prevent a conflict between duty and interest. Unless this is expressly safeguarded the temptation to yield to interest before duty exists. It is laxity in legislation that, allows company directors and members of commissions to be put in the ambiguous position that leads to the deception of people whom it is their duty to protect and on whose behalf they are required to make a disinterested expenditure of public funds.
Remainder of Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

subdebate.1.para: Bill (on motion by Senator Dame Annabelle Rankin) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 4 May (vide page 1 147), on motion by Senator Anderson:

quote.para: That the Bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: - The Opposition supports the Bill in the broad sense. It is fully aware of the problems which confront societies in the 1960s because of the alarming increase in the use of certain drugs. Drug addiction has occurred mainly in western societies where there is a reasonably high standard of living. One pleasing feature of the Bill, which is a by-product of the work of the United Nations, is that it represents the adoption of a single convention resulting from a number of years of difficult negotiation. Undoubtedly what prompted the Government to bring in the Bill was the serious problem which confronts the teenagers of today in the alarming increase in the consumption of pep pills and various other drugs which, when used to excess, cause physical and moral degradation.

speech.para: It is interesting to see from a study of the general social changes in Australia that we follow the pattern set in the larger American cities. In my opening remarks I want to refer to some of the experiences that have occurred in the United States. It has been found that the larger cities, such as New York, Los Angeles and Chicago, have the most difficult problems. It is interesting to see also the types of teenagers and others who become addicted to drugs defined in an American publication Newsday' by reporter Martin Schram. He refers to drug addiction as: a malady of the deprived and moneyless; it has become a middle and upper middle class affliction, as well. Suburban youth - the high schooler, the collegian, the dropout, the pushout - these have all grown upon the fringes of bigcity junkie empires.

Stripped of all these terminologies the use of drugs can probably be attributed to our education systems of today and to the extreme competition which is manifested in relation to success in examinations. Probably for the boy or girl who is on the fringe between passing or failing an examination there is some incentive to use drugs as it may help them to get over a scholastic hump. But often they pay a high price physically and mentally through taking drugs. In some cases the result may be only a minor physical or mental breakdown, but other cases are much more serious.

Statistics are published by various countries to show the number of people taking drugs. There is a tendency in the United States of America, Canada and some of the larger European cities to inflate these statistics and to present the situation as being more serious than it really is. However, it would be wrong to ignore these statistics. The figures published in the United States reveal that although the number of teenagers taking pills and other drugs is not very high as a proportion, it is enough to cause worry to any thinking person in the community. But there is another aspect of the situation. People other than teenagers are involved. Some shift workers or long distance hauliers al times rely on stimulants to enable them to last out a shift. I know that the Transport Workers Union of Australia has been very critical of those who take drugs, but a driver may have paid a high price for his truck and may feel that he has to keep going on interstate schedules to be able to afford the vehicle. In these cases it is sometimes necessary to resort to beanies and other stimulants. Obviously there needs to be a much tighter control on the sale of these preparations.

The Opposition, while supporting in broad principle the Bill now before us, is not unaware that with drugs, as with anything else, an atmosphere of hysteria may be created. It seems to me that there is an added responsibility on the Government to ensure that in enforcing the punitive provisions of the legislation the subject is approached with realism and that the onus of proof provision will apply. I propose to refer in the later stages of my address to one or two specific incidents, but I repeat now that we are fully appreciative of the situation with regard to drugs in the modern society. In our major cities there are all sorts of incidents which show a growing prevalence of this offence. Not so long ago in a special Federal court it was revealed that iwo men who had entered Australia by yachts had used their vessels in an endeavour to make a quick quid by bringing in drugs. One man was smuggling opium and the other LSD. There is a tendency at present when one hears about the smuggling of opium or some other popular form of drug to regard it as an isolated case, but when we examine the experience of the United States we see that the matter becomes much more important. Figures from the San Francisco State College revealed that in one standard term in a student body of 15,000 more than 300 students had indulged in LSD or other forms of drugs. It would be wrong to say that every one of the 300 went completely round the bend - that was not the case - but obviously the danger is there.

In addition to what has been foreshadowed by the Government in this legislation I believe that it is essential that we have educational programmes to inform people of the situation. We find today on the television networks that public relations plays a big part in the sale of various commodities. With many items that are advertised what is referred to as the soft sell is used. 1 believe that complementary to this legislation the Government should contemplate some form of public relations directed at people of school age and those who have left school, lt should be pointed out to them in the modern vernacular that there is not much of a prospect for people to attempt to get a short term advantage from the use of drugs. I do not think we should take a negative attitude on this subject, but neither do I believe that we should hammer the point. Young people must be encouraged to take a different attitude to drugs.

On television we are told of the reasons for smoking the Kool cigarette, the clean cigarette, and there is advertising jargon associated with all sorts of products. Public relations is big business today. I believe that the Government should call some of the advertising agencies together and tell them that if we are to achieve a higher physical and moral standard in Australia they will have to contribute something to society. This would be a simple matter if we could adopt the arguments used against those who take alcohol in excess, lt could be said that someone who feels depressed should be able to take a stimulant, but the tragedy is that many people who are on the verge of an academic career and who are lacking emotional stability get into the situation where they feel that they need stimulants, lt could even be argued by some that there is a similar problem in relation to book censorship, which is also under the administration of the Minister for Customs and Excise (Senator Anderson). Many people have the idea that if one can get a kick out of something it is 'mod' to try it. But where do we go from there?

Although the Opposition supports the Bill in broad principle it does not accept that it provides the whole answer to the problem. We believe that there has to be a complementary education programme to inform people who have problems thai drugs are not the answer. The Opposition believes that the soft sell is the way to do this and is essential if we are to reduce the incidence of drug taking. I notice that the Government is rightly concerned with modern forms of transportation. With the increase in air travel, it is necessary to be extremely vigilant. In the United States recently a consignment of locally manufactured amphetamine - sometimes called beanies - was being exported on a ship leaving New York City. Below the first few layers of the drug was cotton waste. The bulk of the consignment had been hijacked and diverted into large American cities. At the moment, this particular problem in the Commonwealth is limited to a few large cities - Sydney and Melbourne and possibly Brisbane. If it spreads inland, naturally the job of protection will be made more difficult.

In relation to detection I should like to raise a matter to which the Minister might reply later on. In the United States of America the Treasury Department operates the Bureau of Narcotics which in a broad sense combats this problem of addiction among high school students. A new group known as the United States Bureau of Drug Abuse Control has been formed, which deals not with opium and other such drugs but with new varieties that are a threat to teenagers principally.

I arn concerned particularly about one aspect. If we find pedlars operating inland, where will the operations of the Department of Customs and Excise end and where will the Commonwealth Police take over? Be that as it may and with all due respect to the various State police forces, the Department of Customs and Excise unquestionably has an intimate knowledge of this situation and it may be advisable to consider whether or not an additional division should bc established, such as we have seen in the immigration field. Nobody would question the efficiency in many fields of the Commonwealth Police Force but it has still been found necessary to establish a special force to deal with alien registration anomalies or offences, and something similar may have to be considered in relation to drug control.

I know that this matter is worrying numerous groups in the community. In the United States of America this vice - that is what it is - of drug addiction is increasing, and sometimes one can learn from the mistakes of other groups. Unquestionably, this is a challenge to the community. In big cities wc see a big influx of strangers and there are always people moving around peddling drugs. Then there is a different group altogether. Amongst middle-aged people we find some who are constantly in pain and it is a small step from taking the drugs that are provided under the normal prescriptions of doctors to taking increased quantities. .1 should imagine that ir would he absolutely stupid to be too rigid in these matters. We sec the tragedy of combating pain in people who are suffering the last stages of cancer. It is obvious that the medical profession takes a much broader approach to the cushioning of pain than it used to do. There is a more flexible approach to the use of drugs for this purpose than there was ten or twenty years ago. That is one of: the difficulties involved in the administration of legislation of this kind. We have to consider how much control should be exercised without being too loose in supervision. There may be cases of people in desperation who look for relief and find that it is claimed by some members of the medical profession that their hands are tied.

In general terms the Opposition is not unaware of the problems. We believe that unquestionably some unscrupulous people are trafficking in drugs. A number of rings have been broken up recently and we are quite happy about that. But there are dangers. We have a cosmopolitan population and there may be miscarriages of justice. My mind goes back seven or eight years when I, together with other people, was seeing off a foreign ship leaving Australia. There was an extremely cosmopolitan group of people farewelling relatives. 1 had a friend who was from European country A and there were people from European country B. As 1 came down the gangplank 1 turned round and 1 noticed that my friend had disappeared. I made some inquiries and found that he was being interrogated by customs officials. 1 do not blame them for their vigilance. What happened was that half a dozen fellows from the foreign group B had some very minor racket - 1 am not condoning it - in relation to cigarettes from the ship's canteen. I asked what my friend was doing there. He had nol been long in Australia and he spoke two or three European languages. The officials said: 'We heard him speak in language B and of course we took him in with the other six.' 1 want to say in fairness that justice was done. There was no prosecution. I was able to satisfy the officials that the fact that he was able to pass the time of day in one foreign tongue did not mean that he was an accessory to the crime. 1 throw in that particular instance because in the light of the penalties prescribed we have to be careful. In that connection the Minister might indicate from the point of view not merely of avoiding miscarriages of justice but also of detection, how many officers of the Department of Customs and Excise have a knowledge of some foreign tongue. We have already raised this matter in relation to the Department of External Affairs and other issues. I am sure that a knowledge of foreign tongues would be invaluable in regard to detection and 1 make that point in relation to future operations of the Department. Has that matter been taken into consideration?

The Opposition is not unaware of the situation. We have reached a certain stage in the manufacture of drugs in this country and a close check must be made, lt is probably not a matter of a firm itself being involved, but it is possible that some unscrupulous person in it might divert an amount of a drug that is produced into illegal channels, and this is a very difficult situation. In broad principle we support the Bill. We are not unaware of the fact that even what is proposed will not mean a solution of the problem. The US is dealing with this problem, which is increasing all the time, and probably we can learn from its experience. In relation to penalties we should like an assurance in broad terms, that the principle That the onus of proof is on the Crown will not be jettisoned. At least we hope that we will be able to keep this unquestionable evil of the 1960s within bounds and we want to ensure that people who exploit other human beings by trafficking in drugs will be adequately dealt with. At the same time we must ensure that it is not only the person in the lower echelons of drug peddling that is caught while the top operators are not. I know that in this particular field the Department of Customs and Excise has a difficult row to hoe in that sometimes when prosecutions are launched it is found the top operators have disappeared. That brings me to a question that I wish to pose to the Minister. I note that not all the member nations attended the original United Nations convention that was held to deal with this matter. The Minister might indicate to us the member countries of the United Nations who are not parties to this Convention. I know that over the years problems have arisen because certain people have refused to face up to their obligations under the Panamanian flag with relation to shipping. In the same way it would appear that certain countries are not facing up to their obligations with relation to drug addiction. Finally, the Opposition has no desire to delay the Bill unduly. We realise that it can do some good and we hope that it will achieve the objects we all desire it to achieve.

talk.start.para: - I should like to take this opportunity of congratulating the Minister for Customs and Excise (Senator Anderson) on presenting this Bill to the Senate. Its purpose is to control the manufacture of narcotic drugs from locally produced raw materials and to direct certain other operations involving drugs in accordance with obligations which Australia will assume on becoming a party to the Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs 1961. As the Minister explained in his second reading speech, the Single Convention is a codification of nine earlier international treaties on drug control and is the result of years of work by the United Nations Commission on Narcotic Trade in consultation with the World Health Organisation and other interested bodies. Fiftyseven countries and thirty-three territories have ratified it. The Convention covers all aspects of narcotic control, both national and international and forms the basis of a world-wide campaign against drug addiction and illicit trafficking. As the Minister has said, the Bill is the first of a number of steps that the Government proposes to take to counter the illicit production of and illicit trafficking in narcotics in Australia.

speech.para: My interest in this matter goes back over many years. 1 should like to remind -the Senate that it was on 12th July 1950, not long after I entered the Senate, that I asked my first question in connection with -he smuggling and use of drugs in Australia. In July 1951 I followed up my first question with another. I asked then whether the Australian Government had entered into an agreement with the United Nations to limit the production and distribution of narcotic drugs.

Because I was disturbed at reports of drug smuggling and drug addiction, I persisted with questions in 1952, 1959, 1961, 1963, and 1966. Earlier this year I continued to ask questions. They covered increases in smuggling, methods of detection at airports and on ships. T recall that on one occasion I asked for information concerning a statement by a former commissioner of police in Victoria about the increase ;n drug smuggling. The replies that I received have been courteous in the extreme. Three Ministers have held the relevant portfolio since 1950, and on every occasion I have been informed that all efforts are being made to control and prevent the illegal entry of certain drugs into the country. Instances were reported where the vigilance of customs officers had resulted in the seizure of drugs and other goods.

This was very good as far as it went, but my basic fears remained unassuaged because, from information I had received, I had reason to fear that Australia was likely to face problems similar to those of other countries where drug peddling and addiction had already reached extraordinary pro portions. I do not suggest that this matter should be over dramatised; nor do I believe that the dangers in it should be underestimated. Many Australians - I do not include the Minister for Customs and Excise (Senator Anderson) amongst them - believe that drug trafficking and addiction find their places only in the police records of other countries or in parts of the often sleazy underworld stories served up as entertainment by film and television media. I am sure that it came as a great shock, therefore, to many people to read that Australia was in danger of being considered an important link in an international chain of drug pedlars and that many responsible people were voicing their concern about the control, or lack of control, of certain narcotics and hallucinatory drugs.

The extent to which addiction is increasing in Australia is unknown, but it is worthy of mention that Article 18 of the schedule deals with the treatment of addiction. Dr M. S. Dalton, who is in charge of an alcoholic and drug unit attached to Parramatta Hospital in Sydney said recently that it was impossible to estimate the number of addicts. Speaking later to the annual conference of the Country Women's Association of New South Wales in Sydney, Dr Dalton said that addiction was just as tragic in the older age groups, although it was the younger addicts who were featured mostly in the newspapers. I was interested to note that Senator Mulvihill, who made a very worthwhile contribution to this debate, confined most of his remarks with regard to drug addiction to teenagers and young people. Dr Dalton, however, stated that there was a large group of addicts aged between thirty and forty who were mostly housewives with grown children. This group, she said, was addicted mainly to the barbiturates and sedatives and the cure rate for addicts was only between 5% and 40%. Once a person was cured he or she had to abstain from all forms of drugs for life.

We have heard a lot of talk about narcotics and hallucinatory drugs. Dr Dalton supported much of what has been said because she claimed that of all drugs, these are the most dangerous types. She also stated that heroin has a 100% addiction rate.

talk.start.para: - What did she mean by that?
- She meant that almost 100% of the people who took heroin became totally addicted to it.
- There is no redemption, in other words.

- That is so. I believe that the Bill before the Senate is evidence of the determination of the Commonwealth to prevent narcotics becoming available to the Australian public for other than bona fide medical purposes. This feeling is shared at State levels because all State governments have indicated their acceptance of the provisions of the Convention and, as the Minister has said, all necessary amendments have been made to their legislation by the States. 1 understand that in my own State of Victoria the police force recently strengthened its drug squad and that other States have taken steps to tighten control over both prescribed and illicit drugs.

speech.para: Sir DerrickDunlop, physician to the Queen in Scotland since 1961 and Chairman of the British Ministry of Health Safety of Drugs Committee, spoke on an ABC radio programme when he visited Australia last year. He referred to the insatiable demand of the public for medicine and to the fantastic amount of money expended in purchasing over the counter patent medicines which do not have to be prescribed. Sir Derrick said that potent drugs, especially drugs acting on the central nervous system, were being used too frequently for non-specific trivial reasons. These drugs, included tranquillisers, barbiturates and pep pills. Those are some of the drugs to which Senator Mulvihill referred. Sir Derrick then went on to say that some four billion capsules containing barbiturates were manufactured each year in the United States of America. Those four billion capsules represent the manufacture of only one country. The total number of pills of this kind manufactured in the world would be absolutely astronomical.

I do not claim to have any clinical knowledge of the effect of drugs, nor would I presume to voice an opinion other than to say that I have been assured by a most reliable source that the dependence of persons of any age on drugs of a narcotic or hallucinatory type paves the way for possible addiction from which there is often no way back and no cure. In my opinion the legislation is most desirable and long overdue. Following control of narcotics, penalties for breaches of the law will be increased. Senator Mulvihill mentioned this aspect also. Unlike Senator Mulvihill, however, I see no reason why people who peddle drugs should be absolved from responsibility. I would like to see maximum penalties imposed for the breaches of the law committed by pedlars because these people know that by trafficking in drugs they are helping to destroy the body and soul of the unfortunate person they supply.

I should like to see this Bill passed through the Senate with as little delay as possible. I congratulate the Minister on what I agree has been a lengthy and most difficult task, and I take comfort from the following statement in his second reading speech:

quote.para: Apart from these measures the Government is examining narcotics control generally with a view to identifying what further steps might be taken to safeguard the Australian public. 1 agree wholeheartedly with Senator Mulvihill that the Government's action needs support through educational programmes designed to point out to the Australian people, and particularly to our youth, that addiction to drugs is one of the most soul destroying experiences and that the end result is too dreadful to contemplate. I support the Bill.

talk.start.para: - As the Minister for Customs and Excise (Senator Anderson) said in his second reading speech, this Bill is designed to control all aspects of the manufacture of narcotic drugs from locally produced raw materials under a system of licensing manufacturers as provided for in the Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs 1961. Bearing in mind the obvious great increase in the consumption of narcotics, not only in Australia but also throughout the world, let me say at the outset that it is surprising that the Australian Government has taken so long to bring a Bill of this very important nature into the Australian Parliament. I suppose this is a case of better late than never. But much more needs to be done in the future. I agree with Senator Wedgwood's comment that this legislation is long overdue.

speech.para: According to the history set out in the Minister's second reading speech, representatives of seventy-four countries including Australia met in New York in 1961 to draw up an agreement in relation to narcotic drugs. The Convention came into force, after it had been ratified by a certain number of countries, on 13th December 1964 and now in 1967, three years later, the Government has introduced this measure into the Parliament. This is a very important matter because narcotic drugs affect not only the lives and welfare of a great number of people but also, as history has shown, the welfare of nations.

A narcotic substance is one which when swallowed, inhaled or injected into the system brings about a state of drowsiness, sleep, stupefaction or insensibility. The increasing trend towards the taking of narcotic drugs by sections of society, especially some members of our younger generation, must be of concern to all thinking people. Indeed it is rather frightening because hardly a day goes by that we do not read in one of the metropolitan daily newspapers in Australia some article about an increase in the smuggling of drugs, about a quantity of drugs having been picked up by customs officials, about the problems of people taking drugs and about the attitude adopted by pedlars towards their victims. The reliance of people on narcotics now appears to be so heavy that newspapers are devoting long and detailed articles to it. Only recently I read that the taking of drugs has become a status symbol among members of our younger generation.

The Reverend Ted Noffs, who is in charge of the Wayside Chapel at King's Cross in Sydney, has had a lot to do with this problem. He has dealt with a number of drug addicts and has written a pamphlet on the subject. He divides members of the younger generation who take drugs into four different categories. He refers to the thrill seekers, the people taking drugs for the purpose of stimulation; the experimenters; the escapists; and the rebellious who want to get away from the present form of society. Dealing with the thrill seekers Mr

Noffs says that it is inevitable that the question of drugs should arise in most discussions when young people are gathered together. More particularly it arises when conversation is focused on boredom with and sickness within modern society. He says that thus the stage is set in a definite cultural group for what is in many cases a social adventure. This gentleman has had a lot of experience with people who are addicted to drugs because they are sick of their ordinary, everyday lives. They want to get 'hep', which I understand is one of their terms. They resort to drug taking.

When I was a young boy at school the closest that 1 and my contemporaries ever got to drug taking was to sneak down into the bushes and light up cigarettes. To us this was a status symbol, lt is sad to compare (hat practice with newspaper reports of young girls - fourteen, fifteen and sixteen years of age - at high schools taking the pep drug referred to by Senator Mulvihill as LSD. The nation has reached a very serious stage indeed. What a rat race it is. What a mad hatter's society it must be when drivers of motor transport vehicles in order to earn a reasonable living must rely for some reason or another on a co-pilot in the form of a pill or drug to keep them awake at the wheel.

In the edition of 'Time' magazine of 5th May an article appeared on the subject of drugs in the United States of America. Reference is made in the article to transport workers. It states that drivers of independent trucks use 'bennies', which I understand are a form of stimulant, to stay awake and make longer runs. Motor fleet operators sternly forbid their use. The article states that when amphetamine stimulation wears off it may do so abruptly and put the driver to sleep at 60 miles an hour. Therefore not only is that type of drug a danger to operators of long distance vehicles, but also in some cases, as honourable senators can imagine, it could be responsible for fatalities of other persons on our roads. Perhaps a great number of Australians do not realise the importance and the serious nature of the legislation under discussion this evening.

The 'Australian' of 21st November 1966 attributed certain remarks to Sir Derrick Dunlop, Chairman of the British Ministry of Health's Safety of Drugs Committee. He is reported to have said that about 10% of beds in general hospitals are occupied by patients suffering from the effects of drugs used to treat them; that is, 10% of hospital beds are occupied by people suffering from the after effects of drugs prescribed for their treatment. One can imagine the effects on the human body of drug taking without a prescription and without thought to the problems involved. If Sir Derrick Dunlop's assessment of the effectsof prescribed drugs is correct, it might be fairly asked: What is happening to people who are addicted to narcotics for the purpose of stimulation? Unfortunately there is no doubt on the evidence available to us that Australians are becoming a nation of pill swallowers. I do not mean that every person in Australia is engaged in the illicit use of narcotics, but even on prescriptive standards, according to a recent article in the 'Sydney Morning Herald', it is rather staggering to compare what is happening in Australia with events in the United States of America. On top of the chart of prescription usage of drugs in Australia are hypnotics - the sedatives and sleeping pills which rank no higher than seven on the prescription usage chart of the United States of America. The rating of analgesics - they are the pills, powders and tablets taken for real and imaginary headaches - on the Australian chart is fourth. On the American chart they are sixth. A comparison of the prescription usage of drugs in Australia and the United States shows that there is justification for the claim that the Australian nation, for whatever reason, is becoming a nation of pill swallowers.

I have referred to what might be described as the legitimate use of drugs. In addition, of course, there are the people who are caught up in the illicit use of drugs. It has become a great problem which is growing and touching all sections of the Australian community. Recently I read in a Sydney newspaper that almost every type of drug, including marihuana, methedrine and the hallucination drug LSD to which I referred earlier, is available in New South Wales gaols and psychiatric centres. Not only are drug pedlars able to operate within the ordinary section of the community but also, by devious means or otherwise, they are able to get drugs into the gaols and psychiatric centres.

talk.start.para: - Does this Bill deal with that matter?

- This Bill deals with the control and manufacture of drugs, but I am dealing with the spread of the drug nuisance. I suggest that this Bill Joes not go quite far enough and that is the reason whyI have mentioned this matter to the Senate. This type of drug apparently is in use in New South Wales and 1 venture the opinion that probably it is also in use throughout Australia. Some of these drugs debilitate and destroy the inner fabric of man. If a drug leads to addiction the user often becomes so obsessed with it that he reaches the stage where he feels that he cannot live without it. In fact, he lives for nothing else. Therefore, as I was saying in reply to Senator Wright's interjection, whilst I personally do not cavil at the terms of this Bill, I think that far from sufficient has been done by this Government or by any government in Australia effectively to deal with and clean up this trade.

speech.para: Recently we read about Sydney being used by an international drug running company. From all reports that one reads, not only is the company growing internationally but it has an expanding market in Australia. But apart from trying to deal with the manufacture of drugs, from the curative point of view it appears to me that little, if anything is being done for the rehabilitation of people who have been caught up in this trade.I shall refer to a report which was called for by the President of the United States of America. A Commission was set up in order to tender him advice on narcotic and drug abuse in the United States. The report was tendered on 1st November 1963. I would suggest that anyone who is interested in this subject should obtain a copy of this report and give it very serious consideration. It is headed: The President's Advisory Commission on Narcotic and Drug Abuse'. It is the final report of the Commission of November 1963. In the preamble to the report the Commission states:

quote.para: The general philosophy of this Commission can be stated in three parts:

item.para: The illegal traffic in drugs should bo attacked with the full power of the federal government. The price for participation in this traffic should be prohibitive. It should be made too dangerous to be attractive.

The individual abuser should be rehabilitated. Every possible effort should be exerted by all governments - federal state, and local - and by every community toward this end. Where necessary to protect society, this may have to be done at times against the abuser's will. Pertinent to all, the causes of drug abuse must be found and eradicated.

Drug users who violate the law by small purchases or sales should be made to recognise what society demands of them. In these instances, penalties should be applied according to the principles of our present code of justice. When the penalties involve imprisonment, however, the rehabilitation of the individual, rather than retributive punishment, should be the major objective.

speech.para: Those remarks were pertinent to the United States in November 1963, and because of the growing trade in Australia, I believe that they are very apt in Australia today. When one turns to the back of the report and sees the rehabilitation service that is provided for narcotic users, one sees that in a comparison between Australia and the United States very little, if anything, is being done in Australia.

Senator Wedgwoodreferred to some comments which had been made by a Dr Dalton who is a woman psychiatrist attached to the alcoholic and drug addiction unit at the Parramatta Hospital in Sydney. Dr Dalton suggested that one of the first steps that should be taken towards overcoming this addiction problem was the establishment of a register of drug addicts. She pointed out, for instance - and I think that Senator Wedgwood referred to this - that heroin had a 100% addiction rate.
