Dr Dalton in this address which was extensively reported throughout the metropolitan newspapers of Sydney, at any rate, went on to say that in England if a person became addicted to heroin, the addict, after registering at the Home Office, was able to have prescribed a certain dosage in order to help overcome the addiction and the insatiable desire for more of the drug. It paid these people to register at the Home Office in order to receive appropriate treatment.

Of course, our doctors and social workers are scattered throughout the length and breadth of this nation. Therefore I suppose it would be difficult to ascertain the number of addicts in any particular area. Surely ways and means of doing this have to be found. Consideration has to be given to effectively dealing with what could become a matter of very great national importance. We of the Opposition do not oppose the

Bill. We believe that it will help a lot in tackling what is a great problem at the present time. Nevertheless, in order to prevent the problem expanding further, we believe that much more must be done towards eliminating this vile practice of narcosis.

talk.start.para: - 1 want to make a comparatively brief contribution to this debate. In common with other honourable senators, in addition to having been supplied with a copy of the Bill and a copy of the second reading speech of the Minister for Customs and Excise (Senator Anderson), I have been supplied with notes that deal with the clauses of the Bill. I commend the Minister for having supplied this additional data, an action which is the exception rather than the rule in this chamber. I make what I believe is a fairly valid comment when I say that the wealth of material which is contained in the second reading speech and the notes on the clauses of the Bill only serve to indicate to me that this Bill and its implications need much more examination than they will get from the Senate before the Bill becomes law.

speech.para: I think that any honourable senator would be bold if he rose in his place and said that he had a complete and absolute understanding of the purpose of the Bill, how it will operate and whether when it becomes law it will meet the requirements of this country in the field of narcotics, both on the question of addiction and the way in which illegal narcotics find their way into the hands of people who become addicts or who take these drugs. I believe that we would be bold indeed if we felt satisfied that this legislation will provide any great degree of protection against the drug traffic which we are trying to fight. I do not want anybody to get the idea, because 1 have said this, that I am unhappy about this Bill having come before the Senate. I believe that there is and has been for some time in this country a growing awareness of the very great evil that narcotic drugs cause in the community. We know what evil they have wrought in other countries where their use has been allowed to gain a foothold and where addiction has become widespread. I do not suggest either that this measure is too little or that it is too late. But I believe that we must take some other action to provide the sort of precautions that are necessary if we are to be able, as a legislative chamber, finally to say that we are satisfied with the legislation introduced for the control of narcotic drugs.

Having said that, Mr Acting Deputy President, I want to touch on a subject that I raised some weeks ago by way of a question. The Minister for Customs and Excise will no doubt recall the question. I asked whether the Government had considered the advisability of establishing in this country a counterpart of the Bureau of Narcotics in the United States of America and whether the time was considered right for the establishment of such a body. I am not yet convinced that the measures that the Minister, in his reply, stated were to be taken will adequately meet the situation. As 1 have said, I have at this stage examined the Bill, the Minister's second reading speech and the accompanying notes only cursorily. I am still not satisfied that if we were to refrain from establishing some overall authority similar to the United States Bureau of Narcotics we would be acting in the best interests of this country. Such a body could deal expertly with narcotics problems and determine how the people of Australia could best be protected from narcotics.

There are two branches of this problem. The first is the availability of narcotics and addiction to them. The second, I consider, is perhaps the more important of the two. lt concerns the manner in which narcotic drugs reach this country illegally. There is no need for me lo remind the Senate that in the last year or so in particular we have experienced mounting disquiet at the number of hauls, as the customs officers call them, of narcotics that have been taken from overseas ships in some of the capital city ports. I believe that the magnitude of these hauls has prompted the Government to introduce this measure, or at least has speeded up its introduction. This is a good thing. But I am still disquieted by the thought that the measures provided for in this Bill may not adequately meet the situation that confronts us in Australia at present.

As I have said, the Department of Customs and Excise has had some success in detecting illicit imports of drugs. I commend the officers of the Department on their vigilance. 1 believe that no group of men could perform better within the limitations imposed on them and the bounds of the procedures under which they work. But I consider that they are being inhibited by the fact that we are not tackling the narcotics problem in a proper and cohesive manner. I believe that we ought to have some overall authority in the form of an Australian bureau of narcotics. We might give it any name, but we should at least have some expert advisory body that could deal with the whole problem of the prevention of addiction on the one hand and the protection of Australia from the introduction of narcotics from other parts of the world, and particularly the Far East, on the other hand. I know that il: is comparatively simple for people in this country who are so disposed to grow certain plants and produce dangerous drugs for themselves. As we know, a person in Sydney was recently convicted on a charge of growing in his bathroom the plant from which the drug marihuana is produced. We all are aware that this and other drugs can be produced readily from plants that may be easily grown in this country. However, I believe that the real danger that confronts us is that presented by the possibility of imports of narcotic drugs in large quantities, mainly from Asia, and especially from the Far East.

The great danger that we face has been emphasised by the large hauls that customs officers have discovered, particularly in the last two or three years. It was the increase in the volume of illicitly imported drugs being discovered by customs officials that prompted me to ask the Minister whether the Government considered that the time had arrived when we ought to consider the establishment in Australia of a bureau of narcotics. I believe that if we adopt the view that because illicitly imported drugs have been found only in capital city ports it is only at those places that any problem in relation to imports exists, we are only fooling ourselves. We are ever conscious of the fact that this country has thousands of miles of unguarded coastline. There is no doubt in my mind that dangerous drugs are landed in this country by foreign ships not only at capital city ports but also at obscure points, perhaps between Sydney and Brisbane or between Brisbane and ports farther north, as well as off the north western coast of

Western Australia. One can only conjecture about this, but I am reasonably certain that ships secretly land unlimited quantities of drugs at convenient points along unguarded stretches of our coastline. One needs no particular measure of imagination to concede not only that this probably happens but also that it is almost a certainty.

talk.start.para: - There is a great profit in it.

- As Senator Mulvihill has reminded me, the risks may be great, but the profits are similarly great. People who get the opportunity to make great profits out of narcotics will certainly take the risk and go to any amount of trouble. I believe that as Australia is so vulnerable to illicit imports of narcotics landed at isolated and secret points on the coastline, we ought to exercise much more care and look beyond the capital city ports and also beyond the secondary ports. We can profit by studying the experience of other countries The Coast Guard in the United States is continually fighting a running battle with drug runners, lt is a vigilant organisation and it has the facilities that it needs to deal with those who traffic in drugs. We must realise that what happens in other countries will inevitably happen here, because the habits and practices of people who deal in drugs are the same the world over. We should not fool ourselves by believing that the only narcotics that enter this country are those that come in through the capital city ports. Wc must take preventive measures not only at those ports but also round our entire coastline if we are to prevent the illegal entry of dangerous drugs.

speech.para: I believe that the factors that 1 have outlined support my contention that we need to go further than is envisaged in this Bill and that we should constitute some overall authority, separate and apart from the customs service, lt is worth recalling that the Bureau of Narcotics in the United States is responsible not only for preventing the illegal entry of narcotics into that country but also for co-ordinating the nation's counter measures against addiction and illegal trafficking in drugs within the country. Unless Australia adopts a similar system we must forever have in the back of our minds the unpleasant possibility that the measures that we are taking are purely stop gap ones which will not meet the requirements of the situation. I hope that the Minister, in his reply to this debate, will pay me the compliment of giving a more considered reply than he gave to the question that 1 asked some weeks ago. If he does that, I and all other honourable senators will be pleased to hear the Government's views not only on what happens in the capital city ports but also on what is likely to be happening in the great stretches of unguarded water between the capital city ports. If the Government is satisfied that nothing of the nature I have suggested is likely to happen or is happening, I believe it is much more easily satisfied than 1 am. That was the main reason for my intrusion into this debate.

The only other contribution that 1 wish to make on the Bill now before the Senate is on the matter of advertising. To some extent, because we permit unrestricted advertising of some drugs that can be, and in many cases are, used for addictive purposes, we are culpable in helping people to form an addiction to these drugs. It is all very well to say that in a private enterprise system people should not be inhibited in advertising their products; but some type of supervision should be imposed on advertising drugs which are potentially dangerous and which could lead to addiction.

talk.start.para: - Which drugs would come within that category?
- It is interesting lo note a statement made by Lord Shawcross who, rather than criticising the advertising of drugs, was supporting it. He said:

quote.para: One of the criticisms heard about the drug industry is that their advertising policies are irresponsible and that too much money is spent upon them. I would not for a moment suggest that in the past advertising executives may not have put out material which was exaggerated or in poor taste, or both; the pharmaceutical industry is not alone in that. But, in fact, the proper advertisement of drugs is an essential step in ensuring that the medical profession is made fully aware of the potentialities and uses of particular drugs. 1 do not entirely agree with that. Before somebody reminds me of the fact, I must hasten to say that I am nowhere near being the authority that Lord Shawcross is. But 1 am entitled to my opinion. I feel that I must differ sharply from his statement because every day one sees instances of the advertising of certain drugs that could lead to some type of addiction. I give the Senate one illustration. Every day in the Pressin my State - I do not know whether this applies in Queensland, the State of Senator Morris, who interjected - one can see an advertisement for a certain type of sleeping tablet, which tells people that they can get a restful sleep if they take one of these tablets every night.

talk.start.para: - It is non-habit forming!

- That is so, but the person has to take one every night! This is indicative of the fact that some supervision of this type of advertising is required. One of two things is so. Either the drug that is being advertised has not any of the dangerous properties of a sedative and therefore the advertising is misleading, or, if it is a drug the taking of which could lead to addiction, there should be some supervision and people should be given some protection from being brainwashed in relation to the potentialities of this type of drug. That is only one illustration. Each honourable senator could find in the newspapers in his State every day quite a number of illustrations of my contention.

speech.para: The people who will have the responsibility of administering this Bill might well give some consideration to the question of advertising. They might find out, first of all, whether the drugs that are advertised have any harmful or addictive properties. If they do, some restriction should be imposed on them. If they do not the fact that emerges is that the advertising must be misleading and untrue. These are matters to which the Senate could well give consideration. There are other points whichI had in mind and to which I wish to refer; but they would be dealt with more appropriately at the Committee stage. I should like the Minister to give me a reply to my suggestion about the formation of a federal bureau of narcotics to tidy up and to integrate all of the forces needed not only to prevent drug addiction and drug trafficking in Australia but also - perhaps this is more important - to prevent the illegal entry of drugs into Australia, which I consider represents the most dangerous invasion that any country can have.

talk.start.para: - I would like to feel happy about congratulating the Government on the introduction of this Bill. I know that it is a necessary Bill and that it follows the passage of a Bill that tightened up the drug traffic and narcotics trade around the waterfront. The Minister for Customs and Excise (Senator Anderson) has been concerned about this matter for many years now - in fact, ever since he became Minister for Customs and Excise. He will remember that about three years ago, in company with other honourable senators, I called attention to the fact that the waterfront was understaffed. I had been approached by customs officers who were really working under difficulties.

speech.para: I give the Minister credit for being able to increase the staff around the waterfront. He has made a great impression. The customs officers are more than happy about what has been done to relieve them of their heavy burden. Sydney had developed the reputation of being the drug clearing house of the world. Whether that was true I do not know. But this Government attempted to do something about the position in Sydney. Possibly Sydney is entitled to that reputation. I live around the waterfront - in the Woolloomooloo, Potts Point and Kings Cross areas. I know the great scourge that the drug trade constitutes. I know its effect on young people in particular.

I am glad that we have in the Senate three or four lawyers who are interested in the preservation of liberty and who can see legal injustices where the layman may not sec them. My experience of the people who are affected by the drug trade is that more or less all of them are people who have not much to live for in this world. Whether their attitude is justified is another matter. I meet these people in the streets of Kings Cross every day that I am around that area. I see the young people particularly at weekends. That brings me to the point which I want to make and in which I think Senator Wright will be particularly interested. The explanatory notes that have been circulated state:

quote.para: Clause 20 provides that an offence against Part III may be prosecuted summarily or upon indictment. If the offence is prosecuted on indictment, a maximum penalty of $4,000 or imprisonment for ten years or both upon conviction is laid down. Where the offence is prosecuted in a court of summary jurisdiction the defendant may be committed for trial or if dealt with summarily is subject to a maximum penalty of $1,000-

speech.para: That clause does not apply to any of the people 1 see who are involved in the drug trade. Mostly these are people who have lost their places in society for various reasons. They are the long hairs and the beatnik population around Kings Cross. There are probably 10,000 people of this type around that area. These people are all over Sydney today, lt is the new form of youth that we have today. These people are supposed to be trying to find their place in the community. I am not sympathetic to them at all but it is around these people that drug addiction seems to operate.

Some of them indulge heavily in the use of drugs; others indulge only to a very little extent. Some of them are on the drug LSD. J have spoken to a number of them. I think that this legislation is much too heavy in ils application regarding LSD. I do not want it to appear that 1 am looking with admiration on the drug LSD. But I. do think that this legislation is very heavy handed where these people are concerned. Most of them are penniless or next to penniless. They do not know where they are living most of the time. They are getting a little kick along from their drugs. I do not think the punishment matches the crime. 1 may be completely wrong-

talk.start.para: - Does not the offence dealt with in clause 20 apply to the person who listributes the drug?
- The honourable senator is talking about the recipients and not the distributors.

- 1 have explained that 1 am not a legal man. I do not want to become technically involved in the matter. In a place not far from my home marihuana is grown in the window box of a flat in which certain people live.
- The honourable senator had better come to my Department and report the matter right away.

- AH right. But this is going on everywhere. All over Kings Cross people are growing their own marihuana. After all, marihuana is grown in the Hunter River valley. I once asked a question about that in the Senate. I was told that it was a

speech.para: State matter. We should shift this obstacle out of the way and do something about making it a Federal matter. The Minister for Customs and Excise is doing that now. But marihuana grows all over Australia.

talk.start.para: - lt grows wild in Queensland.

- lt grows wild everywhere. What is wrong with these people - these miniature addicts who live around Kings Cross - bringing a few roots home and growing it in their window boxes on their window sills? If an investigator locates one of these people, what is his fate? Will he go to gaol for two years? From the Minister's interjection I gather that he visualises these penalties applying to the big manufacturer; he is the one who will be gaoled for ten years or fined $4,000, or both. Certainly the Bill must have these people in mind because it could hardly apply to what I call the small traders in drugs. Yet they are the menaces around Sydney because they are almost everywhere. Heroin and other minor sorts of drugs-
- Minor?

- In minor quantities I mean. Only the other night on television I saw a programme in which various people were handing around their prescriptions or their recipes in much the same way as a woman hands out a recipe for her scones. The Government has a great difficulty in front of it in clearing up this sort of trade. But I believe that this is a matter of addiction more than anything else. If the Government wishes to tackle the matter, first it must try to solve the problem of the long hairs, as they are called. They do exist. They are a part of the community today. They have even set up their own employment office at Kings Cross. In the last month they have put about 700 or 800 of these long hair types into jobs. They have found it difficult to obtain jobs. I make a plea on their behalf because I think we have to accept the fact that there are people of the long hair type and the beatnik type who say that they are trying to escape from modern society or give some other excuse for their action. We must do something about educating them. I do not know that they love their drugs. They get a kick out of LSD for a while. I think that is all it amounts to - a kick. They are not heavily drugged. But the heavily drugged people whom one sees around are a really great problem. I get the impression that this Bill could be too severe in its application to them.

speech.para: When I was a pressman before I entered the Senate - that is not so long ago - a big organisation was running drugs. This is a problem that the Government really needs some assistance to handle. I do not know whether the police force is capable of handling it. It would be a matter to bs dealt with at the State level. But in the incident of which I had experience a big quantity of drugs was dropped into Sydney Harbour. They were taken to a certain place in Crown Street in Sydney from which they were distributed. There were 150 customers on the distribution list. The little parcels of drugs were taken down to a big Sydney retail store. The man distributing them walked in and asked for a pair of pants or a blanket or some other item for a Mr So-and-So at such and such a place in Vaucluse or Bellevue Hill. He said to the person across the counter: 'Wrap this small parcel up with the item and send it out to this man'. So the drug was delivered in a smart wagon belonging to one of the biggest stores in Sydney. This practice went on for some time. Drug distribution is a clever trade and it is big business. This Bill may deal with people who deal with drugs in a big way like that.

But my sympathies are with the beatnik type of drug addict whom I see every day of my life. The Reverend Ted Noffs has established the Wayside Chapel at Kings Cross. So some people are trying to help these drug addicts. He has a theatre and a coffee house for them. They bring their paintings there and they may have a little bit of LSD. The Reverend Ted Noffs is doing very good work. I believe that the Government ought to set up this type of agency to deal with this problem as it is to be found in all our major cities. Of course, we do not know the extent of drug addiction in private homes. I do not think that the Bill extends that far.

Clause 24 gives power for authorised inspectors to inspect the manufacturer's premises, stocks and records at any reasonable time and to take samples for assay. A maximum penalty of $1,000 is provided for obstruction of an officer in his inspection duties. An authorised inspector in clause 24 means an officer authorised in writing by the Minister for Customs and Excise to carry out inspections. Obviously the clause is aimed at fairly large businesses. These inspections do not apply to the type of people about whom I have been speaking, yet they are the ones who get most of the publicity. They are the unfortunate people who are suffering as a result of this industry. It would be almost impossible to eliminate the use of drugs in fashionable homes or at fashionable levels of society.

talk.start.para: - Has the honourable senator looked at the power of entry contained in clause 24 and considered whether it is wider or narrower than the power of entry that was given to inspectors under the Poultry Industry Levy Collection Bill which we dealt with during the Budget session last year?

- -I would like to discuss that in Committee so 1 shall raise it then. Clause 25 permits the Minister and the Comptroller to delegate their powers under the Act, except the power of delegation. Clause 26 relates to the serving of notices on persons and clause 27 gives power to make regulations under the Act and provides a miximum penalty of SS00 for offences against the regulations.
- The honourable senator is not suggesting that they would have $50, is he?
- 1 do not think they would have, but I do not see how the Bill can put an end to their situation.
- The honourable senator is talking as though he is suggesting that the penalty should be to give them a drink of milk.

- Not at all, but I do not think this measure wm solve the problem of the small addicts, I would call them. Nor must it be forgotten that for every drug addict there are ten thousand alcoholics. We must be careful in framing legislation of this type. We might find next that purple hearts come within the provisions. If the authorities start arresting people who take purple hearts many families of good social standing will be affected. We might find next that the truck drivers come within the ambit of the legislation. In the next Bill we might deal with truck drivers who take drugs to keep themselves awake at night. I know that is also a problem. Drugs cover a much wider field than is envisaged in this Bill and the Government has opened up a very large scope for investigation. In England the insurance companies - private enterprise undertakings - have taken an interest in this subject and have set out to help the Government to deal with the drug trade. I propose to read a report to the Senate because it shows that at least they are thinking in different terms from this Government on this problem. The report states:

quote.para: Insurance companies have joined a nation-wide drive to smash the drug racket in Britain.

speech.para: Insurance companies are doing this because chemist shops have been broken into and have become the targets of people who want to break in to get drug supplies which are stored in chemist shops. The report continues:

quote.para: The insurance companies are demanding highly improved standards of security.
Raids on chemist shops have rocketed in the past 12 months as drug pedlars have made the apothecary's shop their target to maintain supplies.

A number of highly experienced burglary surveyors working for insurance companies have undergone a special course in the type of security needed to stop raiders reaching the drugs stored in chemist shops. lt is understood preliminary investigation has already shown a complete lack of security by many chemists.

speech.para: The chemists are culpable. They are nol looking after their drug slocks and are not keeping them in the security which is necessary. I dare say the same sort of thing is happening here. The situation of the chemist might be covered by the Bill, but I do not see any specific reference to it. The report continues:

quote.para: The survey is being carried out mainly by companies which belong to the British Insurance Association.
The association represents 2S0 companies dealing with more than four-fifths of Britain's insurance business.
Insurance cover is to be made much more difficult for chemists who do not take the required precautions to ensure their drug stocks are safe.
The association is working closely with the Home Office and police forces throughout the country.
Regular talks are held between all crime prevention authorities and the crime prevention subcommittee of the British Insurance Association.
The association revealed that in 1966 member companies paid out $40m in crime losses compared with $32m the previous year.

talk.start.para: - Who said that?
- This is a report on an investigation of chemist shops in England in relation to the drug trade. The report continues:

quote.para: Mr KennethBevins, the chairman of the subcommittee, said, 'It is disturbing to have to report another substantial increase in crime losses for the year and to realise criminals are getting away with more than $750,000 a week'.
Mr Bevinssaid a rougher and tougher policy was being adopted by insurance companies in cases where there was failure to introduce proper and adequate safety precautions.

speech.para: That part of the problem has been dealt with in England. Private enterprise - the chemist shops and insurance companies - have combined to help the Government to block some of the escape channels for the drug pedlars in London and elsewhere in England and Scotland. I do nol know whether the Government's attitude extends so far as that in Australia. I do not think it does. There are State laws and Federal laws in relation to these things, but the Bill does not give me any indication that the Government proposes to seek the co-operation of the various police forces of the Stales to attack this great problem. As I said earlier, I congratulate the Government on what it is doing. I think the Minister has taken on a difficult task.

In conclusion I should like to refer .o a problem which might get me into a bit of bother. Often I have been critical of radio and television for over-dramatising. Although I believe that a television station has a duly to expose evils, I think there is a way in which this should be done so that adolescents are not shown how easy ,t is to obtain drugs. Television stations are very careless of their responsibility. I would be the last one in the world to try to suggest what television stations should show in a programme such as Project 67 or a similar documentary programme, but I often feel that they go too far in dramatising something like the drug trade as they did one night last week. They showed how easy it was to make your own drugs. The programme showed this going on all over the port of Sydney where young people get together and exchange recipes for the various types of drugs. I do not see how the Government can solve that problem without much assistance from chemists, the pharmaceutical industry, State police authorities and State governments.

I have before me a note stating that Mr Jago, the Minister for Health in New South Wales, is concerned about the amount of drug addiction in the asylums and psychiatric centres in Sydney. He spoke especially about the worry of the parents and relatives of people who are in Callan Park. The situation is particularly serious when an uncontrolled drug trade is carried on in our psychiatric institutions. I congratulate the Minister on the Bill. However, I believe it needs much public support to see it through. Nevertheless I commend the Minister for his efforts in trying to control the drug traffic.

talk.start.para: - in reply - lt seems lo me that everything I have heard here tonight is a complete vindication of this legislation. I congratulate late honourable senators who have spoken and who have recognised the need for this legislation. Without wishing to show any disrespect for Senator Mulvihill, who led for the Opposition in this debate, I want to come first to some of the things that were said by Senator Ormonde, because they are fresh in the minds of all of us. While congratulating the Government on the action being taken, he went on to suggest that the drug commonly known as LSD was only a minor drug and that he was concerned lest the penalties he loo severe in certain instances. I want to make quite clear that the Government and I personally, as the Minister responsible, make no apology for the penalties that are provided in this Bill or in the Bill that will follow.

speech.para: Senator Ormondespoke of terrible things that are happening to people in the community. He described them in a certain way. I will not be so all-embracing. He said that these people were victims of drug addiction in minor form or major form. This Bill is calculated to protect these people. The penalties prescribed are calculated to act as a deterrent to those evil people who peddle the drugs to the victims about whom he speaks. Much of his speech was about the victims of drug addiction. We have before us a Bill which provides penalties that are severe - one might say unprecedented - but they are prescribed as an acknowledgment of the seriousness of crimes relating to drug addiction. I say that no-one should waste any sympathy on the small pedlar or be confused by the suggestion that LSD is only a minor pep drug. It is a fact of life that LSD is a drug that is a softener-up. Persons who start on pep pills or on LSD are sitting shots for the next phase of drug addiction. As far as we are concerned, the pedlar of LSD is just as culpable, just as evil, just as rotten as the pedlar of any other drug. That is the position as far as the Government is concerned and as far as I am concerned as the Minister responsible for the time being for this legislation. I want to make perfectly clear that we are out to protect people.

Much of what Senator Ormonde said concerned the responsibilities of the States in relation to supervision of State laws concerning addiction. Under the Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs and under the Bill I hat we have before us, all of the States have accepted their responsibilities and have carried out their part of the arrangements. Reference is made to this fact in the second reading speech. The penalties prescribed by the States for those who do wrong things in relation to drugs compare with the penalties proposed in the Bill. The Bill provides that a person who is dealt with summarily and is convicted will be subject to a maximum penalty of two years imprisonment or a fine of SI, 000 or both. If the offence is prosecuted on indictment, the maximum penalty prescribed is S4.000 or imprisonment for ten years. These provisions as to penally were arrived at after the Attorneys-General of the States and the Commonwealth had met to consider the problems. Having regard to the responsibilities of the Slates and the Commonwealth in relation to narcotics, they recommended that the penalties should be as the legislation prescribes. It is not only the Commonwealth that is involved. The States, loo. are playing their part. I want to come to a few questions that were raised - properly - by various honourable senators. Senator Mulvihill referred to minor drugs of addiction. In a circulated amendment these have been incorporated in the description of narcotics.

talk.start.para: - This involves hippies and such people.

- The insidiousness of this particular problem is such that an innocent boy or girl of nineteen or twenty years of age could be induced to take one of these so-called pep pills in a sweet, chocolate or sandwich or in some other way, without being conscious of the implications of it, and would find himself or herself caught up in the need to take a pep pill again. In this way they take the very first step towards the dangers about which we all know. We must prescribe a minimum penalty of some magnitude and significance. That is why the minor penalty is provided.
- What minor penalty?
- I am referring to the penalty prescribed upon conviction in a court of summary jurisdiction, which is two years imprisonment or a fine of Si. 000 or both.
- The Minister referred to a minimum penalty. He did not mean that.

- No. I meant a maximum penalty. It may bc that when we get into the Committee stage we shall have a more informal discussion. Senator Mulvihill suggested that perhaps we did not have enough people in the Department who spoke foreign languages. I think it would be true to say that we have not enough; we want more. But we have officers who meet arrivals at all points of entry, and particularly at big points of entry, who are able to speak foreign languages and who arc capable of handling the situation. In all of these things we can visualise a situation in which we could do with more of a particular type of person on a particular occasion to meet a particular situation. Senator Mulvihill referred also to countries thai had ratified the Single Convention. As Senator Wedgwood indicated, as at 18th April fifty-seven countries were parties to the Convention. I do not propose to read the whole of the list, but it includes such big countries as the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, Czechoslovakia, Canada, New Zealand, Sweden, the United Kingdom, the United States of America, Spain and Japan. With the concurrence of honourable senators, I incorporate the complete list in Hansard.

speech.para: It has to be understood that this Bill stems from a convention that came out of the United Nations Economic and Social Council, lt has to be understood, also, that, contrary to what Senator McClelland had to say, up to the present time we have been able to control the import of drugs under our customs laws. The urgency of this Bill emerges when we discover that the manufacture of narcotics for bona fide purposes such as medicine is about to commence in Australia as the result of plans being well advanced to manufacture morphine and derivatives from raw materials of local origin. lt is not true to suggest, as Senator McClelland has done, that we were doing nothing and that suddenly we have got a spurt on. Something has been done. The fact is that we have control over the importation of raw materials under our customs laws, and we are now taking power under a system of quotas and licences to control the manufacture of narcotics in Australia. 1 should like also to make some reference to a statement that was made about heroin. It is well to remind the Senate that the importation of heroin into Australia is absolutely prohibited and has been so for some considerable time under our customs laws. I repeat that there has been no delay in introducing this Narcotic Drugs Bill. I felt that the purpose of the Bill was rather misunderstood by many honourable senators who spoke. This is a measure by which we are going to control the manufacture of narcotics. They will be controlled until t hey reach the wholesaler. After they reach the wholesaler, the responsibility will move from the Commonwealth and the States will control them under their narcotics laws. There is quite proper provision in the Bill for extreme penalties to be imposed on those people who fail to accept the responsibilities they have with relation to documentation and the control which the Department of Customs and Excise will lay down and which, to a large extent, is spelt out in this Bill.

Senator Tooheyreferred to a bureau of narcotics. He has suggested that it may well be that, whatever is being done in relation to the world problem that is emerging in connection with narcotics, we need to be looking beyond the normal controls that are being exercised at both Commonwealth and State levels. In the first place, we have to understand that we have a federal system - a division of power. In fact, this Bill points out that the States have certain responsibilities. But it is proper that I should say to Senator Toohey and all other honourable senators that at the present time the very highest level of senior officers of various Commonwealth departments are making a very important examination of the particular problems that may be associated with other powers that it may be necessary for us to assume. If honourable senators look at the final paragraph of my second reading speech they will find that it points out that the Government is not saying that this is the ultimate in what is going to be done.

I think it is proper that I should say to the Senate that in fact we are looking closely at what is being done in other parts of the world. A close study is going on at present and it is probable that in the fullness of time, after further studies have been made through the United Nations organisation, which I understand is in conference at present in connection with certain other drugs which it may be necessary to bring under control, we will need to come to the Parliament again with further amendments. 1 want to give the Senate the unqualified assurance that it is the strong determination of the Government, with relation to the control and manufacture of narcotics and in connection with our customs laws, by-laws and penalties, not to be content to say: 'Having done this, we do not need to do any more'. We propose to continue with all the research that may be necessary, and where it is considered appropriate we will not hesitate to come to the Parliament to deal with any matter that may emerge.

Perhaps I have missed some points that some honourable senators have made. If I have. I regret it, but when we are discussing the Bill in Committee, where the procedure is less formal, we may get an opportunity to deal with any point which any honourable senator may wish to raise. I thank the Senate for its assurance that the Bill will have a speedy passage through the second reading stage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
In Committee.
The Bill.

talker.electorate: New South WalesLeader of the Opposition
talker.name: MURPHY, Lionel
Senator MURPHY

talk.start.para: - We indicatedthat we were not opposed to the general policies of this Bill and that we would give the second reading of the measure a speedy passage, which we have done. But there are a number of observations I would like to make on the various clauses of the Bill which we are now going to consider in detail. Firstly perhaps I should say that, in fact, this is a. Bill to carry out the international obligations which Australia assumed under the United Nations Convention on Narcotic Drugs 1961. Of course, that is six years ago. When that Convention was made we knew that we would be expected to do something about it. We have allowed a number of years to pass while various countries added their agreement to the Convention. That process ended in 1964. Last year, apparently the Commonwealth and State Attorneys-General got together to consider the various penal provisions of the Bill. That was some considerable time ago.

speech.para: Now, into the rush of legislation, with the two Houses considering some thirty or more Bills and having very little time to do it, we find that we have injected this Narcotic Drugs Bill with some laudable provisions but also with a great number of detailed clauses imposing offences upon citizens and dealing in some remarkable ways with their rights. Honourable senators are called upon to consider it at this stage as a matter of urgency, apparently, because the Minister indicated that that was what he wanted. I regret very much that he has indicated that. It is most unfortunate that honourable senators should have to deal with a matter of such great importance with this degree of urgency. I cannot see why it has to be done. The whole world knew that there was a narcotics problem. There have been years to consider this problem but here we are faced now with these clauses. I say quite frankly that honourable senators have not time 10 consider the implications of the various clauses of this Bill in the way they should be considered.

When the Minister replies I should like him to tell me why, in the clauses dealing with offences in relation to drugs, all sorts of provisions have been handled in a lump sum way. A great number of offences has been created. There are offences which may be major offences; there are offences which may bc minor offences, yet they are all lumped together in relation to penalty. Clause 15, which comes within Part III - Offences in Relation to Drugs - is in these terms:

item.para: - (1.) A person shall not manufacture a drug unless he is the holder of a licence granted under section 9 of this Act to manufacture that drug.

speech.para: Clause 17 provides:

quote.para: A licensed manufacturer shall comply wilh any direction given to him in pursuance of section 12 of this Act with respect to the handling of drugs or narcotic preparations.

speech.para: When one turns to proposed section 12, one finds the directions expressed in this way:

item.para: - (1.) The Controller may, by notice in writing served on a licensed manufacturer, give directions to him with respect to the handling of drugs in his possession or control. (2.) A direction under this section may be given in respect of drugs generally, in respect of a drug of a kind specified in the direction or in respect of such particular drugs are as specified in the direction.

speech.para: That means any kind of direction - an important direction or a minor direction.

If one looks at the other provisions one finds that there are some extremely important matters, such as the destruction ot drugs, and some minor matters. However when one turns to penalties one docs not fmd, as one would expect to find, m'.nor penalties in relation to minor offences and major penalties in relation to major offences - gradations of penalty depending on the intent of the defendant or the circumstances of the case. Instead one finds this extraordinary provision in clause 20:

item.para: - (1.) A person who contravenes or fails to comply with a provision of this Part is guilty of an offence against this Part punishable upon conviction by, subject to sub-section (3.) of this section, a line not exceeding Four thousand dollars or imprisonment not exceeding a period of ten years, or both a fine not exceeding that amount and imprisonment for a period nol exceeding that period. (2.) An offence against this Part may be prosecuted summarily or upon indictment, but an offender is not liable to bc punished more than once in respect of the same offence.

speech.para: One would hope not - (3.) Where proceedings for an offence against this Part are brought in a court of summary jurisdiction, the court may either determine the proceedings-

One notices that no option is given to the defendant - or commit the defendant for trial, but, where the court of summary jurisdiction determines the proceedings, the court shall not impose a fine exceeding One thousand dollars or sentence the offender to imprisonment for a period exceeding two 'ears, but may impose both a fine and a period of imprisonment in respect of the offence.

This Bill deals with serious matters. There is no doubt that Part III wilh which we are concerned covers extremely serious offences. There is no doubt also that Part III may cover minor offences, but let me deal with the serious offences, which may be the simplest way to consider the matter. Here are serious offences - charges of a nature so serious that a person may become liable to imprisonment for ten years. There can be no doubt that this is a very serious matter. It is a serious matter to be charged with any offence - whether relating to narcotics, manslaughter or anything else - in the criminal code which involves liability to such a term of imprisonment. Irrespective of the penalty one may receive ultimately, the charge is a serious charge.

The thread which runs through our law and has run through it for centuries is that when a citizen is charged with a serious offence he is entitled to trial by jury. Here is a provision whereby a person who has committed an offence that, at the option of the prosecution, can render him liable to ten years imprisonment upon conviction by a jury, may, without any option, be dealt with without a jury. In other words, he may be dealt with on summary proceedings before a magistrate or similar official and there he may be given two years gaol. Leaving aside the question of the two years gaol, the serious aspect is that, a citizen may be dealt with for an offence of this weighty nature without the opportunity of trial by jury.

The Constitution of the Commonwealth includes a provision which was intended to prevent such a happening. Section 80 of the Constitution provides that all trials on indictment shall be by jury. Unfortunately that section was given an interpretation which has been much criticised as one of the most ridiculous interpretations ever given by a court. The court suggested that it was only when an actual indictment was issued that the citizen was entitled to trial by jury and that a government, by not indicting him but by charging him orally or in some other way, could avoid this great constitutional protection. It is to be hoped, as many learned writers have said, that in the future that interpretation will be changed. The relevant words of the section are these:

quote.para: The trial on indictment of any offence against any law of the Commonwealth shall be by jury.

speech.para: Irrespective of the interpretation of that provision, the philosophy of our law is that any serious offence against the criminal code shall be dealt with by a jury. This Bill contains a serious departure from that principle. It is no use saying, as the Minister may say, that such provisions have occurred in the Customs Act previously and that there may be a few similar provisions in State legislation. That is true, but 1 am raising this matter because at some point of time it has to stop. The practice started with the provision that in respect of certain offences for which a person was liable to serious punishment on indictment on trial before a jury, if that person were tried summarily the punishment could be a sentence of six months imprisonment. Then we find that in the Commonwealth Crimes

Act the sentence may be twelve months imprisonment, but that Act contains a provision which requires in most instances that a person may be dealt with summarily only with his consent. That provision does not exist here.

In this Bill we have the twin evils - the defendant has no option of trial by jury, and the penalty is two years imprisonment. I say it is time we put a stop to this. We should set some limit. When a person commits a serious offence - no one can doubt that these are serious offences - he is properly entitled to trial by jury. This legislation has all the earmarks of either haste or insufficient consideration. I am not impressed by the fact that the Anorneys-General of the Commonwealth and the Stales got together to consider these things. That would be perhaps the worst atmosphere in which to decide important legal questions affecting the citizens of this community. These are important questions. We are noi concerned about lesser penalties which may be imposed on citizens. Nothing I am saying is a plea that persons who commit serious offences should not be punished adequately. I am concerned about the mode of trial.

There is not the slightest suggestion from me that the maximum penalty of ten years imprisonment should be reduced. Let that be quite clear. 1 say that if the Bill were properly put together more consideration would have been given to the various offences instead of having a lump sum to deal with all of them, major and minor, irrespective of circumstances. That is the criticism I make, but in general 1 am not concerned about the penalty itself. Do not let thai, become a side issue in this matter. The important consideration is the mode of trial. As this legislation stands a citizen in this community may be charged with a most serious offence and summarily tried. It. is important to observe that the Crimes Act itself applies to this measure and that there is an extension of the provisions of that Act. Section 5 of the Crimes Act applies so that great width is given to these matters. It states:

quote.para: Any person who aids, abets, counsels, or procures, or by act or omission is in any way directly or indirectly knowingly concerned in, or party to, the commission of any offence against any law of the Commonwealth or of a Territory, whether passed before or after the commencement of this Act, shall be deemed to have committed that offence and shall be punishable accordingly.

speech.para: It is clear that the provisions of this Bill represent a very great extension to the operations of the Crimes Act.

There may well be cases where a person will be charged with being in some way, directly or indirectly, concerned in a matter. He may say: T am innocent. I am not concerned with whether there is a penalty of two years or ten years. I am not concerned about coming before a magistrate and perhaps getting punishment of only two or three months. 1 say that I am innocent and I insist upon having trial by jury'. Am I to believe that legislation went through this Parliament to provide that a citizen in this community charged with a serious offence - it might be called a dreadful offence - which would render him liable to be charged and punished by a maximum of ten years imprisonment plus a fine of $4,000, is not entitled when he wants it to trial by jury?

This is a very serious matter and I would like the Minister to tell me his answers to these questions. Why is it that provision cannot be made for the consent of a defendant to summary trial, thus leaving it to both the prosecution and the defendant to decide upon a summary trial. That could easily be provided.

talk.start.para: - Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.
- I rise only to enable Senator Murphy to continue his remarks.

talker.electorate: New South WalesLeader of the Opposition
talker.name: MURPHY, Lionel
Senator MURPHY

talk.start.para: - I thank the Minister for his courtesy and consideration. If what I have suggested cannot be done, I ask alternatively: Why does not the Government provide in any event that the penalty should not exceed one year? That provision would be in line with the classic thread which runs through the Constitution and distinguishes between offences dealt with by one year's imprisonment and other offences. A thread seems to run through much of the legislation. I am not saying that in this Bill some precedent for this matter cannot be found.
- ls the honourable senator asking for a reduction of the penalty?

- No. I am saying that a line has to be drawn. 1 am saying: Let the maximum penalty of ten years stand. Let that be firm. But I am also saying: Why should we not take the course of bringing this legislation into line, for instance, with the provisions of section 12 of the Crimes Act, which states, in part: (1.) Offences against this Act, other than offences expressed to be indictable offences, shall he punishable either on indictment or on summary conviction. (2.) Where proceedings for an offence against this Act are brought in a Court of Summary Jurisdiction, the Court may either determine the proceedings, or commit the defendant for trial.

speech.para: Honourable senators will be aware that the words 1 have quoted are very similar to the words in clause 20, sub-clause (3) of this Bill, which states:

quote.para: Where proceedings for an offence against this Part are brought in a court of summary jurisdiction, the court may either determine the proceedings or commit the defendant for trial, but, where the court of summary jurisdiction determines the proceedings, the court shall not impose a fine exceeding One thousand dollars or sentence the offender to imprisonment for a period exceeding two years, but may impose both a fine and a period of imprisonment in respect of the offence.

speech.para: A line is drawn between summary matters and indictable matters at one year. Section 12a of the Crimes Act states, in part: (I.) Any proceeding in respect of an offence against this Act, although declared indictable, may, with the consent of the defendant, be heard and determined by a Court of Summary Jurisdiction.
Sub-section (2) then provides that the consent of the defendant is not necessary if the charge relates to property the value of which is less than $100. Trivial matters are thus provided for.

talk.start.para: - In effect the honourable senator is advocating a reduction of penalty so far as this Bill is concerned?

- No, I am not. It is important to observe this point. I am drawing a line at the mode of trial and saying that there are principles which should be applied in respect of it. The legislation has classically drawn this line in two ways: Firstly, by providing for the consent of the defendant. He can have a summary trial instead of exercising his right to trial by jury. Secondly, in respect of matters which have been considered to be trivial - and perhaps not so trivial because a punishment of one year's imprisonment is involved - he may be subject to summary trial. My point is this: Let the ten year penalty stand. I am concerned with the mode of trial. Are we to extend the set-up where a citizen in this community can be given a summary trial; that is be deprived of trial by jury in respect of extremely serious offences and then be given more than one year's imprisonment without trial by jury? It is as simple as that. Do not let us' be distracted from this issue by a discussion of a reduction of the penalty, because the penalty will remain the same. A defendant is still open to be prosecuted under any circumstances before a jury and to be given ten years imprisonment. I have not said one word to detract from that penalty.
- This Bill provides for two years imprisonment and the honourable senator is advocating one year's imprisonment.

- No. The honourable senator should either be fair or listen to what I am saying. I am not asking that the penalty be reduced from tcn years. I say firstly that the proper principle is that a man on a serious criminal charge should be entitled to trial by jury. Next, we ought to strive to ensure that he is not to be deprived of that right without his consent. But I say that in any event we ought not to extend this legislation past the situation where he would be liable to more than one year's imprisonment on summary conviction-
- That is the point where I disagree.

- The point to come back to is that under any circumstances at all it is still open to the prosecution to take a defendant before a judge and jury and, if he is convicted, in the discretion of the judge he will receive punishment up to a maximum of ten years imprisonment plus a fine of $4,000. I have not said anything to detract from that position. I have suggested that no man should be sub jected to summary trial - that is to be deprived of the right to appear before a jury - unless he consents or unless it comes within the area of punishment which might be regarded as minor, that is, up to one year's imprisonment.

speech.para: Do not let us start extending the summary mode of trial out and out, from punishment of six months imprisonment to twelve months imprisonment to two years imprisonment. Where will it stop? The important thing for honourable senators to understand is not the punishment; it is the mode of trial. We have almost reached the time for the adjournment of the Senate. I ask Senator Anderson to give consideration overnight to the matters I have raised so that perhaps this legislation might be improved. If he does not consider improvement is necessary, then I indicate that I propose to move an amendment.
